title: A history of events in the Cienega Watershed

events.title: Early Agriculture farming occurs along Cienega Creek
events.description: People living in the Late Archaic period begin the earliest farming in the watershed using floodplain agriculture. The evidence of their use of the area include fields, pit houses, small hamlets, and villages along Cienega Creek. As people become less mobile, larger villages occur. Some of their activities are revealed in deeply buried sites below the modern surfaces.
events.source: #Huckell BB. Of Marshes and Maize--Preceramic Agricultural Settlements in the Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers Number 59; 1995

events.title: Cretaceous geologic events with intensive volcanic activity
events.description: The Cretaceous geologic period begins and ends with intense volcanic activity but then the Cretaceous sees warm climate and high sea levels with inland seas. This extension of the Gulf of Mexico is someties called the Rift valley trough or lakes. Mass extinctions of are known from the period. In the watershed, Cretaceous sediments are found in various locations. Later Pleistocene erosion and uplifting reveal Cretaceous rocks and depositions along Cienega Creek bed.
events.source:
#McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015. #McCord RD, Gillette DD. Cretaceous Vertebrates of Arizona. Vertebrate Paleontology of Arizona. 2005. 94-103
#Dickinson, WR., Fiorillo AR, Hall DL, Monreal R, Potochnick AR, Swift PN. Cretaceous Strata of Southern Arizona. Penney JP, Reynolds SJ editors. Geologic Evolution of Arizona, Arizona Geological Society Digest 17, . ; 1989. p. 447-461

events.title: Temperatures and moisture vary as in today's watershed climate
events.description: Temperatures and moisture vary as in today's watershed climate. What we experience today is not unlike earlier peoples in the watershed adapted to in their economic activities.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: Early Spanish contact many Native American groups
events.description: Apache, Sobaipuri, Akimel O'odham, Janos, Jumano, Jocome, and Suma living in regions around SE AZ where early Spanish explorations occur. Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca and three other men, one of whom was Esteban, a Moor, wandered alone through the southwest for many years. It is likely they travelled through SE AZ in early 1536. They met and were aided by many different native groups. In 1539, Fray Marcos de Niza, a Franciscan missionary, travelled through SE AZ with Esteban. Esteban reported that they were looking for Cibola, the City of Gold. It is possible that they entered through the area now known as the border town of Lochiel. According to Marcos, the many natives he met told him about the city. In 1540, Marcos leads Francisco Vasquez de Coronado and his expedition to rediscover it. The city of gold is never found; they do encounter Zuni pueblos in New Mexico.
events.source:
#Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2
#Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000.

events.title: General Land Office of the United States is established
events.description: The GLO oversees the surveying, platting, and sale of the public lands in the western United States and administers the Homestead and Preemption Acts in transfer of public lands to private owners.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: William Banning Vail arrives at the Empire Ranch
events.description: William Banning Vail, Walter Vail's son, is sent to the Empire Ranch to learn the business and eventually take over operations.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011:46

events.title: Gadsen Treaty impacts Southern Arizona
events.description: The Gadsden Treaty is signed on December 30, 1853 by James Gadsden, U.S. ambassador to Mexico, and ratified by Congress on April 25, 1854. The US purchases from Mexico lands south of the Gila River in the region of present-day southern Arizona and southwestern New Mexico for $10 M. 29,670 square miles including the Cienega Valley become part of the US. Anglo-American farmers, ranchers, and miners begin to occupy Sonoita Valley in 1856. The purchase (known in Mexico as Venta de La Mesilla, Sale of La Mesilla), is the last substantial territorial acquisition in the contiguous United States. The U.S. sought the land to provide a better route (less snow) for the construction of its southern transcontinental railway line. The Arizona portion of the Southern Pacific Railroad is built in 1880-1881.
events.source: #Gadsden J., Diez de Bonilla M, Salazar Ylarbegui J, Mariano Monterde J. Gadsden Purchase Treaty : December 30, 1853. In: United States statutes at large, containing the laws and concurrent resolutions ... and reorganization plan, amendment to the Constitution, and proclamations. •	Title varies:Public statutes at large of the United States of America v.1-8 Statutes at large of the United States of America v.9-49. 1853. 10

events.title: Empire Cienega Area designated as continentally important bird area
events.description: American Bird Conservancy designates the Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area as a Continentally Important Bird Area. As of 2000, this is the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003:A2-26

events.title: Homestead Act of 1862 to transfer public lands
events.description: This act and its many subsequent variations create an orderly system to transfer public lands to private individuals. The Law originally offers 160 acres of surveyed land to a claimant who is or who has applied for citizenship after he/she has resided on and cultivated land for 5 years. The Arizona General Land Office, the agency to manage claims and the dispensing of public lands in AZ, moves between Prescott, Tucson, Florence, and Phoenix at different times. Most of the land in the Cienega Watershed transferred from public to private ownership is accomplished either through the Homestead or the Stock Raising Homestead Acts.
events.source: #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Arizona Organic Act creates Arizona territory
events.description: Arizona, for the last 12 years has been the western half of the New Mexico Territory; is now formally its own Territory. Inhabitants demand separation due to lack of support from the territorial capital in Mesilla. Argument that influences Congressional approval is that the area needs closer government oversight of the great silver wealth produced from mining operations. Admitted during the Civil War, Congress (without the southern state representatives) legislates that all slavery is abolished in AZ Territory.
events.source: #Sonnichsen CL . Tucson Life and Times of an American City. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 1982

events.title: Yellowstone National Park is established
events.description: Yellowstone is the first reserved land to be formally set aside by Congress as a National Park. Congress, and later the executive branch, recognize the importance of protecting certain pieces of land from natural resource extraction and development and for preservation and recreation.

events.title: BLM designates Appleton Whittell Area of Critical Environmental Concern
events.description: Bureau of Land Management designates the 3,141 acres acquired from the State Trust lands and the Appletons within the Research Ranch as Appleton-Whittell Area of Critical Environmental Concern. BLM Phoenix Resource Management Plan sets prescriptions for the Appleton-Whittell Area of Critical Environmental Concern.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Coronado National Forest processes Rosemont Mine Environmental Review
events.description: Coronado National Forest issued a Record of Decision; actual mining is still pending on permits and court reviews of the process

events.title: Eusebio Kino explores Southern Arizona bringing new plants and livestock
events.description: Eusebio Francisco Kino, Jesuit priest, enters southern Arizona in 1691. He brings gifts of livestock and plants from Europe to Indian settlements and founds 3 missions (Tumacacori, Guevavi, and San Xavier del Bac) and many visitas over the next 2 decades. These gifts mark the initiation of the spread of exotic organisms into the region. As a stockman, Father Kino spread cattle in the Pimeria Alta with success and trained local populations in animal husbandry.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001. #Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000.

events.title: Peaceful transfer of the Gadsden Purchase lands from Mexico to the United States
events.description: William Kirkland, one member of the American 1st Dragoon troops, raises the American flag over Tucson marking the peaceful transfer of sovereignty of the Gadsden Purchase lands from Mexico to the United States. It was 2 years after the Gadsden Purchase was ratified by the US Senate before the transition was effected. All of the lands within the Cienega Valley were added to the United States under this agreement.
events.source:
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131
#McClintock J. Arizona. Prehistoric, Aboriginal, Pioneer, Modern. . Chicago: SJ Clarke Publishing Co; 1916

events.title: Four room Empire Ranch House is constructed
events.description: Flat-roofed, four-room house with central hallway (zaguan) constructed of hand-cast adobe blocks between 1871 and 1874 by Edward Nye Fish and William Wakefield.
events.source: #Harrison LS. Heart of the Empire. Washington, DC: National Park Service; 1992

events.title: Cattle become dominant livestock in Southeastern Arizona
events.description: Beginning in late 1800s and continuing to today, cattle become dominant regional ecological force, an exotic influence on native ecosystems.
events.source:
#Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131

events.title: Walter Vail and Herbert Hislop purchase Empire Ranch
events.description: William Wakefield sells 160-acre homestead to Edward Nye Fish and Simon Silverberg; Walter Vail and Herbert Hislop (and later John Harvey) purchase Fish's 160-acre Empire Ranch for $2,000.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: International Boundary and Water Commission forms
events.description: Commission surveys the international boundary from El Paso TX to San Diego CA finishing in 1889. Still functioning but changed over time in its authorities, the IBWC deals with issues along the US-Mexico border, especially related to water sources, amounts, quality, and with boundary issues.

events.title: Civilian Conservation Corps work in Colossal Cave Park
events.description: The Colossal Cave Project is overseen by the National Park Service. By May of 1934, the Colossal Cave Project has been authorized, and the CCC are on site, to spend four years there. The first CCC personnel to work at Colossal Cave are Company 0858. Originally from Wyoming, these CCC-ers are assigned to Camp SP-1-A at Randolph Park in Tucson in late October or early November, 1933. On May 5, 1934, instead of being transferred back to Wyoming for the summer, they are assigned duties at the new Colossal Cave state park. At first they continue to live at Camp SP-1-A and are driven back and forth to Colossal Cave each day. By February 1, 1935, they have set up a “fly camp” and are living in tents on La Posta Quemada Ranch immediately to the south of the Cave at Camp SP-10-A, the camp for the Colossal Cave Project.The men work on trails, handrails, and lighting in the Cave, and some construction of the barracks camp that follows them. In May of 1935, the fly camp is disbanded, and Company 0858 is transferred back to Camp SP-1-A, and from there to Wyoming. On August 19, 1935, Second Lieutenant J. Filbrun and twelve enrollees, forming a cadre from Camp NP-2-A, Grand Canyon, Arizona, arrive at Colossal Cave. First Lieutenant Alfred H. Johnson, the initial commander, greets the cadre. By August 22, 1935, enrollees from Texas and Arizona make up the company strength and Company 2851 is established at Camp SP-10-A. In the Cave, they widen passages, lay flagstone pathways, install handrails and lighting, and enlarge the entrance. Above ground, they construct the hewn-limestone retaining wall and Headquarters building, including the doors and shutters (and hardware) and furniture. After the work in the Cave and on the buildings is completed, the CCC personnel create the picnic areas; they build roads and several more stone structures, including the barbecue ramada in La Selvilla Picnic Area and the pumphouse.
events.source:
#Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000:
#Hunt SE, Lamb JJ, Maierhauser M. Civilian Conservation Corps Scrapbook: Camp SP-10-A Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Tucson, AZ: Colossal Cave Mountain Park; 2012

events.title: State land auction at future Audubon Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Arizona State Land Department auctions 2 parcels of County Bond Trust lands in T21S,R18E (future Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch): 320 acres of Section 17 to N.E. Clark; 40 acres Section 23 to Willard T. Roath.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008.

events.title: George Crook returns to Arizona Territory to round up last of Chiricahua Apache
events.description: Brigadier General George Crook returns to Arizona after the Chiricahua Indian Reservation has been abolished. Apaches sent to San Carlos Indian Reservation. Bad conditions and unfair treatment cause many to flee. Geronimo and Naiche and small remaining band are last to agree return to reservation. Failure to arrange their return forces Crook to request a transfer from Arizona Territory.
events.source: #Sweeney E. From Cochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886.. Norman OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2010

events.title: Thousands migrate across Arizona during Great Depression
events.description: Driven by the loss of jobs, homes, farms, and ranches, millions of people abandon their communities and travel westward looking for a different future. Most are hoping to find employment in the farm fields in California. Those affected by the early economic downturn begin arriving in Arizona in 1930. A nationwide drought and the resulting Dust Bowl drive even more westward during the mid-1930s. By then many earlier transients are leaving CA and migrating again eastward. This pattern of movement continues until the US economy recovers and employment rises dramatically as the country gears up for war in the early 1940s. New Deal programs like the Civilian Conservation Corps and the Civil Work Program start in 1933 and hire unemployed on temporary basis. No work programs known to have occurred in Cienega Watershed though many in surrounding mountain ranges and communities.
events.source:
#Williams J. Before the New Deal: Private Charity and Government Efforts to Help the Poor in Tucson, 1929-1933. Journal of Arizona History. Summer 2009. 50(2):103-124
#Weisiger, M. Mythic Fields of Plenty. The Plight of Depression-Era Oklahoma Migrants in Arizona. Journal of Arizona History. Autumn 1991. 32(3):241-266

events.title: Severe summer drought
events.description: Severe summer drought on top of overstocked ranges causes damage to grasslands. Lack of forage leads to heavy mortality of cattle. For the first time, cattlemen use railroad to move livestock to other states (Kansas, Texas, California, Montana) significantly reducing the number of stock by the end of 1886. This is the first warning for ranchers that success in stockraising will be significantly dependent on climate fluctuation.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:45

events.title: Hatch Act passes to aid state colleges
events.description: The Hatch Act, signed into law by President Lincoln, provides funds to state colleges (University of Arizona) to create agricultural experiment stations to research farm systems and to share that knowledge with ranchers and farmers. The Arizona Experiment Station manages 9 locations and supports a network of research activities throughout the state.

events.title: Major floods in Cienega Creek require moving railroad tracks
events.description: A series of major floods through lower Cienega Creek stimulate Southern Pacific RR to move tracks out of flood plain to higher ground from just east of Vail to Pantano. For years the railroad and its users had to contend with this issue making the solution of moving the higher ground important to everyone.
events.source: #David Myrick. Railroads of Arizona. Volume 1. The Southern Roads. Berkeley, CA: Howell North Books; 1975

events.title: Beaver populations gone from Cienega Creek but Rincon sightings
events.description: Due to trapping, human settlement, dams, and loss of riparian habitat, beavers are lost from the Gila River System, including Cienega Creek, by 1895. Beavers do not appear on archaeological faunal inventories of sites along Cienega Creek, but historically were likely present. Starting in 1825, beavers are trapped in the Gila and San Pedro watersheds. The 1894 Boundary Survey mentions that beaver are seen on the San Pedro River and on the Babocomeri Creek, but makes no specific mention of Cienega Creek. See Jeff Simms discussion in the Cienega Creek Shared History video Part 2. Interestingly long-time Vail resident Anne Gibson observed beaver in Rincon Creek as a child. It was when her father returned from WWII in and around 1945. 'There were beaver dams up and down Rincon Creek which helped to slow the water flow and allow for run off to seep into the two aquifers it (Rincon Creek) runs over.'
events.source:
# Carrillo C, Bergman D, Taylor JD II, Nolte DL, Viehoever P, Disney M. An Overview of Historical Beaver Management in Arizona. USDA National Wildlife Research Center, Staff Publications. 2009. 882
#Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Forest Reserve Act of 1891 passes
events.description: Congress gives the President the authority to set aside reservations of land to protect timber and water resources. The act provides no guidance or financial support for administration or management of those reserves. However President Theodore Roosevelt in the early 1900s uses the act to set aside many early Forests including Santa Rita, Santa Catalina, Rincon, and Whetstone.

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership incorporates
events.description: The Cienega Watershed Partnership (CWP) incorporates November 15, 2005. CWP grows out of a need to support the Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership and the Cienega Corridor Conservation Council, two public forums lacking the ability to receive and expend funds for project and community actions.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Empire Ranch Foundation incorporates
events.description: Empire Ranch Foundation is incorporated and established as a 501(c )(3) organization with a mission 'To protect, restore, and sustain the Empire Ranch historical builds and landscape as an outstanding western heritage education center.'
events.source: #Arizona Corporation Commission. State of Arizona Public Access System. Corporation List.. Website.2015.

events.title: Extended drought lead to animal loss
events.description: Extended drought conditions required ranchers to strategize to minimize financial loss. Despite some loss of animals, high cattle prices keep ranchers from financial loss. Ranchers refused to sell where grasses held out. Some animals were exported to Kansas for grazing and other animals sold to markets in California, Denver, Chicago and Kansas City.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55

events.title: Pancho Villa visits Bill Williams at Benson
events.description: Circle Bar Ranch's Bill Williams is friends with Pancho Villa. It is said that Ida Williams, born c. 1900, has her picture taken sitting in Pancho Villa's lap at age 3 while he visits Benson.

events.title: First Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium
events.description: First Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium begins as a quarterly meeting of the Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership. Held on the Audubon Research Ranch, topics include: grassland restoration, Montezuma quail, bird and vegetation monitoring.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: State of the Watershed focuses on Shared Cienega History
events.description: This shared history exercise becomes the Cienega Watershed Timeline Project (2012 through 2018). The Cienega Watershed Partnership and 30 partners share their knowledge of events in the watershed by writing on blank flip charts divided by millennia, centuries, and decades. Individuals are captured on YouTube discussing their specific contributions. Notes from the shared history exercise are transferred into an Excel database providing the founding documentation for the Timeline Project. These partners, who have spent up to 30 years in the watershed, provide essential knowledge that might not be captured elsewhere or readily available in print. On YouTube 13 videos are available.

events.title: Extended drought conditions
events.description: Drought with dry winter and spring conditions leads to little forage.Conditions led to a widepsread loss of one-third of the cattle.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55

events.title: Abundant rains provide good forage
events.description: Abundant summer rains develop good forage. Ranges restocked with cattle from Texas and other states. Summer rain fall allowed cattlement to recover from the last downward fluctuation.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131.

events.title: National Audubon Society renames the Appleton Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Name changes to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society, Inc. Memorandum of Agreement transfers management from The Research Ranch Foundation (aka The Research Ranch, Inc.) to National Audubon Society. This sets up an endowment to support the Research Ranch and continue important management approaches which include no grazing of the area.
events.source: #Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Forest fire rages in Rincon Mountains
events.description: This fire damages timber in the Rincon Mountains, some of the most heavily timbered mountains in Pima County, and a National Forest Reserve since 1902.
events.source:
#Baisan CH. Fire History of the Rincon Mountain Wilderness, Saguaro National Monument . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona ; August 1990
#. Fire in the Rincons. Arizona Daily Star . June 29, 1907. Pg. 8

events.title: Santa Cruz County Fair and Rodeo Association Forms
events.description: Santa Cruz County Fair and Rodeo Association forms. The organization still hosts the annual fair and rodeo events.
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: William Banning Vail of Empire Ranch marries Laura Perry
events.description: William Banning Vail, 4th son of Walter Vail, returns from California to manage the Empire Ranch in 1909. In 1913, he woos and marries Tucsonan Laura Perry.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Severe and extended drought causes cattle mortallity and drives
events.description: ' In 1920 very severe climatic conditions caused an extraordinary high mortality among cattle”. Eventually Waggoner notes that "...many stockmen being compelled to drive their cattle into Sonora where grass was more plentiful' . Ranchers were required to constantly strategize between available pasturage for grazing, makret forecast and credit, and where supplemental feed, rail transport and stockyards were available.
events.source:
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:55
#Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38
#Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:15

events.title: National Fish and Wildlife Foundation initiates Sky Island Grassland
events.description: Sky Island Grassland Initiative works in both the US and Mexico. The private foundation is set up to support landowners who wish to manage and conserve their grasslands, wetlands, and valuable wildlife habitats that lie adjacent to the Sky Islands. The initiative provides support by guiding landowners in the use of regulatory incentives, access to funding, and technical support in conservation actions.

events.title: Stock Raising Homestead Act passes to assist homesteaders
events.description: Stock Raising Homestead Act enabled homesteaders to acquire property by claiming the land to raise livestock; the requirement in the Homestead Act of 1862 for cultivation was eliminated. Act authorizes claims for 640 acres; it creates a separation of ownership of the land surface from subsurface that allows others to claim mineral and oil and gas rights below the homestead. The act is generally deemed a failure since 640 acres of grasslands in the West is still too small to raise sufficient livestock to make a living for one family. Most of the Cienega Watershed land transfers from public to private ownership are accomplished either through the Homestead or the Stock Raising Homestead Act.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Arizona surface water code is enacted
events.description: Arizona formally adopts the doctrine of prior appropriation to govern the use of surface water. This doctrine is based on the tenet of “first in time, first in right” which means that the person who first puts the water to a beneficial use acquires a right that has a higher priority than later appropriators of the water. Prior to June 12, 1919, a person could acquire a surface water right simply by applying the water to a beneficial use and posting a notice of the appropriation at the point of diversion. On June 12, 1919, the Arizona surface water code now known as the Public Water Code states a person must apply for and obtain a permit in order to appropriate surface water unless: 1) the water is from the mainstream of the lower Colorado river, in which case a contract with the Secretary of the Interior is required; 2) the person or the person’s predecessor-in-interest lawfully appropriated the water prior to June 12, 1919, and the person or the person’s predecessor-in-interest has filed a statement of claim for the appropriation with the state; 3) the water is stored in a stock pond constructed after June 12, 1919 and before August 27, 1977.

events.title: Turbine pumps come to Tucson Basin and Cienega
events.description: Once fossil fuel becomes available to make using pumps practical, turbine pumps are adopted in the Tucson Basin in the 1910s and later at Cienega Creek. These pumps are significant because water could now be pumped from much deeper areas and much faster. Thus with increased pumping throughout the Tucson and other basins, water tables begin to drop, dewatering surface soils, seeps, rivers, and creeks.
events.source: #Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve water quality studies begin
events.description: Water quality studies begun in the lower reach of Davidson Canyon in Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. Studies show high quality of water and rare value as one of last perennial water sources in Arizona. Later nomination by Pima County as Unique Waters of Arizona in 2005 and designation by Arizona Department of Environmental Quality. Purpose of nomination to protect water resources from degradation by human activities. Development of Rosemont mine in Santa Rita Mountains will affect water availability and quality in Davidson Canyon.

events.title: Another drought year
events.description: Drought in 1925 leads to shortage of forage for cattle and poor and unstable economic trends make bringing cattle to market difficult. Individual areas experience reversal of some recovery seen earlier.
events.source:
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:58
#Duncklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38

events.title: Abundant rains produce high cattle markets
events.description: Despite the stock market crash, abundant rain produces good forage and valuable steers. Market values for cattle do not fall until the following year.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:58

events.title: Las Cienegas National Conservation Area Resource Management Plan is approved
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management issues the Record of Decision approving the Resource Management Plan for the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. This guides decisions on land uses and how specific desired management goals will be met for over 47,000 acres of public land, resources, and uses within the Las Cienegas NCA and Sonoita Valley Acquisition Planning District. The LCNCA Resource management plan also includes management of the Appleton-Whittell Research ACEC.
events.source:
#Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003
#Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Joe Jr. and Jack Kennedy summer at J Six Ranch
events.description: Joe, Jr. and Jack Kennedy spend a summer during their teens; they assist in constructing a small adobe building.

events.title: Extended drought leads to regional disaster
events.description: Drought begins in the summer of 1933 and continues through January 1935. By the spring of 1934, 2/3 of the nation is drought-stricken. All southern Arizona counties are considered emergency areas. A national program of drought relief for farmers and ranchers begins in mid-1934.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:59

events.title: Federal Farm Bill supports struggling agriculture
events.description: The farm bill is the primary agricultural and food policy tool of the federal government. The comprehensive omnibus bill is passed every 5 years or so. The farm bill was first created during the Great Depression to give financial assistance to farmers struggling due to excess crops, which resulted in low prices, and also to control and ensure an adequate food supply. The first farm bill, known as the Agricultural Adjustment Act (AAA), was passed in 1933 as a part of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal. The bill allows farmers to receive payment for not growing food on a percentage of their land as allocated by the Secretary of Agriculture.

events.title: Cochise and Chiricahua Apaches initiate 11 year conflict with Americans
events.description: Second Lieutenant George Bascom from Fort Buchanan confronts Chiricahua Apache chief Cochise at Apache Pass and falsely accuses him of abducting a young Mexican boy from a ranch near Sonoita. Both sides take prisoners, including relatives of Cochise, and kill them. Cochise begins a campaign to eliminate all settlers from Southeast Arizona that lasts until the establishment of the Chiricahua Apache reservation in 1872 in the Sulphur Springs Valley.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:88-90

events.title: The Nature Conservancy fine tunes Las Cienegas monitoring
events.description: The Nature Conservancy comes in to tailor monitoring and ensure it addresses main indicators (management trigger points); with BLM works on grassland monitoring; 2006 – wet/dry monitoring [challenge cost share of federal funding is valuable mechanism for sustaining collaboration and partnerships]

events.title: Soil Conservation Service is established
events.description: The agency is founded largely through the efforts of Hugh Hammond Bennett, a soil conservation pioneer who had worked for the Department of Agriculture from 1903 to 1952. Bennett's motivation is based on his knowledge of the detrimental effects of soil erosion and the impacts on U.S lands that leads to the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. On September 13, 1933, the Soil Erosion Service is formed in the Department of the Interior, with Bennett as chief. The service is transferred to the Department of Agriculture on March 23, 1935, and is shortly thereafter combined with other USDA units to form the Soil Conservation Service by the Soil Conservation and Domestic Allotment Act of 1935. Hugh Bennett continues as chief, a position he holds until his retirement in 1952. On October 20, 1994, the agency is renamed Natural Resource Conservation Service as part of the Federal Crop Insurance Reform and Department of Agriculture Reorganization Act of 1994. Today NRCS continues to provide education and assistance to individual land owners to manage and restore soils on their properties.

events.title: First aerial photographs of Cienega Watershed reveal erosion
events.description: First aerial photographs of Cienega Watershed to look at soil erosion by the Soil Conservation Service (now Natural Resources Conservation Service). Comparisons with modern aerial photographs show that the arroyo has reached approximate depth of modern day, but widening continues.
events.source: #Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Soil Conservation Range Benefit Program begins
events.description: Soil Conservation Range Benefit Program begins. The program encourages range improvement and erosion mitigation on private range lands through better stock distribution. Funds available to develop fences, dirt dams, stock tanks, and wells. By the summer 1937, 450 Arizona ranchers were co-operating.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:61

events.title: The Phoenix Grazing Region 9 is established
events.description: Under the Taylor Grazing Act of 1934, unclaimed, public domain lands are divided into districts or regions of similar climate and ecology. These regions are managed by the Grazing Service (later the Bureau of Land Management). Each district has an advisory council of local ranchers to advise on management. Within the district, allotments are leased to applicants for a period of 10 years. Region 9 contains some of the most contentious cattlemen and as a result is one of the last regions to be created.

events.title: Bankhead Jones Farm Tenant Act to improve conservation
events.description: Act 1) provided loans to poor farmers, 2) helped farmers rehabilitate tired farm land, and 3) allowed the Secretary of Agriculture to purchase submarginal lands to control soil erosion and reforestation, preserve natural resources, mitigate flooding, prevent impairment of dams and reservoirs,conserve soil moisture, and protect streams.11.3 M acres acquired; 1/2 given to BLM and other Department of Interior agencies, rest to USFS to create National Grasslands.

events.title: Seasonal variations help in a dry decade
events.description: This decade experiences variation in dry years and normal years allowing some recovery from the 1930s severe droughts.
events.source: #Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:44

events.title: Lehmann Lovegrass and Boer Lovegrass planted on Babocomari Ranch
events.description: Lehmann Lovegrass and Boer Lovegrass (exotic grasses from Africa) are planted on Babocomari Ranch by U.S. Soil Conservation Service for range improvement and revegetation. These non-native species will cause trouble for native ecosystems.
events.source: #Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: First General Land Office opens in Prescott
events.description: The General Land Office opens its first Arizona office in Prescott in 1870. It is open until 1904. In 1873 a second office is opened in Florence, moved to Tucson in 1881, and subsequently moved again to Phoenix in 1905.
events.source: #Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015. #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Chiricahua Apache Reservation is established and later closes
events.description: Chiricahua Apache Reservation established. First interlude of peace in more than 40 years. Boundaries include San Simon Valley south of Gila River to Mexico border and Dragoon Range to New Mexico border. This lull in hostilities creates the opportunity for the most courageous and resilient stockmen to establish their ranching businesses. Walter Vail and Herbert Hislop purchase Empire Ranch in Cienega Valley at this time. The Indian Reservation is closed in 1876 and the land returned to public domain. The Chiricahua Apaches are removed to San Carlos reservation. Many flee and renew old raiding patterns. The spatial organization of the Empire Ranch evolves as a direct consequence of the changing level of Apache threats.
events.source: #Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Black tailed prairie dog colonies disappear
events.description: Black-tailed prairie dogs are believed to have been eliminated from Arizona by 1961.
events.source: #Hoffmeister DF. Mammals of Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1986

events.title: Fort Huachuca is established to control Apache raiding
events.description: Fort Huachuca established in 1877 as one of the military encampments to aid in control and prevention of depredations by the Chiricahua Apaches after their reservation had been eliminated. The Fort's establishment coincides with some of the worst conflicts with a small group of Apaches who refuse to stay at the San Carlos reservation and instead escape to follow Naiche and Geronimo. The site is chosen for its quick access to the border region. Walter Vail, Herbert Hislop, and John Harvey, partners in the Empire Ranch, believe that they and their business will be more secure with a military fort only 30 miles away. The Fort plays an important role of the final efforts under Generals Crook and Miles to end Apache raiding and to effect the removal of the Chiricahua from Southern Arizona.
events.source: #Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015. #Collins W et al . The United States Military in Arizona, 1846-1945. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona State Historic Preservation Office; 1993:30

events.title: Mustang Fire
events.description: The Mustang Fire is 27.18 acres (0.11 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: Narragansett copper mine claim is sold to Ramsdell
events.description: J.K. Brown sells Narragansett claim to William Ramsdell. The Narragansett in upper McCleary Canyon produces 34,300 tons of copper ore and employs up to 270 miners during Ramsdell's ownership. Ramsdell runs the company store as well. The mine closes in 1918 when ore thins and value of copper declines at end of WW1. The mine has already produced 5M lbs of copper and 42,000 ozs of silver. Today the mine is part of the proposed Rosemont Mine development area in the NE Santa Rita Mountains.
events.source:
#Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Briggs D. History of Helvetia-Rosemont Mining District, Pima County, Arizona. Arizona Geological Survey. June 2014. Contributed Report, CR-14-D:5-6
#Ayres J. The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) ; 1984:135-136
#Schaefer J. The Anamax Project. History of the Rosemont Area in the Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Arizona State Museum; 1979:25-26

events.title: Frank Schmidt files two mining claims on land occupied by Colossal Cave
events.description: Frank Schmidt files two mining claims on land occupied by the Cave, and sublets land surrounding it from Empire Ranch. He and three others are reported by local newspapers to have made the first extensive survey of the Cave, traveling within it for six days before exhausting their supply of food and water.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Federal Noxious Weed Act passes requiring integrated federal programs
events.description: The Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to declare some plants as noxious weeds and to limit their Interstate movement without a permit. The act requires agencies in the Department of the Interior (the National Park Service, the Bureau of Land Management, the US Fish & Wildlife Service) and the US Forest Service in the Department of Agriculture, to develop integrated management programs. In the Cienega Watershed, current programs target plants such as Lehman's Lovegrass or Bufflegrass.

events.title: Breeding program for endangered Bolson tortoise on the Research Ranch
events.description: Program established by Ariel Appleton for the exotic Bolson tortoise, a non-native to the area. She formally establishes a breeding program to support native populations elsewhere, mainly in Mexico.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013. #Appleton A. The Research Ranch, A Dream Becomes Reality. National Parks & Conservation Magazine. Dec 1973.

events.title: Food Security Act passes to improve private lands
events.description: Food Security Act requires farmers who receive USDA assistance to have a conservation plan for their Highly Erodible Land (HEL) soils, and wetlands. The Conservation Reserve Program, a subunit of the FSA, pays farmers to remove environmentally sensitive lands from agricultural production and to plant species that improve the environmental health and quality, prevent erosion, and reduce loss of wildlife habitat. FSA is the largest private land conservation program in the US.

events.title: Shrine of Santa Rita in the Desert is built and dedicated in Vail
events.description: Built by Caroline Takamine Beach for 'the poor Hispanic ranching families', the Shrine honors Caroline's first husband, Japanese scientist Jokichi Takamine. Architects are H.D.R. Figge and D. Burr DuBois.
events.source: #National Register of Historic Places Nomination. Shrine of Santa Rita in the Desert. Nomination number: 14001231.Dec 7, 2015.

events.title: Civil War in Southern Arizona
events.description: In 1861 the southern half of the New Mexico territory is claimed as part of the Confederate States, and a confederate garrison is established in Tucson. Tucson is 'liberated' by the 1st California Volunteer Cavalry on May 20, 1862. The major consequence for inhabitants of Southern Arizona is the withdrawal of most established military encampments leaving settlers to defend themselves against intensified Apache depredations. Most settlers abandon the area during the war.

events.title: Bomber Fire on Research Ranch
events.description: The Bomber Fire on Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch is 900 acres (3.642 sq. km,) in size. Residents of Elgin report seeing a low-flying aircraft jettison a large quantity of some unknown liquid before it banks steeply upward and flies away. Minutes later they see smoke rising. Burning in O'Donnell and Post Canyons and Turkey Creek, fire burns mostly sacaton areas and grasslands but also kills cottonwood and mesquite trees. Fire temporarily opens burned areas to other native plants and animals and retards dominance of sacaton for 14 months. Larry and Marsha Michel are Directors of the Research Ranch.
events.source:
#Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000
#Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013. #The Research Ranch, Inc.. Annual Report. Elgin, AZ: The Research Ranch, Inc; 1975

events.title: Tucson Plant Material Center introduces non native grasses to SE AZ
events.description: Tucson Plant Material Center established for range regeneration and erosion control research under Soil Conservation Service. FJ Crider imports Lehmann lovegrass, buffel grass, and other non-native grasses from South Africa. While introduced grasses are beneficial for erosion control, non-natives outcompete native grasses and plants, are less palatable to and nutritious for livestock, and will fuel more intensive, hotter fires that kill other native plants. Lehmann's lovegrass has explosively spread throughout SE AZ rangelands. Buffel grass is invading much of metropolitan Tucson and increases local fire danger.
events.source: #Crider FJ. Three Introduced Lovegrasses for Soil Conservation. US Department of Agriculture Circular 730; 1945

events.title: Walter Armer submits first instream flow for Cienega Creek
events.description: Advised by hydrologist Leonard Halpenny, Walter Armer, rancher of Flying R and Bar V, files for the first instream flow right on Cienega Creek. Armer already has his own water rights claim. He is concerned that with the development of the Rosemont Mine in the near future, he will need to secure through this water rights claim additional water. That instream flow claim and its priority date pass to Pima County when it acquires Armer's properties.
events.source: #Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Food Conservation and Energy Act aims to improve land stewardship
events.description: The Act is another extension in the series of 5-year agricultural subsidy bills. It also supports the Conservation Security Program that encourages producers to augment their stewardship of the land by improving conservation practices.

events.title: Arizona Unique Waters nomination for Cienega Creek
events.description: Pima County nominates a 28.3 mile reach of Cienega Creek from Gardner Canyon into the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve as a Unique Water of Arizona. Later the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality approves the designation. Later the Creek is redesignated Outstanding Arizona Water but the importance remains the same. The designation implies that the waters should be protected from degradation of water quality by human activities.
events.source: #Fonseca J et al. Unique Waters Final Nomination Report for Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; Nov 28 1990

events.title: Colossal Cave discovered by Solomon Lick
events.description: Searching for stray cows, Lick discovers an entrance to 'either a very extensive old mine, or a wonderful cave,' and undertakes a series of explorations of what today is known as Colossal Cave.

events.title: Due to acute drought, monitoring initiated at the Cienega Preserve
events.description: Because of the acute drought, the Pima Association of Governments begin a monitoring program at the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve (GW ESWS). Quarterly monitoring is reported. Other watersheds across Arizona adopt PAG standards for a network of monitoring. Detailed quarterly monitoring results in a data set which aids in understanding flooding events, preciptation, and stream flow.

events.title: The Friends of Kentucky Camp forms
events.description: The Friends of Kentucky Camp is formed as a non-profit to assist the Forest Service in the rehabilitation and interpretation of Kentucky Camp. The Friends Newsletters outline projects and activities and give updates on Kentucky Camp.
events.source: #Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle {Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: Pima County establishes the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve
events.description: Rancher Walter Armer sells his ranch to the Pima County Regional Flood Control District so that the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve could be established by the Pima County Board of Supervisors. The ranch is acquired to preserve riparian habitats, reduce peak stormwater flow, facilitate groundwater recharge and preserve areas of the Cienega Creek corridor from destructive uses. Julia Fonseca begins at Cienega Creek as the first preserve manager. The 4010 acres are managed jointly by the RFCD and the Pima County Natural Resources, Parks and Recreation Department.
events.source: #Fonseca J.. Cienega Watershed Shared History Part Three. Personal Communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Save America's Treasures Millennium grant for Empire Ranch preservation work
events.description: Empire Ranch preservation work is aided by a $95,000 Save America’s Treasures Millennium Grant, a National Park Service program. The Bureau of Land Management applies for and receives the grant, and the Empire Ranch Foundation raises the required matching funds by December 31, 2000. Project work is completed in 2002.
events.source: #Auerbach C. The Empire Ranch Headquarters: A Partnership for Protection and Preservation. Forum Journal, National Trust for Historic Preservation.. 2008. 22(4):30-35..
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: World War II
events.description: World War II is a global conflict that involves 100 million people in 30 countries but is fought primarily in Europe, Africa, and Asia. It is initiated on September 9, 1939, when Nazi Germany invades Poland and ends in Europe when Germany surrenders on May 8 1945 and in the Pacific when Japan surrenders on August 15, 1945, after the US drops a second nuclear weapon on the city of Nagasaki. Between 53 and 80 million people died during the war. The US enters the war in December 1941 following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in Hawaii. In Southern Arizona, as with most of the rest of the country, people at home struggled with restrictions and rations on goods and materials -- gasoline, rubber and tires, metals such as wire for fencing. As with WW1, there was also a significant labor shortage with so many men oversees. Women and youth all stepped forward to fill those vacancies. Many men working in the food producing industries were exempt from service. Their contributions at home were deemed as important.

events.title: Greaterville gold deposits are depleted at Kentucky Camp
events.description: Greaterville gold deposits 'worked-out' with traditional panning techniques at Kentucky Camp.
events.source: #Doumas, M. Kentucky Camp Interpretive Plan. Personal communication.May 10, 2013.

events.title: National Historic Preservation Act expands site protection
events.description: The Act (Public Law 89-665; 16 U.S.C. 470 et seq.) preserves historical and archaeological sites; creates the National Register of Historic Places, the list of National Historic Landmarks, and the State Historic Preservation Office. Eight sites, structures, or landscapes in the Cienega Watershed are on the National Register including: Empire Ranch, Cienega Bridge, Empirita Ranch Rural Historic District, Colossal Cave Historic District, Kentucky Camp Historic District, Upper Davidson Canyon Archaeological District, Old Vail Post Office, and the Shrine of Santa Rita In the Desert.

events.title: Pima County removes livestock from the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve
events.description: Pima County Regional Flood Control District and Pima County Natural Resources, Parks and Recreation remove livestock from the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve in order to restore sections of Cienega Creek and adjacent native vegetation communities. Once cattle are removed, deer grass and cattail return and pools form. The preserve corridor is fenced off to block livestock but open to an array of mammals that use the corridor. Scientists monitor the water and vegetation regularly to track flow and vegetation regrowth.

events.title: Coronado National Forest revises land use plan
events.description: To replace the 1986 land use plan, a new process begins in 2006. After preparation of environmental impact statement and associated reviews, the Record of Decision is signed April 27, 2018. The new plan is effective in July 2018. The land use plan reviews the larger landscape management issues for Coronado National Forest including those sections of the Whetstone and Santa Rita Mountains that are in or adjacent to the Cienega Watershed. The Plan directs how forest lands will be used and managed for multiple purposes.

events.title: Wildlife cameras sight jaguar and ocelot
events.description: On December 20, 2012, through a joint news release, the US Fish and Wildlife Service, Arizona Game and Fish Department, and the University of Arizona announce that pictures of a jaguar taken in late November of that year in the Santa Rita Mountains using camera-traps, are of the same individual photographed one year earlier. The camera-traps had been set by the Jaguar Survey and Monitoring Project, an initiative led by the University of Arizona. The cat’s unique spot pattern matches that of a male jaguar photographed by a hunter in the fall of 2011 in the Whetstone Mountains.This provides clear evidence that the big cats travel between southern Arizona’s “sky island” mountain ranges. A new ocelot photo is taken in the Huachuca Mountains November 20, 2012, four miles away from previous locations, by one of the UA project cameras. Again, comparisons of the spot patterns reveal this to be the same male ocelot that has been reported by the AGFD photographed in the Huachucas several times in 2011 and 2012. The jaguar had been listed for Federal protection in 1997 and the ocelot in 1982 under the Endangered Species Act. The presence of a Federally protected jaguar and ocelot in the area means that Federal actions, including Rosemont Mine, must take effects to the species into consideration.
events.source: #U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, University of Arizona, Arizona Fish and Game Department. Jaguar and Ocelot Recently Photographed by Monitoring Cameras in Southern Arizona. News Release. Dec 20, 2012.

events.title: Chiricahua Leopard frogs at the Clyne Ranch
events.description: Constructed by the Clyne family likely in the 1950s as a cattle water source, the Clyne pond once had Chiracahua Leopard Frog. In the 1960s to 1970s, exotic species like Bluegill sunfish, bullfrogs, largemouth bass and crayfish are introduced. In 2007, crayfish are documented as present. In 2009 the Ranch is purchased by Pima County. In 2010, breeding populations of bullfrogs and crayfish remain but are removed when the pond is drained between 2010 and 2012. Chiricahua Leopardf Frogs are re-introduced, but numbers remain low except for the summer of 2017.
events.source: #Hall D. Local Population Dynamics of the Chiricahua Leopard Frog (Rana chiricahuensis) a Federally-Listed Frog within the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area in Arizona, Report to the Cienega Watershed Partnership and the Bureau of Land Management. Tucson, A: FROG Project, Cienega Watershed Partnership ; Dec.19, 2019

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership Annual Meeting in Sonoita
events.description: Held at local Sonoita winery, Wilhelm Family vineyards, preceded by snow storm. Board of Directors: Martie Maierhauser (Chair), David Scalero (Secretary), Trevor Hare (Vice Chair), Shela McFarlin, Mead Mier, Larry Fisher
events.source: McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Jaguar Critical Habitat designated in Upper Cienega Watershed
events.description: The areas designated as Critical Jaguar Habitat include the upper elevations of the Whetstone, Santa Rita, and Patagonia Mountains, the Canelo Hills,and the western slopes of the Huachuca Mountains. Critical Habitat identifies areas containing features essential to the conservation of a listed species and may require special management considerations or protection. Critical Habitat does not affect land ownership or establish a refuge, and has no impact on private landowners taking actions on their land that do not require federal funding or permits. The designation has little effect on development within the bounded area except to prohibit future harm resulting from federally funded activities.
events.source: #Department of the Interior. Fish and Wildlife Service. Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Designation of Critical Habitat for Jaguar . Final Rule. Federal Register. March 5, 2014. 79(43):12572-12654

events.title: PaleoIndian groups occupy the Cienega watershed
events.description: While archaeological sites show that people occupied southeast Arizona, paleoindian sites in the Cienega watershed are not abundant. Sites are generally lacking and small in size and contents showing that humans continued to use the Cienega watershed but remains indicate that small groups of humans continue to hunt large animals and game. Their economic pursuits are likely very diverse taking advantage of seasonal vegetation communities and animal movements.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: End of Ice Age is an Ecological Transition
events.description: Temperatures cooler than now, less arid; grassland with marshes. PaleoIndian people had a variety of plants and animals available for food and resources. Some animals became extinct including mammoths, camel, horse, some bear species, bison and sloth.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: Erosional episodes during early agricultural period
events.description: Climate changes produces erosion. Incisions and filling events on Cienega Creek result in buried archaeological sites over 15 ft in depth. While this buries some features, continued erosion exposes these older sites.
events.source: #Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Climatic transition period is warmer and drier than today
events.description: Warmer and drier than now and the period proceeding this one. Channel-cutting noticeable with erosion periods during the transition. Human populations may have been sparse and communities may have moved up into more mountainous areas. Smaller animals and different plan communities were available.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001

events.title: US Forest Service acquires Kentucky Camp
events.description: US Forest Service acquires the property as part of a land swap. Site is named Kentucky Camp, a name that is neutral to its former mining and ranching uses.
events.source: #Doumas, M. Kentucky Camp Interpretive Plan. Personal communication.May 10, 2013.

events.title: Pima County acquires the Sands and Clyne Ranches increasing conservation lands
events.description: With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County acquires 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch located in the far southeast corner of Pima County. (In its entirety, the historic Sands Ranch totals 64,000 acres, extending east of Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to the San Pedro River in Cochise County.) This acquisition further connects a system of publicly-owned lands from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains, especially when coupled with the County’s subsequent acquisition of the adjacent Clyne Ranch. Not only does it contribute to the health of the Cienega Watershed, but also conserves high quality native grasslands and wildlife movement corridors.

events.title: General Mining Law passed governing mineral lands
events.description: The General Mining Act of 1872 identifies mineral lands subject to exploration, occupation, and purchase under stipulated conditions. The law governs prospecting and mining for gold, silver, copper, and other valuable minerals. It codifies a system to acquire and protect claims. Any unpatented claim must be worked every year. Patent provision transfers lands to private ownership. Example: Rosemont copper mining area.
events.source: #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: 355 acres of National Forest lands are withdrawn for Natural Research Area
events.description: Public Land Order 5835 withdraws 355 acres of National Forest lands from mining claims and for Natural Research Area. (Section 26,T21S,R18E)
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Arizona is granted statehood
events.description: President Taft signs legislation granting Statehood to Arizona. Arizona's Statehood Act gives title to all unreserved Sections 2, 16, 32 & 36 in each township for 'school sections' to be held in trust for support of the state's public school system or other state institutions either for sale or for lease. Most of those lands were only useful for grazing purposes. 10.5 Million acres of public domain land initiallly transfered to Arizona. Due to land trades between state and federal agencies, the State of Arizona holds the largest amount of land in the Cienega watershed. Most of those exchanges took place between 1915 and 1960. Often ranchers requested that the state claim those lands adjacent to their own properties so that the ranchers might have a good option to lease those lands for grazing. Today many of those state-owned properties are leased to ranchers at low cost for grazing purposes, including state lands within the LCNCA. Title of Section 16 (NW corner of Research Ranch) passes to the State.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Biological Planning process begins for Empire Cienega Allotment
events.description: Mac and John Donaldson, grazing permit-holders for Bureau of Land Management lands for the Empire-Cienega Allotment, begin the biological planning process as part of their grazing management. Working with Grant Drennen and Karen Simms of the BLM staff, this new approach is later expanded into a formal process. The Biological Planning workshops continue into 2022.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: Good rain year Tucson and Empire Ranch
events.description: On July 11, Tucson receives 5” of rain in 70 minutes. 5 feet of water in downtown streets. In August, flooding reported on the Empire Ranch.
events.source: #Woolley JJ, Wilkening L. The Empire Ranch and Walter L. Vail. The Copper State Journal. 2002. 37(4):12-17:14

events.title: Nelson Miles commands AZ military to capture and deport last of Chiricahua Apache
events.description: General Nelson A. Miles assumes command of all Southwest Army forces to recapture last of Chiricahua Apaches. Indians brought to Fort Bowie and deported from Arizona to Florida on September 8 1886. Decades later, the Chiricahua are given choice to reside at Ft Sill OK or at Mescalero Reservation in NM but not to return to southern AZ.
events.source: #Sweeney E. From Cochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886.. Norman OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2010

events.title: Multiple rain events cause significant flooding damage and erosion
events.description: Droughts and floods accompanied by severe overgrazing are major causes of arroyo formation, water channel deepening, and decline of water tables throughout SE AZ.

events.title: Pancho Villa raids New Mexico
events.description: In January 1916, Pancho Villa kidnapped 18 Americans from a Mexican train and killed them. A few weeks later Villa led his guerilla troops across the border to stage a brutal raid against the small American town of Columbus, New Mexico. Villa was seeking military equipment and supplies. There his troops killed 19 citizens and burned the town. Under President W. Wilson's orders and with the permission of Mexico, General Pershing and 6000 troops pursued Villa inside Mexico for two years. He was not captured despite Pershing's use of trucks and aircraft for the first time by an American army. The presence of American troops inside Mexico led to resentment in local communities long remembered.

events.title: Frank Schmidt runs the first guided tours into Colossal Cave
events.description: These tours consist of outfitting his guests with ropes and lanterns and leading them through the unimproved passageways. Women were advised to wear bloomers (for modesty). As time went by, Schmidt strung a few electric light bulbs on a bare wire and put in some wooden steps and pathways. He never ceased exploring in the Cave.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Augusta Resources Corporation acquires Rosemont property to open major copper mine
events.description: Augusta signs an options agreement for Rosemont lands on 4/18/2005 and completes the purchase of private property 3/31/2006. The Rosemont property sits in the northeast portion of the Santa Rita Mountains. With the acquisition, Augusta initiates planning for a major copper mine and associated facilities at Rosemont in private and public lands (managed by the Coronado National Forest).

events.title: US Grazing Service becomes Bureau of Land Management
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) is created by Congress through the merger of the General Land Office, the Grazing Service, and the Oregon and California Railroad (O&C) Revested Lands Administration
events.tags: United States, Bureau of Land Management

events.title: Failed Pima County effort to acquire Empire Ranch
events.description: Efforts fail for Pima County to acquire Empire Ranch lands to create open space from Mexico to Oracle. Instead many acres were marketed as ranchettes. The conservation biology principlies supporting corridors and keeping the landscapes whole were then encorporated into other county planning like the Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan.

events.title: Major drought decimates cattle industry in southeastern Arizona
events.description: Twenty-eight month-long drought with less than 70% of expected rainfall. In 1891 causes 50-75% loss of livestock as forage severely depleted and springs and wells dry up. One of the five most severe droughts in Southern Arizona.
events.source:
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:53
#Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Heavy summer rains
events.description: Tremendous summer rains, high cattle production, coupled with high cattle prices cause ranching over-optimism. Ranchers hold cattle on ranges hoping for even higher prices.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:54

events.title: Tohono O'Odham people move from Greaterville to San Xavier
events.description: While some Tohono O'Odham have already left the Greaterville area, once the Tohono O'Odham Reservation is established in 1916, further movement occurs. Part of the Tohono O'Odham Nation, the San Xavier reservation is first established in 1874. Documentation of historic presence Important for understanding cultural linkage to the Santa Rita mountains.
events.source: #Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Chamberlain surveys fish distribution and species in S AZ
events.description: Frederick Moulton Chamberlain surveys fish in southern Arizona and records fish distribution and species descriptions in the Santa Cruz River basin.
events.source: #Minckley WL. Frederick Morton Chamberlain's 1904 Survey of Arizona Fishes, with Annotations. Journal of the Southwest . 1999. 41(2)177-238

events.title: Bureau of Land Management fences Cienega Creek in the Empire Cienega Allotment
events.description: In the Empire Cienega Allotment (now part of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area), the BLM fences off the Cienega Creek corridor. Once cattle no longer graze the area, native riparian vegetation begins to respond. Heavy canopy cover expands even-aged stands of trees. With less light and more leaf filter, the Gila topminnow community is impacted negatively.

events.title: Pima County Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Management Plan released
events.description: Pima County plan outlines objectives and policies for management of the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve, a 3,979-acre parcel located along Cienega Creek, managed by Pima County Flood Control District. Approximately half of the reach exhibits perennial stream flow. The quality of surface water in Cienega Creek is very good. A reach of the creek within the Preserve has been designated as a Unique Water of Arizona due in part to the excellent quality of the surface water. The stream channel is deeply incised. The Preserve is significant due to the presence of perennial stream flow and lush riparian vegetation, which creates an area with very high values for recreation, scenic quality, and wildlife habitat. The natural condition of the site also serves to facilitate groundwater recharge and to ameliorate the intensity of storm water runoff from the Cienega Creek basin, which drains into and through the Tucson metropolitan area. The significance of the Preserve is high as of a very few remaining examples of a desert riparian environment.
events.source: #Scalero D. Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. Personal communication.Nov 2012.

events.title: GEP Smith designs subsurface dam on Lower Cienega Creek
events.description: G. E. P. Smith, University of Arizona hydrologist and first hydrologist in the state of Arizona, designs a subsurface dam on lower Cienega Creek near present-day Rancho del Lago. The dam increases the water levels in Cienega Creek. The concrete arched dam remains today. Smith, also a civil engineer, is instrumental in all aspects of water management. He is involved in the creation of the first Arizona Water Law in 1919 and the design of turbine pumps that bring water from a much greater depth than earlier designs.
events.source: #Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication. Nov. 2012.

events.title: Anglo Americans begin to arrive in Southern Arizona region
events.description: The California Gold Rush of 1848 stimulates a major movement of Anglo Americans and other nationalities westward across the United States. Many entrepreneurs during their crossing note the available natural resources of wildlife, timber, and grasslands and return to Arizona when their gold fever abates.

events.title: Taylor Grazing Act regulates livestock access on public lands
events.description: Taylor Grazing Act of 1934 authorizes grazing districts and regulations of public lands. (Pub.L. 73–482) (excluding Alaska). It is the first national law to provide for regulated control of the unappropriated grazing land. The act is intended to help prevent overgrazing and erosion, improve rangeland conditions and regulate their use; lands are administered by the Department of the Interior. As amended, the law applies to approximately 162,000,000 acres inside grazing allotments. These can be vacant, unappropriated, and unreserved land from public lands, all except for Alaska, national forests, parks, monuments, Indian reservations, railroad grant lands, etc. Permits are given for grazing privileges in the districts, or to build fences, reservoirs, and other improvements. Permittees are required to pay a fee; permit cannot exceed ten years but is renewable. Permits can be revoked because of severe drought or other natural disasters that deplete grazing lands.The act also ends the opportunity to claim a homestead, when the remaining unappropriated lands come under federal control. Most importantly, it ends the opportunity to graze livestock for free on federal lands.
events.source: #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Pima County acquires Empirita Ranch
events.description: Between 1988 and 1990, the Pima County Flood Control District purchases 360 acres of the Empirita Ranch. In 2009, Pima County’s acquisition of the 2,700-acre Empirita property conserves the last remaining portions of the private land that comprised the historic Empirita Ranch. With assistance from the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County negotiates the purchase of the Empirita property. The owner also assigns the County its contractual right to withdraw up to 1,600 acre-feet of groundwater annually from the Cienega Creek Basin. The Empirita acquisition expands upon already conserved reserves, including the Coronado National Forest, the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, and the County’s Bar V Ranch, Empirita Ranch, and Cienega Creek Natural Preserve.

events.title: AZ Game and Fish begin releasing bullfrogs across Arizona
events.description: The Arizona Game and Fish Department introduces non-native species, including fish, crayfish, and American bullfrogs (Lithobates catesbeianus) for food and for sport purposes starting in the 1920s. Bullfrogs compete with and often prey upon many aquatic species and have detrimental effects on native fish and amphibian populations including on protected native species, such as the Chiricahua leopard frog and Mexican garter snake. Bullfrogs are also very adept at natural dispersal over significant distances from occupied sites via perennial streams, intermittent streams, or over land. It is not until the 1980s that scientists determine that bullfrogs have contributed to the loss of native fish, frogs, and snakes. Researchers determine that bullfrogs are also eating a wide range of species such as bats and birds. University of Arizona scientists, including Drs. Cecil Schwalbe and Phil Rosen, develop programs to eliminate bullfrogs, with extensive programs in Pima County at Buenos Aires National Wildlife Refuge, and beginning in 2002 in the Cienega Creek Watershed. Bullfrogs are first observed in Empire Valley in 1986, according to Rosen and Schwalbe, after being introduced into a livestock pond, and apparently, dispersing into Cienega Creek.
events.source: #Brown DE. Biotic Communities, Southwestern United States and Northwestern Mexico, Second Edition . Logan, Utah:University of Utah Press; 1994

events.title: Pima County acquires Clyne Ranch
events.description: Pima County’s December 2008 acquisition of 5,000 acres of the Sands Ranch, located east of Las Cienegas National Conservation Area creates an interconnected corridor of conserved lands stretching from the Santa Rita Mountains to the Whetstone Mountains. With the assistance of the Arizona Land and Water Trust, the County then acquires the Clyne Ranch parcels, totaling 880 acres, east of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area and adjacent to the Sands Ranch. In addition, development restrictions are placed on 90 acres maintained by the seller. The ranch is an integral part of this assemblage of publicly-owned lands and further contributes to this corridor through the Cienega Valley. The Clyne Ranch parcels, like the Sands Ranch, contain high quality native grasslands found in the Sonoita Valley area.

events.title: Empire Ranch House listed on National Register of Historic Places
events.description: The Empire Ranch House and surrounding 160 acres are listed on National Register of Historic Places; submitted by Marjorie Wilson, Arizona State Parks, and approved May 1975.
events.source: #National Park Service. National Register of Historic Places. Website.2015.

events.title: Cienega Creek groundwater becomes public concern
events.description: Cienega Creek groundwater becomes public concern in that overpumping is affecting Cienega Creek water flows. Cienega Creek, dependent on groundwater to feed flows, may become one of the last perennial Arizona waters.
