events.title: Wild horses collected during droughts
events.description: In both drought periods, 1933-1934 and 1938, 'wild horses' that compete for forage are collected and either sold or shot.
events.source: #Ingram Laura V. Oral History Interview of Laura "Dusty" Vail Ingram by Laura Souliere Harrison. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; Feb. 28, 1993:29

events.title: Pima County land purchases contribute to protection of Cienega watershed
events.description: Between 2003 and 2006, Pima County acquires 5 private properties through purchase or land exchange totalling 2,141 acres in the Cienega watershed that contribute to the preservation of both underground and surface water flows, protect important endangered or threatened species and add critical components of the landscape linkages that enhance wildlife survival and movement through the region known as the Missing Link.The properties include Walden, McKenzie, Poteet, Amadon, and Nunez lands.

events.title: Range Conservation Program seeks to improve rangelands
events.description: Range Conservation Program is designed by the Soil Conservation Service to encourage deferred grazing by removing cattle from 25% of grasslands until grasses reach maturity. Program encourages development of erosion mitigation through water spreading, gully stopping, dam, well, and stock tank development, and improvements of grassland potential through spring development and the eradication of cactus, saltcedar, and mesquite. During the Great Depression this program provides important funds to ranchers struggling with cattle loss, range degradation, drought and the livestock market collapse. Today the National Resources Conservation Service works with individual ranchers to plan and manage their rangelands including erosion control and recovery from drought years. The Empire-Las Cienegas Coordinated Management Plan was completed by NRCS and its partners in 2012-2014.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:62

events.title: Certificate of water right to divert Cienega Creek at dam
events.description: Rancho del Lago is granted a certificate of water right to divert water from the Pantano dam (constructed in 1910) principally for the purpose of irrigating agricultural crops. In 1936 water is transported through a ditch to the ranch.

events.title: Land and Water Conservation Funds to acquire and protect land and water
events.description: Federal fund established in 1965 to provide moneys and matching grants to federal agencies and state and local governments to acquire and protect important lands and waters in order to achieve cultural, natural, wildlife, and recreational management objectives. Congressional funding has declined significantly since its start.

events.title: Earliest Cienega Creek baseline streamflow measurements
events.description: Leonard Halpenny, Arizona hydrologist with the US Geological Society, makes base flow measurements, the earliest on lower Cienega Creek, over concern for declining surface waters.
events.source: #Fonseca J. Shared History of Cienega Watershed Part 2. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve Expansion
events.description: Recognizing the extraordinary importance of Cienega Creek and its watershed, the Pima County Board of Supervisors first establishes the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve in 1986 using voter-approved bond funds for flood-prone land. Spanning 4,000 acres, the Preserve protects 12 miles of the lower reaches of Cienega Creek, which supports native endangered fish species, provides aquifer recharge, and provides important natural flood control protections that lessen impacts to the developed areas in the Tucson Basin. The Preserve also hosts the historic railroad town of Pantano, along with many archaeological features, including bedrock mortars.

events.title: Cloud seeding attempted
events.description: An attempt at cloud seeding is initiated by local ranchers; the program runs from June 15-September 30. A.C. Barnes of the Precipitation Control Company is hired to do the job, but produces inconclusive results.
events.source: #Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:39

events.title: Pronghorn antelope disappear
events.description: Pronghorn antelope are extirpated (eliminated) from the Cienega Valley and Sonoita Plain in the 1950s.
events.source: #Hoffmeister DF. Mammals of Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1986

events.title: Whetstone Fire
events.description: The Whetstone Fire is 612.82 acres (2.48 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: National Wild and Scenic Rivers Act sets designation process
events.description: Wild and scenic designation protects the free-flowing nature of rivers in non-federal areas, something the Wilderness Act and other federal designations cannot do. Designation does not alter property rights. 8 rivers protected at enactment; 203 as of 2011. 2 segments of Cienega Creek were proposed to Congress; however, Sen. John McCain blocked designation of waters in Arizona.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003:I-5

events.title: Forest and Range Renewable Resources Planning Act requires assessments
events.description: The Forest and Range Renewable Resources Planning Act (RPA) requires the US Forest Service to conduct assessments on all renewable resources in forests and on rangelands, to include timber, grass, wildlife and fish, biodiversity, water, outdoor recreation, wilderness, urban forests, and effects of climate change on all resources.

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad is completed through Arizona opening and closing markets
events.description: Completion of SPRR through Arizona opens new national markets to SE AZ ranchers, new shipping opportunities for miners. Cienega Valley ranchers bring cattle to the Pantano Station. Although local stage lines remain in operation, some into the 1930s,this eliminates most interstate lines, including National Mail and Transportation Company. Stagecoach stations, including Mountain Springs on La Posta Quemada Ranch, are no longer needed.
events.source:
#Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:19-61
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:44
#Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Release of Black tailed Prairie Dogs on the Research Ranch fails
events.description: Release of Black-tailed Prairie Dogs on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch fails. More info in the Research Ranch Annual Report August 31, 1972.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Vegetation changing on the Research Ranch
events.description: After three years without domestic livestock on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch (Elgin), vegetation begins to shift from short-grass to mid-grass prairie.
events.source: #Bonham C . Vegetation Shifts. Newsweek. September 24, 1973.

events.title: National System of Public Lands is set up for Bureau of Land Management lands
events.description: Omnibus Public Land Manager Act authorizes National Landscape Conservation System (NLCS) Secretary of Interior Dirk Kempthorne designates BLM Public Lands as a National System of Public Lands to characterize the interconnectedness of public lands and their multiple uses. Under the NLCS, Las Cienegas National Conservation Area is considered a special unit. NLCS develops policies, oversees land uses, and has budget functions at the national level.

events.title: Appleton Whittell Research Ranch incorporates as nonprofit
events.description: The Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch (of the National Audubon Society) incorporates as not-for-profit Arizona Corporation to manage the former Elgin Hereford Cattle Ranch (Appleton), Articles of Incorporation, Dock 106 Page 73, State of Arizona, Certificate of Incorporation #77060 issued 15 Sept 1969 by Milton Husky, Chairman, ACC. The Appleton Research Ranch is created, cattle removed, native grasses improve.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Drought leads to grassland degradation in southeastern Arizona
events.description: The severe drought of 1891-1893 continues the ecological decline of the grasslands in southeastern Arizona into the 20th century. Overgrazing by excessive numbers of cattle removes protective grasses throughout valleys and along the streambanks. Over the 28 months of the drought, tens of thousands of cattle die from thirst and starvation. The result of holding too many animals for too long under severe drought conditions is the permanent loss of topsoil and important grass species, and the lowering of the water table. The ecological destruction and financial losses drive some but not all ranchers to change their breeding and shipping patterns and management of grass and water in order to reduce the potential for future drought disasters. At Empire Ranch, most animals are removed to other states. By the end of drought in July 1893, only 2000 animals left on Empire ranges.
events.source:
#Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20
#Thornber J. J.. The Grazing Ranges of Arizona . College of Agriculture, University of Arizona (Tucson, AZ); Sep. 21,1910

events.title: Anamax acquires Empire, Cienega, and VR Ranches
events.description: Anamax purchases the Empire Ranch from Gulf American Corporation in 1974. In 1977 Anamax acquires Ed Vail's VR Ranch in Rosemont Valley and the Cienega Ranch from Sam Bell. Anamax is interested in the Empire and Cienega Ranches for their water rights and water supplies and the VR for potential copper resources and as a site for a tailings pile.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Flood of 1983 revives continuous flow in areas of Cienega Creek
events.description: Flood recharges Cienega Creek groundwaters and causes cottonwood recruitment; Hannas living on the Reserve can't cross the creek for 6 weeks. Flood creates areas that flow for several years after. Based on this observation, a residential development plan for 12,000 units is deemed not to need surface water rights.

events.title: Coronado National Forest releases Final Environmental Impact Statement for Rosemont Copper Mine
events.description: The Final Environmental Impact Statement release by Jim Upchurch, Coronado National Forest ( CNF) Supervisor, for the Rosemont Copper Project. The EIS is finalized in November 2013 and available to the public on December 13, 2013. CNF issues draft Record of Decision (ROD) for the Proposed Mine Plan of Operations and Finding of No Significant Impact (FONSI) for the land use plan amendment. CNF selects Alternative 4 – Barrel Alternative described in the Final Environmental Impact Statement (FEIS). Following publication of the FEIS and draft ROD , in January 2014, CNF initiates a formal objection process receiving 101 eligible objections. After review, the Regional provides direction to the CNF Forest Supervisor to republish Appendix G to include all Public Concern Statements and responses and scanned copies of actual letters received by Federal, State, and local agencies and elected officials.
events.source: #Final Environmental Impact Statement for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; Dec 2013

events.title: Coronado National Forest issues decision approving Rosemont Mine Plan of Operations
events.description: Coronado National Forest (CNF) issues Final Record of Decision (ROD) for the Rosemont Copper Project Mine Plan of Operations. The Final ROD documents the decision of Kerwin Dewberry (Forest Supervisor), along with the rationale for the decision and alternatives considered. The Final ROD includes a discussion of preferences among alternatives based on relevant factors and how those factors were considered in reaching the decision, as well as mitigation and monitoring measures that are required. The Final ROD documents changes and additions to the Mine Plan of Operations (MPO) deemed necessary by CNF. The Final ROD includes a decision to amend the 1986 Coronado National Forest Land and Resource Management Plan which would create a new forest management area (MA) for which specific standards and guidelines would be established relative to a large-scale mining operation. The copper mine cannot yet, however, begin until the Hudbay Company submits the final MPO with the ROD requirements incorporated, files an acceptable financial assurance bond, and provides proof of the Clean Water Act Section 404 certification.
events.source: #Final Record of Decision for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Forest Service, Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; Dec 2013

events.title: Colossal Cave Mountain Park listed on National Register of Historic Places
events.description: Nomination submitted by Linda Mayro, County Archaeologist, and is due to the existence of Civilian Conservation Corps structures, ancient Hohokam sites, and other historic treasures in the Park.

events.title: First well at Vail Arizona original town site
events.description: The first well between the tracks hits water at 614 feet.

events.title: Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership forms taking active role in Cienega Watershed
events.description: Volunteer collaborative planning organization: initiated with federal, state, and local agencies, organizations, and private citizens, the Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership continues meeting for years. Initially starts to complete the Resource Management Plan for the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area managed by the Bureau of Land Management. Issues represented: conservation, grazing, recreation, mining, and biological concerns. SVPP develops the vision, goals, and resource objectives for the Upper Cienega Creek basin and small portions of the Upper Babocomari and Sonoita Creek basins. Last meets in August 2014. The SVPP meets hundreds of times in forums and committee meetings to deal with major issues. Subgroups : grazing and wildlife habitat, water, mining, recreation and sustainable uses. SVPP develops the annual meeting, Science on the Sonoita Plain, to continue study and informational sharing in 2009.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: Pima Association of Governments starts Cienega Creek wet and dry mapping
events.description: PAG (Pima Association of Governments) starts quarterly wet/dry mapping; also does monthly mapping (detailed dataset); water quality monitoring and delineation of shallow groundwater areas; and intermittent/perennial streams (as part of Sonoran desert Conservation Plan). Severe drought begins in 1999 and headcut erosion begins at Horseshoe Wetlands

events.title: Adaptive Reuse Plan for the Empire Ranch Headquarters published
events.description: A written Adaptive Reuse (AR) Plan for the historic Empire Ranch House provides a wealth of information about the history of the ranch and the region, summarizes ideas and guidelines for how rooms and areas might function in the future, and implements very important planning decisions made for restoration and interpretation of the ranch house, headquarters, and the surrounding Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. By 2018 most of the recommendations concerning the stabilization and restoration of the Empire Ranch House have been implemented.
events.source: #Adaptive-Reuse Plan for the Empire Ranch Headquarters. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2004. Technical Report 03-64
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Guevavi mission and Tubac presidio abandoned because of Apache raiding
events.description: Devastating attacks by Apaches begin in 1768 on settlements in Santa Cruz, Sonoita Valleys. Visita at Sonoita abandoned in 1770. Guevavi deserted in 1774 and Tubac in 1775. All flee to last presidio at Tucson.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:53

events.title: Intense drought damages grasslands producing heavy cattle losses
events.description: Brief but intense drought, first since Anglo-American arrival. Annual rainfall less than 50% of average in 1885. Also below normal in 1886. Heavy loss of cattle as overstocking of range leads to grass destruction. Few recognize long-term threat to now over-extended industry.
events.source:
#Bahre CJ, Shelton ML . Rangeland Destruction: Cattle and Drought in Southeastern Arizona at the Turn of the Century. Journal of the Southwest. 1996. 38(1):1-22
#Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:45

events.title: Spanish establish Tucson Presidio
events.description: In deciding on the most effective locations for the northern Spanish defensive forts, Hugo O'Conor chooses to situate the northernmost in Tucson on August 20, 1775. The defensive fortifications of the presidio are not completed until December 1783.
events.source:
#Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:53
#Officer J . Hispanic Arizona: 1536-1856. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1989: 50, 58

events.title: Coronado National Forest established
events.description: The Coronado National Forest is established in 1908 from combination of several local Forests in Southeast Arizona and Southwest New Mexico in order to centralize and coordinate management.

events.title: Canelo Wildfire burns Westgate Community and areas of the Research Ranch
events.description: The Canelo Wildfire burns in the Westgate Community and about 2,500 acres of the Audubon-Whittell Research Ranch. The fire, which starts on private land southwest of the Research Ranch, burns swiftly to the east, causing much damage to some homes in the Westgate Community. The fire moves northward much more slowly. The Research Ranch is part of the Audubon‐Babacomari FireWise Community. The FireWise preparations to create defensible space around buildings are noted and appreciated by the firefighting personnel. Members of the Sonoita‐Elgin Fire Department are on site for the duration of the fire as are firefighters from many other agencies. The preceding dry winter hasn’t produced much ground moisture and the plants are stressed, so the incident commander to try to halt the northern spread of this fire by lighting backfires, using roads within the Research Ranch as ignition lines.
events.source: #Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch . Annual Reports of the National Audubon Society Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, 2007-2017. . Elgin, Arizona: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch ; 2008. #Bock CE, Bock JH. Response of Birds to Wildfire in Native Versus Exotic Arizona Grassland. Southwestern Naturalist . 1992. 37:73-81

events.title: Wheeler Military Survey in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico and Arizona
events.description: Officially titled the United States Geographical Surveys West of the One-Hundredth Meridian the project is placed in charge of First Lieutenant George M. Wheeler of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.
events.source: #Brown DE. Arizona Wildlife. The Territorial Years 1863-1912. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Game and Fish Department; 2009:3

events.title: Greaterville fire
events.description: The Greatervillle Fire is caused by a Rosemont Copper Company employee welding a broken well bracket near Rosemont Ranch. The fire spreads into Box Canyon and burns 2,200 acres (8.903 sq. km.) altogether. A smoke advisory is issued for Pima, Cochise, and Santa Cruz Counties due to the combined smoke from the Greaterville Fire and the Bull Fire, which is burning on both sides of the International border near Nogales.
events.source: #REF!

events.title: Turkey releases on Cienega Creek
events.description: Arizona Game and Fish Department (AZG&F) releases Gould's turkey on Cienega Creek, transplanting 14 turkey including 4 gobblers (1 tom, 3 jakes) and 10 hens from O'Donnell Canyon to Las Cienegas in 2012. AZG&F records list: Feb. 6 (5 birds), Feb 7 (7 birds), and Feb 16 (2 birds).
events.source: #Tucker R. Arizona Game & Fish Department Records on Wild Turkey Transplants and Sightings. Personal Communication .2020.

events.title: Beavers reintroduced into San Pedro River
events.description: After much deliberation, public input, and completion of an environmental assessment, beavers (Castor canadensis) are reintroduced into the San Pedro River by the Bureau of Land Management and Arizona Game and Fish. Historically, these have been trapped and eventully ellminated in the system. The re-introduction is considered an ecological success story for the riparian corridor and supported species. But since 2016, no new beaver dams have appeared; the beavers may have disappeared again.
events.source: #Notes: Biological Planning Meeting. Spring 2018 Biological Planning,Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Tucson, AZ: Bureau of Land Management ; Mar. 30, 2018.

events.title: No significant Paleoindian sites in Cienega
events.description: Humans follow big game (megafauna, mammoth, bison, antelope), smaller animals, and gather plants. No Paleo-Indian sites recorded yet but finding these sites may be difficult due to: 1) sites may be deeply buried and occasionally exposed by erosion into old deposits; 2) the material remains are scant and do not include ceramics, house structures, or other features; 3) due to the mobile patterns; 4) material culture was perishable; and 5) sites are ephemeral in nature and the overall site density would have been low given the hunting and gathering patterns. Sites potentially exist based on late mammoth finds that are known for the creek.
events.source:
#Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2
#Huckell BB. Of Marshes and Maize--Preceramic Agricultural Settlements in the Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers Number 59; 1995

events.title: Archaic human settlements and activities become highly adaptive
events.description: The Archaic prehistoric period is marked by patterns of hunting and intensive plant collecting with seasonal mobile camps. This pattern continues for thousands of years. Many sites exist in the Cienega Valley attesting to this successful adaptation to changing environments. In the last phases of the Archaic, domestic plant growing is added to the Cienega Archaic adaptations.
events.source:
#Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001. #Stevens MN. Archaic and Early Agricultural Land Use in the Cienega Valley. . Archaeology Southwest . 2001. 15(4):3-5
#Mabry, JB, Stevens MN. Beyond the Cochise Culture: New Views of Archaic Foragers and Early Farmers in Southeastern Arizona.. Wallace HD ed. Between Mimbres and Hohokam: Exploring the Archaeology and History of Southeastern Arizona and Southwestern New Mexico, Anthropological Papers No. 52. . Tucson, AZ: Archaeology Southwest ; 2014. p.111-164

events.title: George Crook commands Army forces in Arizona Territory
events.description: In 1872 Colonel George Crook defeats Northern Apaches, who agree to reside on reservation. O.O. Howard persuades Cochise to inhabit Chiricahua reservation in Sulphur Springs Valley. By end of 1872 southern Arizona Territory is relatively peaceful and continues so until 1875 when Crook is reassigned to the Northern Plains to subdue the Sioux Indians. This era of peace defines the arrival of many ranchers, the onset of the cattle industry, and the rush for previously unused grasslands.
events.source: #Sweeney E. From Cochise to Geronimo: The Chiricahua Apaches 1874-1886.. Norman OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2010

events.title: First surveys of fishes in Southern Arizona
events.description: First surveys for fishes are associated with boundary surveys.
events.source:
#Minckley, WL, Marsh PC. Inland Fishes of the Greater Southwest, Chronicle of a Vanishing Biota. Tucson, AZ:The University of Arizona Press; 2009
#Girard C. Ichthyology of the Boundary. Washington DC: US Government Printing Office;\; 1859

events.title: Santa Cruz County established
events.description: Santa Cruz County created out of parts of Pima County.

events.title: Interstate stage lines operate across Southern Arizona
events.description: Numerous stage lines carry mail and passengers through southern Arizona. The San Antonio-San Diego Mail Line (also known as the Jackass Mail) operates in early 1857, and the Butterfield Stage Company from 1857 to early 1861 when Confederate separatists in Texas damage company resources. Butterfield builds a relay station in lower Cienega Creek (near present-day Marsh Station).Three other stage lines restart transport in 1870 but close for good in 1881 when Southern Pacific RR completes its line across AZ. Many other stage lines continue to operate within AZ. One line runs from Pantano to Patagonia through the upper Cienega Valley.

events.title: Theodore White surveys 7 townships around Cienega Valley
events.description: Surveyor Theodore White is contracted by the General Land Office in Tucson to survey seven 6-mile by 6-mile townships in the Cienega valley. White records descriptions of natural resources, landmarks, human habitations, roads, and locations and distances between. Using descriptions and precise measurements, he draws first detailed map of each township. These maps are published in the General Land Office and used later by homesteaders and miners to make individual claims. No claims can be filed until a formal survey has been made. With these surveys of the watershed, settlement of the valley by ranchers and farmers accelerates.
events.source: #Gillespie W. . Personal Communication.April 18, 2017.

events.title: Great Depression
events.description: The Great Depression spans the late 1920s to the early 1940s. Factors include world-wide economic collapse, the US stock market crash and nationwide drought, bank closures, agricultural failures. Recovery only achieved with the US entry into World War II.
events.source: #Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Largest known earthquake in Arizona
events.description: May 3, 1887: the largest known earthquake in Arizona, estimated seismic level on Richter Scale between 7.2 and 7.4. It is centered in Batopito, Sonora, Mexico. Just a few miles away in Bavispe, Sonora, adobe buildings are in ruins, and 40 people are killed. In Arizona, it breaks up playas and forms the Mustang Mountains skyline later used in Red River film. The earthquake changes underground water flows and creates many springs. It initiates major fires in all Southeast Arizona mountain ranges from falling rocks. Chimneys at the Empire Ranch collapse. It is reported from Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, to Phoenix, and from Yuma to Santa Fe, New Mexico. May 30, 1887: Tombstone reports significant aftershock. Other significant aftershocks occur August 27, 1887, and November 11, 1887, which is the second aftershock in two weeks, and cracks wooden depot buildings in Pantano.
events.source: #McGarvin, TA. The 1887 Sonoran Earthquake: It Wasn't Our Fault . Arizona Bureau of Geology and Mineral Technology Field Notes. Summer 1987. Vol 17, No 2

events.title: Franklin Delano Roosevelt creates Civilian Conservation Corps
events.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) is established by President Franklin Delano Roosevelt during the Great Depression of the 1930s. The purpose of the Corps is twofold: to provide jobs for unemployed young men, and to preserve and develop the nation’s natural resources by assisting the Departments of Agriculture and Interior with forest, park, and soil conservation projects. 'CCC boys' as they are called, are unmarried men between the ages of 17 and 24. In general, they earn $30.00 per month, of which $25.00 goes home to their families. The CCC camps are overseen by U.S. Army personnel, while the work is supervised by other agencies.
events.source:
#Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000
#Hunt SE, Lamb JJ, Maierhauser M. Civilian Conservation Corps Scrapbook: Camp SP-10-A Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Tucson, AZ: Colossal Cave Mountain Park; 2012

events.title: Tunnel excavated into Colossal Cave
events.description: Otto Schley, businessman and Vail Postmaster, drives a 75-ft tunnel into Colossal Cave in order to mine bat guano, takes out seven train carloads before the resource is exhausted. Tunnel serves today as ingress and egress for the various bat species using Colossal Cave.

events.title: Voices of Vail Oral History project begins
events.description: Vail Preservation Society begins 'Voices of Vail' oral history project. As of 2022, the Society has recorded over 60 oral histories. "Voices" expresses the stories of over 100 year of people in the area.

events.title: Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 covers public lands leasing
events.description: Mineral Leasing Act of 1920 30 U.S.C. § 181 et seq. authorizes and governs leasing of public lands for developing deposits of coal, petroleum, natural gas, and other hydrocarbons, in addition to phosphates, sodium, sulfur, and potassium on public lands in the US. Previous to the act, these materials were subject to mining claims under the General Mining Act of 1872. Act requires that royalties be collected to provide funds for states, the US treasury and a Reclamation Fund.

events.title: 1908 Vail Store and Post Office listed on the National Register
events.description: Nomination submitted by J.J. Lamb, Vail Preservation Society; an icon to Vail residents since 1908. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

events.title: Shrine of Santa Rita in the Desert is listed on the National Register
events.description: Proposed by J.J. Lamb, Director of the Vail Preservation Society, the Shrine becomes listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

events.title: After Mexican Independence Apache raiding increases causing abandonment
events.description: After 11 years of conflict against Spanish rule, Mexico wins independence. The loss of financial support from Spain leaves the Apache Peace Program and many military presidios unfunded. Apaches return to earlier raiding patterns. Within 10 years, Spanish and Mexican land grants are abandoned, including the San Ignacio del Babocomari, San Rafael de la Zanja, and San Jose de Sonoita. Most livestock are left behind.

events.title: Mexican American War
events.description: The Mexican-American War, also known as the Mexican War, the US–Mexico War, the Invasion of Mexico, the U.S. Intervention, or the United States War Against Mexico, is an armed conflict between the United States of America and the United Mexican States from 1846 to 1848, in the wake of the 1845 U.S. annexation of Texas,. Mexico considers Texas part of its territory despite the 1836 Texas Revolution.

events.title: Empire Ranch House rear addition rooms constructed
events.description: Eleven rooms are added to the original four-room Empire Ranch house to provide space for offices and staff.
events.source: #The Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2015

events.title: Mesquite encroaches from washes into grasslands accelerates
events.description: At the beginning of the 1900s, mesquite is largely confined to large washes above 1000m, though early botanists note small plants within grasslands. Since 1930 mesquite cover and density rapidly increase. This loss of available grass for grazing leads to many different efforts by ranchers to physically remove or chemically poison individual mesquite plants.
events.source: #McClaren M. A Century of Vegetation Change on the Santa Rita Experimental Range. Santa Rita Experimental Range: 100 Years (1903 to 2003) of Accomplishments and Contributions. Conference Proceedings. USDA Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station. RMRS-P-30.; Oct 30-Nov 1, 2003.

events.title: General Land Office surveys public domain south of Babocomari Land Grant
events.description: General Land Office completes land survey of public lands South of San Ignacio del Babocomari Land Grant in Cochise County. Survey delineates boundaries of townships and sections so that homestead claims can be filed and State Land Trust Department can select lands to lease. In Township 21 South Range 18 E, most of township is part of original Spanish land grant. Remaining is open to claims. Until 1908, land was part of Huachuca Forest Reserve but returned to the public domain. Lands later become part of Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: National Environmental Policy Act requires agencies to consider impacts
events.description: National Environmental Policy Act requires federal agencies to prepare environmental assessments or environmental impact statements that explore the potential impacts of any actions on the environment. Enforcement occurs through the court system. Decisions are open to public review and comment. This law allows citizens to challenge the adequacy of review and assessment of planned actions proposed by federal agencies or any other agency that receives federal funding.

events.title: Pantano becomes major cattle shipping point
events.description: Southern Pacific Railroad reaches Pantano. Pantano Station becomes the primary cattle-shipping point for the Empire Ranch.and others.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Edward L Vail becomes an Empire Ranch partner
events.description: Edward (Ned) L. Vail, Walter Vail's brother, becomes a partner in the Empire Ranch.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: A deep long-lasting drought decade
events.description: Deep long-lasting drought which was wide-spread in the West. Grassland disappear, reservoirs dry up. In the Altar Valley, Dunklee descibes how ranchers reduce herds, use supplemental feeding trying to wait for the wet years. Arizona was declared a drought disaster.
events.source:
#Duncklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38
#Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:22

events.title: Extended drought conditions damages topsoil
events.description: Even though herds are reduced, drought combined with heavy grazing causes loss of much topsoil in Southern Arizona.
events.source:
#Duncklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38
#Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:22

events.title: Lower Cienega Creek has no cottonwood gallery
events.description: Aerial photos of the Lower Cienega Creek show no cottonwood forest as exists today. The creekbed exhibits active erosion and mesquite encroachment into the sacaton zone.
events.source: #Fonseca J.. Cienega Watershed Shared History Part Three. Personal Communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Children's Addition added to Empire Ranch
events.description: A wooden frame building is added to the family house (Victorian and Rear Additions) to accommodate Walter and Margaret Vail's growing family.
events.source: #Harrison LS. Heart of the Empire. Washington, DC: National Park Service; 1992

events.title: Gila topminnow first listed as Endangered
events.description: Gila topminnow first listed as Endangered on the Federal Endangered Species list. The Cienega Creek, with its well-watered pools is a primary location for populations of this fish. Recent drought and changes in creek bed structures have reduced those populations significantly. In 2019 due to conservation activities, the Arizona Game and Fish Department petitions the US Fish & Wildlife Service to move the species to 'Threatened'.
events.source: #Arizona Game and Fish Department. AZGFD moves to downlist endangered Gila topminnow to threatened. Arizona Game and Fish Department Website Enews. Sept.16, 2019.
events.tags: ESA Status, Species, Loss of Habitat, Native

events.title: State Trust Lands classified for grazing values
events.description: Works Project Administration (WPA project # 274) is assigned to classify all AZ State Trust lands. The project includes a physical examination of the state grazing lands 1) to determine leasing values, 2) to draft a topographical map for each township to show different land ownership, and 3) to estimate the carrying capacity, rainfall amounts and soil conditions.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:73

events.title: Safe Drinking Water Act to protect water quality
events.description: The Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) is established to protect the quality of drinking water in the U.S. This law focuses on all waters actually or potentially designated for drinking use, whether from above ground or underground sources.

events.title: Dr Jay Schnell becomes Research Ranch Director
events.description: Dr. Jay Schnell hired as Director of the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Empire Land and Cattle Company headquarters moves to Los Angeles
events.description: Walter Vail moves the headquarters of the Empire Land & Cattle Company and his family from the Empire Ranch to Los Angeles, CA. Empire Ranch left under the management of foreman Hadden McFadden.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Endangered Species Act to protect species from extinction
events.description: The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a 'consequence of economic growth and development untempered by adequate concern and conservation'. Endangered Species Act requires conservation of threatened and endangered plants, animals, ecosystems; the Act provides a framework for actions. The agency that implements ESA in the Cienega Watershed is the US Fish and Wildlife Service.
events.source: #United States. Endangered Species Act of 1973. 16 US Code 1531 et seq.. Washington, DC: Government Printing Office; 1973

events.title: Cattle removed from the Elgin Hereford Cattle Ranch
events.description: Frank and Ariel Appleton purchased the deeded land and grazing allotments of the Clark Ranch and the Swinging H Ranch (approximately 8,000 acres total) and created the Elgin Hereford Ranch (EHR). In 1968 the Appletons decide to go in another direction. They sell their cattle and converted the ranch into a research facility. The Appletons formed a non-profit Research Ranch Inc. The purpose is to evaluate large scale land uses, including but not limited to grazing by domestic livestock. Cattle were also removed from their state and federal forest leases.
events.source: #Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Cienega Creek streamflow monitoring begins due to the 1983 floods
events.description: Monitoring for streamflow has been an intensive effort especially post-1983 flood in which water flowed in Cienega Creek. Changes in the water flow are reflected in the riparian zone and creek scouring. The Hannas (living on the Cienega Creek Preserve) report numerous cottonwood saplings due to scouring; there had been very few cottonwoods before the flood. Among the entities and agencies monitoring the flow are Pima Association of Governments (PAG), Pima County, Bureau of Land Management, and Montgomery & Associates. All continue monitoring and reporting. Technical reports can be found on the PAG website.

events.title: Federal land survey establishes San Ignacio del Babocomari Grant boundaries
events.description: The first federal land survey in the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the National Audubon Society area establishes boundaries of San Ignacio del Babocomari Grant.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Gulf America Corporation later Anamax drill wells in Cienega Valley
events.description: Gulf American Corp begins drilling wells throughout the Empire, testing for water availability. One of the first wells is at the west end of the air runway. Anamax Mining Co, following purchase of the Empire from GAC and Cienega Ranch from Sam Bell, continues to drill wells with the intent of using that water at its Rosemont mine. At least 88 are now in existence.
events.source: #Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: James Stetson acquires Kentucky Camp mining claims and water rights
events.description: Stetson acquires mining claims, water rights, and reservoirs for a large-scale hydraulic gold mining operation, based on similar operations in California gold mines. Stetson, a mining engineer, pioneers hydraulic mining techniques that involve piping water over distances and using valves to boost water output for a water cannon. George McAneny and James Stetson form the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company on October 3rd. The Headquarters includes a large building (headquarters), two cabins, a barn, and an assay building. Miners live in tents.
events.source: #Orell FL. Kentucky Camp and the Santa Rita Water and Mining Company. Kentucky Camp Chronicle [Newsletter]. 1998. February

events.title: Memorandum of Understanding between US Forest Service and National Audubon Society
events.description: Memorandum of Understanding signed, 'to cooperate in studies to encourage research on factors related to maintaining and improving management of Southwestern desert grasslands and to maintain the established Elgin Natural Research Area.' MOU dated June 14, July 28, & July 13, 1982; Dr. Mark Stromberg is Resident Director of the Research Ranch.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Cattle overgrazing prompts management on early S Arizona Forests
events.description: Range management on southern Arizona forests (later the Coronado National Forest) begins with controlling the number of ranchers who access forest grasslands, and then on reducing the stocking rates. Range managers institute a policy of 'transfer reductions', requiring a 10% reduction in permitted numbers of livestock each time a permit is transferred to a new permittee. Despite its good intentions, the policy is not effective in reducing overgrazing; the resulting damage on the range is due to the lack of control over cattle movement on and off the allotments, to unpermitted cattle trespass, to the lack of accurate data on the actual number of livestock on the range, and a lack of understanding of the real carrying capacity of the grasslands, i.e. the remaining amount of grass after grazing needed to support the next season's growth.
events.source: #Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20

events.title: Walter Vail, founder of the Empire Ranch, dies
events.description: Walter Vail killed in a streetcar accident in Los Angeles. Management of the Empire Ranch continues under the direction of Carroll W. Gates and Vail family members.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978

events.title: Learn and Serve Youth Program preserves Empire Ranch features
events.description: A Learn and Serve program recruits youth and trains them to preserve 70 windows and doors, other features at the Empire Ranch House. The Empire Ranch Foundation obtains a grant to fund the program.

events.title: Sanford Family Land Acquisition in Cienega Valley
events.description: Don Alonzo Sanford settles at the confluence of Wood, Stevenson, and Cienega Creeks in 1874 in Township 18 South Range 17 East, Section 23. Sanford’s brother, Franklin, claims land two miles south in the area now known as the Ag Fields. Sanford brings his fiancé, Louisa Bloxton, and her brothers, John and Robert, to join his Cienega settlement later in the same year. All homestead or purchase lands along the Creek and claim water rights. Their claims provide the family with some of the richest grazing and tillable lands within Cienega Valley. Their family control of land and water in the middle Cienega Valley area essentially excludes any competing ranching enterprise.Sanford sells all of the family lands in the upper Cienega to Walter Vail in 1882. Don takes over brother Denton Sanford's ranch in Patagonia following his brother's death.

events.title: Agriculture development and water distribution at Empire Ranch
events.description: Walter Vail acquires the Sanford Ranch in 1882. Like Don Sanford, the Vails use the extensive floodplain for agricultural production; they plow a number of individual fields, each of which probably supports different crops. In 1892 Walter Vail expands agricultural endeavors to the riparian area near the Empire Ranch. Vail files a Desert Land claim on bottom lands 1/2 mile east of the corrals and around Empire Gulch. He conveys water during spring and summer months in a ¾-mile-long ditch with numerous laterals to a broad flat area on the northeast and southwest sides of the Gulch. That irrigation system supports 250 fruit trees and five tons of corn, barley, and alfalfa annually. It also provides stock waters for the horse and newly-weaned calf herds.

events.title: Patagonia adopts new adequate water supply rule
events.description: Because of declining ground and surface water supplies, new developments in Patagonia AZ must prove access to 100-year water supply.

events.title: Donaldsons change grazing management at Empire Ranch
events.description: John Donaldson, cattle grazing permit holder on the Las Cienegas, changes his range management and breeding practices. Donaldson, with his son Mac, introduces Brahman-Hereford crosses to range and increases number of fenced pastures to apply better pasture rotation, especially after 1988. Under BLM direction, Donaldson fenced cattle out of the creek and riparian wash areas. These best practices, have helped uplands and damaged riparian areas along the Creek at Las Cienegas begin to recover.
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016. #John Donaldson. Oral History Interview with John Donaldson by Jake Kittle. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; Apr. 11. 1998

events.title: Black tailed prairie dog reintroduction
events.description: Missing from the Watershed since the 1950s, the Black-tailed prairie dog (Cynomys ludovicianus) is a species of special concern in Arizona: According to the Arizona Game and Fish Department (AGFD), their research indicates that prairie dogs are a keystone species: they provide a special service in the grassland by turning over and loosening the soil as they burrow, allowing water to penetrate, thus promoting nutrients. In addition, other species benefit from the plant richness and shelter that burrows offer. The Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision prescribes reintroduction of the black-tailed prairie dog. In 2008 AGFD begins establishing colonies at Las Cienegas; in 2015 this expands to three colonies, and in 2017, prairie dogs are released at the Sands Ranch.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012. #Walton E. Black-tailed Prairie Dogs released near Sonoita. KOLD. Oct.13, 2017.

events.title: Sacaton mapping and condition assessment on Las Cienegas
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management Tucson and The Nature Conservancy develop a mapping project. The focus is to map the sacaton plant community in the bottom lands to assist with management decisions.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Endangered Desert Pupfish released at Appleton Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Endangered Desert Pupfish released at HQ pond on the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch during Science on Sonoita Plain Symposium. Pond serves as a refuge population.
events.source: #Third Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain. Quarterly Meeting of the Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership . Sonoita, AZ: Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership ; Jun 4, 2011

events.title: Empire Ranch Foundation receives Arizona Governor’s Heritage Preservation Honor Award
events.description: Arizona Governor’s Heritage Preservation Honor Award presented to organizations that push preservation efforts forward. Nomination acknowledges work, funding, and archive efforts for the Empire Ranch Foundation..
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Management agreement between Swift Current Land and Cattle Co. and National Audubon Society
events.description: 2007 Management agreement signed between Swift Current Land and Cattle Co. (Resolution Copper Company), and National Audubon Society; covers lands purchased from Appleton heirs.

events.title: Project YES! Youth Engaged Stewardship offers leadership and restoration projects
events.description: Begining in 2011, the YES! program offers summer sessions to enhance youth leadership through restoration projects. In 2012 a pilot with six students initiates field work. In 2013 youth and adult mentors transplant 48 Huachuca Water Umble and 150 sedge plugs into two ponds at Las Cienegas Cieneguita. In 2014 through 2018, YES works at the Gardner Sacaton site, Cottonwood Tank, Cieneguita, Bill's Pond, Hummel and Grove Houses, and more projects to restore aspects of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Funded by the Bureau of Land Management, National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, Cienega Watershed Partnership, and donations. YES! is a youth leadership and restoration program for teens in the Tucson Basin. Their summer work is augmented by the Empire High School Advanced Desert Ecology classes and by volunteer events. A video The New Keepers is available from Arizona Illustrated. The 2012 pilot started with Arizona Game & Fish funding and four partners -- Cienega Watershed Partnership, Empire High School, Ironwood Tree Experience (Prescott College), and Tucson Bureau of Land Management.

events.title: Red River filmed at the Empire Ranch
events.description: The movie Red River, starring John Wayne, is filmed at the Empire Ranch and other local locations.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011:46

events.title: Cienega Valley supports 5,000 cattle and 23,000 sheep
events.description: Empire (Vails) and Meadows Valley (Sanford) Ranches, the two largest stock raising operations in the Cienega Valley, graze over 5,000 cattle and 23,000 sheep. A number of other smaller ranches and homesteads in the valley are also running cattle and sheep.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:41

events.title: Sonoita and Babocomari plains thick with Sacaton and Saltgrass
events.description: The Sonoita area and the Babocomari Land Grant are thick with Sacaton and Saltgrass.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:42

events.title: Severe flash flooding on Cienega Creek
events.description: A wall of water produced by flash flooding in Upper Cienega Creek drowns 100 head of the Vail's cattle on overcrowded range. Vail begins to move cattle off overcrowded Cienega range to California; causes the Pantano Hotel to flood. The Valley of Cienega according to newspaper article is half full at 15 ft depth from cloudburst in the Santa Rita Mountains. Flash flooding mainly July 1 and July 2.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:76

events.title: Dry conditions; heavy summer rains at Empire
events.description: Generally dry conditions at Empire Ranch. But heavy summer rains keep range grasses in good condition. By extension, if the Empire Ranch suffered drought, then had summer rains, most of the Cienega Watershed is likely to have similar pattern.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:120

events.title: Boice family lease to manage the Empire Ranch discontinued
events.description: Boice family lease to manage the Empire Ranch discontinued by Anamax and the remaining Boice cattle are sold.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Mrs Wood describes major snowstorm and drought
events.description: Jane Woods' mother, a teacher in the area, writes diary entries about her experience during one snowstorm: so deep that her horse has to be led by other horses to reach her home. This is a drought time when cattle have to be driven into Mexico for food. Jane reveals this story March 17, 2012, at the Elgin Club during a 'Back Then' potluck.
events.source: #Woods J. Diary entries of my mom. Personal communication.Mar. 17, 2012. #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:57

events.title: Colossal Cave Mountain Park created by Pima County
events.description: In 1989, using 1986 voter-approved bond funds earmarked for parkland acquisition, Pima County Board of Supervisors purchases the 495-acre Colossal Cave Park from the Arizona State Land Department. Till now, Pima County has been leasing the property. At the same time, they purchase the adjoining historic La Posta Ranch, also the site of a stagecoach station dating to the mid-1870s, and additional acreage. This combines Colossal Cave Park and La Posta Quemada Ranch and formally establishes Colossal Cave Mountain Park (CCMP), now about 2,400 acres. The non-profit Pima County Parklands Foundation takes over La Posta Quemada Ranch’s State grazing leases,to use the 5,714 acres to protect the boundaries of the new mountain park. Pima County Parklands Foundation also takes over administration of CCMP, and Joe and Martie Maierhauser continue as Park operators for the Foundation. CCMP supports habitat for almost half of the bat species in the State of Arizona, including the endangered Lesser Long-nosed Bat. CCMP also protects large segments of lush riparian vegetation along Posta Quemada Wash and Agua Verde Creek, a major tributary to Cienega Creek.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Bureau of Land Management initiates surveys for Empire Cienega Conservation Area
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management acquires the Empire, Cienega and Rose Tree Ranches and manages these as the Empire-Cienega Conservation Area (prior to the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area in 2000). BLM scientists commences baseline surveys for vegetation communities, birds, fish and riparian and other habitats. Survey data now available at the Tucson BLM Office. These surveys become important when BLM initiates a land use and resource management plan in 1995.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011:46
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Pima County expands important wildlife corridor
events.description:
Using both 1997 and 2004 voter-approved bond funds for open space acquisitions, Pima County purchases five properties. The significance in these acquisitions is the expansion of the link between Colossal Cave Mountain Park (CCMP) and Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. The properties are:
1 - Akers/Dailey Properties: in August 1999, the Board of Supervisors approves acquisition of the Akers/Dailey parcels totaling 158 acres for $1,122,720. The significance of the acquisitions is not only building a link towards the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve, but also the protection of natural floodplain functions, an Important Riparian Area and wildlife corridor.
2 – Bradley property: Also in August 1999, the Board of Supervisors approves acquisition of the 40-acre Bradley property for $266,036. This adds to the linkages towards the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve and protection of natural floodplain functions, an Important Riparian Area and wildlife corridor.
3 - Alpher Property: In January 2000, the County purchases the 147-acre Alpher property for $514,412. The property expands CCMP’s eastern boundary, protecting upstream water sources and habitat for the endangered Lesser long-nosed bat.
4 - Cates Property: In May 2006, the County purchases the 39-acre Cates property for $132,957. The parcel’s location south of CCMP and its proximity to the County’s Baker property, acquired for Cienega Creek Natural Preserve, makes it a strategic acquisition; it supports habitat for Lesser long-nosed bat and Mexican long-tongued bat.
5 - Knez Property: In August 2006, the County acquires the 80-acre Knez property for $240,967. This property connects to the Cates property to expand conserved lands adjacent to CCMP, and expands the connection between CCMP and the Cienega Creek Natural Prese

events.title: Pima County leases Colossal Cave Park from the State Land Department
events.description: Pima County leases the 495-acre Colossal Cave Park from the State Land Department and names Frank Schmidt Supervisor. He operates the Park, personally or through managers, until age 84 (1956). Pima County continues to lease the Park from the State Land Department till 1989, when they buy it.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Severe drought
events.description: 1943 initiates an extended dry period that continues for a decade and finally abates in 1953.
events.source: #Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38

events.title: Drought conditions
events.description: Occasional dry years during the 1940's caused seasonal droughts. Cattlemen could deal with these droughts but the ones that began in the 50s proved disastrous.
events.source: #Duncklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:38

events.title: Arizona drought disaster declared
events.description: Seasonal droughts are a regular occurring feature for Arizona rangelends but beginning in 1956 and lasting though 1959, a widespread drought affected Arizona. Cattle numbers were reduced and augmented feeding like cottonsided cakes were required.
events.source: #Conover A. Keepers of the range: The story of the Arizona Cattle Growers’ Association. Phoenix, AZ: Heritage Publishers; 2007:44

events.title: Kentucky Camp adds new wood shingle roofs to stabilize adobe
events.description: New wood shingle roofs are installed on all buildings to stabilize adobe from rain damage. Headquarters building wall rebuilt after years of rain run-off have destroyed it.
events.source: #Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle [Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: Wild Cow Fire
events.description: The Wild Cow Fire is 939 acres (3.8 sq, km.) in size.

events.title: Don Alonzo Sanford diversifies endeavors in Cienega Valley
events.description: Sanford invests in land, mining claims, built properties in Tucson, and livestock. He provides substantial quantities of beef and barley to nearby Forts Huachuca and Lowell and to the San Carlos Indian reservation. By 1880 Sanford is running 1,000 head of cattle and 23,000 sheep on lands that he controls between the Empire and the Whetstone Mountains as far north as the Pantano Valley. Sanford raises feed crops in the floodplain of the Cienega Creek and maintains an extensive orchard of fruit trees. Sanford apparently waters these agricultural lands from an irrigation system of his own construction. Sanford sells his Meadows Valley Ranch (also called the Stock Valley Ranch) to Walter Vail in November 1882.

events.title: Stabilization and repair of the Empire Ranch South Barn
events.description: The South Barn is replumbed and re-braced to correct leaning, and missing metal roofing is replaced. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source: #Empire Ranch House: South Barn Emergency Repairs Phases 1 and 2. Final Version. . . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2008. Technical Report 07-30
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Pima County acquires Bar V Ranch
events.description: Pima County acquires 170 acres of private land and 12,000 state trust leased lands using Conservation Bond funding. The property is bounded on the north by the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve and includes the lower watershed of the Davidson Canyon. Pima County's acquisition contributes to the conservation of one of the most important wildlife movement corridors in the Cienega Valley as identified in the Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. The Bar V Ranch is located between the Rincon and Santa Rita Mountains adjacent to the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. The ranch includes a significant portion of Davidson Canyon, an important tributary and water source to Cienega Creek and the Tucson Basin. Acquisition of the Bar V Ranch preserves a large intact piece of the Empire-Cienega landscape.

events.title: Las Cienegas National Conservation Area Technical Teams active
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management sets up Technical Teams for the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to implement the approved land use plan. The teams consist of manager, scientists, specialists, and stakeholders to provide technical guidance on issues. Four teams are set up and are still functioning: riparian, upland, landscape, heritage. A coordinating team liaisons between teams and sets up the semi-annual biological planning field sessions. These four teams provide a basic structure for other workshops as well such as the State of the Watershed, Health Assessment, and Climate Change Scenario Planning. Participation is voluntary and co-facilitators for each team set up meetings periodically. In continuous process 2009 through 2022.

events.title: Nicholson completes first thesis on the Research Ranch
events.description: R.A. Nicholson completes the first thesis produced on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch: Grama (Bouteloua Lag.) Communities in a Southern Arizona Grassland
events.source: #Nicholson RA . Grama (Bouteloua Lag.) Communities in a Southern Arizona Grassland (Thesis). ; 1972

events.title: Rescission Act of 1995 affects forest grazing
events.description: The Rescissions Act of 1995 requires each National Forest unit to identify all forest livestock grazing allotments for which National Environmental Policy Act analysis is needed. The analysis evaluates the components of the grazing permit and the conditions of the resources (Water, grass) in each allotment that support the grazing permit. These allotments must be included in a schedule that sets a due date for the completion of the requisite NEPA analysis.

events.title: Kelleys purchase land between the railroad tracks in Vail
events.description: Arthur and Mary Jane Kelley purchase the land between the railroad tracks in Vail including the Old Vail Post Office. The 1908 building is operated as Vail Feed Store until 1994.

events.title: Chiricahua Leopard Frog population failed at Finley Tank
events.description: On the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch, staff determines that the Chiricahua Leopard Frog has failed at the Finley Tank.
events.source: #Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000

events.title: Empire Ranch HQ water supply system replaced; public restrooms installed
events.description: Empire Ranch Headquarters water supply system replaced and public restrooms installed. Work completed and funded by Bureau of Land Management.
events.source: #Empire Ranch Foundation. Preservation Projects. Internet Resource.2007.
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Rosemont Environmental Impact Statement for Asarco Land Exchange Proposal
events.description: The Environmental Impact Statement is prepared by the University of Arizona for a proposed land exchange with National Forest lands and Asarco Mining Company.

events.title: Rosemont Mine submits preliminary Mine Plan of Operations to Coronado National Forest
events.description: In July 2007, Rosemont Copper submits a preliminary Mine Plan of Operations (MPO) to the Coronado National Forest (CNF) requesting approval to construct, operate, reclaim, and then close an open-pit mine on and adjacent to forest lands administered by CNF, in order to develop the Rosemont mineral deposit. The proposed mine is located on private and Forest Service (FS) lands in the Barrel drainage on the Nogales Ranger District. The project would consist of an open pit, a processing plant (mill) and associated facilities, and waste rock and tailings facilities, with a total surface disturbance of an estimated 5,888 acres of combined private lands, lands administered by Arizona State Land Department (ASLD), and FS lands. In February 2008, Rosemont supplies a supplemental preliminary MPO which is accepted by CNF for environmental review. Associated with the mine are: electrical transmission and distribution lines, water supply lines, and transportation needs along State Hwy 83. The project would mine copper, silver, and molybdenum but mainly copper (estimated at 5.88 billion pounds of copper, 194 million pounds of molybdenum, and 80 million ounces of silver.
events.source: #Draft Record of Decision and Finding of Nonsignificant Forest Plan Amendment for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; December 2013

events.title: Loss of Chiricahua leopard frog from chytrid fungus
events.description: Loss of Chiricahua leopard frog in the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve due to chytrid fungus. The first official documentation in US of frog loss as a consequence of the fungus recorded in 1998. The fungus was introduced to the environment by bullfrogs. They are less affected by the fungus than other native amphibians.

events.title: Davidson Canyon Creek designated Outstanding Arizona Water
events.description: 3.2 miles of Davidson Canyon Creek is designated Outstanding Arizona Water by AZ Department of Environmental Quality. Pima Area Governments does isotope studies in 2002 that show Davidson water contribution is important in stabilizing base flow in lower Cienega Creek.

events.title: Las Cienegas NCA has 'implied' but defendable water right
events.description: Based on the 1988 Act H. R. 2941 which establishes the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area,the LCNCA has 'implied' federal reserve water rights. BLM has not pursued federally reserved water right to date. They are considered implied Federal Reserved Water Rights, only because they are not explicitly mentioned in the enabling legislation and will remain implied until adjudicated. They will probably be considered implied until they are adjudicated. The Bureau of Land Management may initiate adjudication work in 2020.The largest existing older claim on the creek is from Anamax for irrigation at the agricultural fields (113.69 acres, 314.07 ac-ft/yr)(CWR 4160) originally filed in 1971, then conveyed to BLM in 1988.
events.source: #Murray D. Implied and Reserved Water Rights at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Oct. 28, 2019. #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: BLM renames Appleton Whittell Research Ranch an Area of Critical Environmental Concern
events.description: Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision renames the Appleton-Whittell ACEC the Appleton-Whittell Research ACEC. Management objectives include prohibiting land use actions except as authorized by the Research Ranch and not opening lands to mineral location, leases, or sales.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: Hispanic stockraising in southern Arizona becomes important enterprise
events.description: Stockraising (cattle, sheep, mules, horses) is essential to support developing communities of settled Indians, miners, military garrisons, and missions. Land grants are allotted to further encourage Spanish and later Mexican ranching enterprises.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:60-61

events.title: Antiquities Act passes and is still in effect
events.description: Antiquities Act preserves prehistoric, historic, & scientifically significant sites, creates national monuments; (Pub.L. 59–209, 34 Stat. 225, 16 U.S.C. § 431–433), signed into law by T Roosevelt. This law gives the President the authority to, by presidential proclamation, create national monuments from public lands to protect significant natural, cultural, or scientific features. Act is used to establish Saguaro National Monument in 1933. By 2017, the Act has been used over a hundred times since its passage, sometimes controversially.

events.title: Youth initiative Wild about the Grasslands with Empire Ranch Foundation begins
events.description: Wild About the Grasslands in partnership with Empire Ranch Foundation is a spring and summer outdoor camp at the Empire Ranch that involves youth in grades 3 -12 in science, art, history and technology projects that teach them about the resources of the grasslands and the local traditions of livestock ranching. youth initiative. first youth work, even in surrounding area these young people now becoming politically involved.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Robert Steidl, U of Arizona, starts bird and small mammal surveys
events.description: Bob Steidl, University of Arizona professor at the University of Arizona School of Natural Resources and Environment, starts bird and small mammal surveys.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Severe drought documented in watershed
events.description: PAG shows wet/dry as about 1.5 miles; vs 9 miles of wet years. Gauges at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area show the lowest annual stream flow between 2001 and 2015.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Edward Nye Fish at Cienega Valley and Empire Ranch
events.description: Edward Nye Fish invests in a variety of industries including cattle ranching, horse breeding, mining, freighting and trading. Fish recognizes the value of the natural resources available in the Cienega Valley. In the late 1860s, Fish and neighbor, Thomas Gardner, cut lumber at their sawmill on the nearby slopes of the Santa Rita Mountains to sell in Tucson. By 1871, Fish has purchased, and is probably living in, the original four-room adobe core of the Empire Ranch’s main house. The original builder of the Main Ranch House is not known.

events.title: Seismic repair of Empire Ranch Adobe Haybarn
events.description: The seismic repair project of the Empire Ranch Adobe Haybarn has two primary components: (1) creating a steel framework that will improve the stability of the roof and its attachment to the walls; and (2) repairing and strengthening the foundations and the soils around them. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Bureau of Land Management.
events.source:
#. Preservation Update. Empire Ranch Foundation News. Aug., 2014. 15(3):3
#. Adobe Haybarn Is Stabilized & Ready for Finishing Work . Empire Ranch Foundation News. May, 2015. 16(2):3
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Leveloggers installed along Cienega Creek to record water
events.description: Leveloggers, devices that continuously measure and record water levels and temperatures, are installed in Cienega Creek to learn how waters vary diurnally, seasonally, and annually.

events.title: Cattle ranching initiates ecological changes in southern Arizona
events.description: Prior to 1872, southern Arizona is described as "a wealth of plant growth practically everywhere". Following the Civil War, large numbers of cattle are moved into Arizona. Cattlemen from more moderate, wetter climates in the east fail to recognize the potential problems from the more extreme climate conditions in the Sonoran Desert. They overstock the ranges and initiate declines in topsoil and grass populations during subsequent droughts and floods.
events.source: #Allen L.. Roots of the Arizona livestock industry. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):9-13

events.title: Cattle numbers dramatically increase in Southern Arizona
events.description: Large numbers of cattle are moved to Arizona from overgrazed ranches in Texas following the Civil War. This includes southern Arizona watersheds.
events.source: #Sayre N.. The cattle boom in Southern Arizona: towards a critical political ecology. Journal of the Southwest. 1999. 41(2):239-271

events.title: Empire Ranch House Victorian Addition constructed
events.description: A separate three-room home (Victorian Addition) is constructed at the Empire Ranch by John Harvey for his wife.
events.source: #Harrison LS. Heart of the Empire. Washington, DC: National Park Service; 1992

events.title: Possibly the first use of Colossal Cave as a hideout
events.description: Three gamblers, Gibson, Murphy, and Moyer, feuding with another gambler named Levy, call Levy out of the Cosmopolitan Saloon in Tucson and each takes a shot at him. Levy is killed, and Gibson, Murphy, and Moyer escape into the Rincon Mountains and hide in Colossal Cave. They then move on to the Catalinas, then the Galiuros. They are captured and put in Pima County jail, where they are reported to have tricked and overpowered their jailer, George Cooler, leaving him tied up and gagged in their cell. They set six other prisoners free, and all escape. Within a month of the jailbreak, George Cooler pleads guilty to letting the prisoners go. Ultimately, Gibson, Murphy, and Moyer are recaptured and brought to trial on murder charges. Murphy and Moyer are found guilty—but Gibson is acquitted on the grounds that Levy was already dead when Gibson’s bullet hit him.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Availability and control of water affects use of grasslands
events.description: Successful use and control of grasslands for livestock grazing is determined by availability of water in the landscape and the rancher's control of access to that water. Homestead claims focus on limited numbers of water sites.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:43

events.title: Township around Empire Ranch surveyed
events.description: Theodore H White, surveyor for the General Land Office in Tucson, surveys, describes, and maps Township 19 South, Range 17 East and much of the rest of the Cienega Valley. That land is now open to homesteading claims.
events.source: #Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: AZ Supreme Court decision against Southwest Cotton case
events.description: AZ Supreme Court rules that a water right to make beneficial use of subterranean streams flowing in definite channels could be established by prior appropriation. The decision connects nearby subsurface flow with above appropriable surface waters. This Arizona decision has forever left open and unresolved the physical connection between underground water and surface water.

events.title: Empire Mining and Development Co oversees Total Wreck mining operations
events.description: Major development of Total Wreck mine and milling operations by Empire Mining and Development Co. Mine produces $500,000 of silver ore that supports expansion of cattle and land operations at Empire Ranch. Silver market declines dramatically in 1887.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:48-49

events.title: Vail family land and water acquisitions
events.description: Using new funds from his partner and uncle, Nathan Vail, Walter Vail purchases Tom Gardner’s Apache Spring Ranch 7 miles Southwest of the Empire Ranch in March, 1881, for its abundant water. To consolidate control of other water sources in Cienega, Walter Vail also files numerous mill and mining claims on springs and seeps in the Empire and Santa Rita mountains.
