Walter Vail purchases a small parcel of land in Section 28, T19S R17E, known as Cottonwood in 1893, which sits at the well-used intersection where the road to Fort Huachuca passes across Gardner Canyon. Cottonwood still operates as an important water source. A well and reservoir provide water to two recently divided ponds that separately supply cattle and wildlife.

events.title: Environmental Protection Agency established
events.description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA or sometimes USEPA) is a federal agency created for the purpose of protecting human health and the environment by writing and enforcing regulations based on laws passed by Congress. The EPA is proposed by President Richard Nixon and begins operation on 12/2/1970. The EPA will be responsible for oversight of water quality within the Cienega Watershed following any mineral developments or activities at the Hudbay Rosemont mine.

events.title: Walter Vail acquires Happy Valley in Rincon Mountains and Meadow Valley Ranch in Cienega Valley
events.description: Walter Vail acquires the Happy Valley ranch in eastern Rincon Mountains and Don Sanford’s Meadow Valley ranch at northern end of Cienega Valley. Acquisition of Meadow Valley ranch 1) provides Cienega Creek waters to run Total Wreck mine milling operations, 2) eliminates major competition for Cienega grasslands, 3) gives Vail access to best agricultural lands, and 4) creates an additional line camp for cowboys. Both acquisitions augment major control of grasslands and land use in region.
events.source: #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:58

events.title: Three train robberies on the Southern Pacific line all by the same gang
events.description:
April 27, 1887: Three masked men ambush westbound Southern Pacific Express Train Number 20 near Vail, Arizona. They bring it to a halt by setting off explosives on the tracks, signaling with a red train lantern, and shooting the cars full of holes. Wells, Fargo Express Messenger Charles F. Smith barricades himself and the safe behind the locked door of the express car. The bandits force the engineer to carry a heavy explosive back to the express car and tell Smith to open the safe and get out or they will both be blown to kingdom come. Smith complies, and the robbers get away with about $3,000 in currency. August 10, 1887: Two of the robbers from the April holdup rob Train Number 20 again, between Pantano and Vail, this time making off with a considerable quantity of gold and Mexican silver dollars. August 16, 1887: Two caves are "discovered" about 12 miles from Pantano by the posses scouring the area for the train robbers, who have escaped. Both caves are thought to have been used by the outlaws. Today, one, "Five Mile Cave at Mountain Springs," is Colossal Cave, and the other is probably a small shelter cave elsewhere in Colossal Cave Mountain Park. The bandits are thought to have rested at Mountain Springs [La Posta Quemada] Ranch and all the tracking parties use it as their headquarters.
October 17, 1887: Two men who have been using caves outside of El Paso, Texas, as a hideout, attempt to rob a train about four miles east of El Paso. They are the same robbers; this time they are shot down by Wells Fargo Messenger J. Ernest Smith. The third bandit, who has been involved only in the first robbery, is apprehended and sentenced to serve five years in the Territorial Penitentiary in Yuma.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Expansion of Empire Ranch land holdings and leases
events.description: From 1882 to 1888, through leases and partnerships, Walter Vail dramatically expands access to grazing lands in San Pedro and Sulphur Springs Valleys, Phoenix, and San Diego, California. Drought of 1885 stimulates desire to move cattle off fragile Empire Ranch lands. Vail’s expansion of land holdings into other regions of the country comes at a critical time in the cattle industry. Repeated droughts in Arizona kill thousands of livestock through starvation and dehydration. Always hoping for rain, many ranchers retain their animals too long on already denuded grasslands. Continuing overuse of the ranges permanently alters those plant communities and reduces the quality and density of the grasses.
events.source:
# Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016
#Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:30-33

events.title: John Donaldson leases the Empire Ranch
events.description: John Donaldson enters into a lease arrangement with Anamax to operate the Empire Ranch and run cattle in the Cienega watershed.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Good rainfall in comparison with past years
events.description: John Dunklee completed his University of Arizona thesis on the Altar Valley. Chapter 3 provides a background on periods of drought for Southern Arizona. He notes (p.49) that the most current drought then ended in 1965 so that 1966 was a good year with good rainfall in comparison.
events.source: #Dunklee J. Cattle raising and adaptations to drought by cattlemen in the Altar Valley Pima County, Arizona [thesis]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1967:49

events.title: Apache Fire
events.description: The Apache Fire burns 212.5 acres (0.86 sq. km.)..

events.title: Bureau of Land Management Gila District established
events.description: Tucson Field Office becomes part of Gila District. Tucson Field Office Manager Patrick Madigan. The Tucson Office was formerly an independent field office reporting to the Arizona State Office
events.source: #Public Lands Foundation. Historical Record of the Offices, Managers and Organizations of the U. S. Bureau of Land Management, Grazing Service, General Land Office and O&C Revested Lands Administration 1934 - 2012. Phoenix, AZ: Public Lands Foundation; April 2012

events.title: Department of the Interior established
events.description: The General Land Office is transferred to the Department of the Interior (DOI). The DOI later houses most other land agencies (National Park Service, Soil Conservation Service (later the National Resource Conservation Service) the Bureau of Land Management, and the US Fish & Wildlife Service). The Forest Service remains with the Department of Agriculture.
events.source: #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Stabilization and repair of the Empire Ranch Victorian Addition west gable and walls
events.description: Foundations of the west wall of the master bedroom and bath of the Victorian Addition are repaired and the lintel and gable are reinforced and anchored. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source:
#Empire Ranch House: Victorian Addition West Gable Emergency Repairs Phase 1. Final Version. . . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2008. Technical Report 07-24
#Empire Ranch House: Victorian Addition West Gable Emergency Repairs Phase 2. Final Version. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2008. Technical Report 08-14
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Hannas move from Empirita Ranch to Cienega Creek Natural Preserve
events.description: Neal and Diane Hanna, working cattle ranch caretakers, move from Empirita Ranch (Pantano Townsites) to present Natural Preserve. Source of many creek observations such as: in 1975 new Tucson East Marsh Station and a lot of air smugglers landing in these areas.
events.source: #Hanna N, Hanna D. Shared History at Cienega Corridor Conservation Council Meeting. Personal Communication.May 4, 2013.

events.title: Fire burns in uplands on Research Ranch
events.description: Large lightning-caused fire burns 2,500 acres (~10 km2) on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch. Fire has intense temperatures but grass cover one year later has recovered ~75%.
events.source: #Hass C. Monitoring Avian Productivity and Survivorship at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area 1997-2009. Reports: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch National Audubon Society. Mar 7, 2010. #Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch . Annual Reports of the National Audubon Society Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, 2007-2017. . Elgin, Arizona: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch ; 2008.

events.title: Gene Knoder serves as Resident Director of the Research Ranch
events.description: Gene Knoder serves as Resident Director of the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Gardner Fire
events.description: The Gardner Fire is 74 acres (0.30 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: Continuous winter rains trigger flooding on Cienega Creek and Davidson Canyon
events.description: Rain on almost continuous basis for 2 weeks. Significant flooding on most watercourses in Central and SE AZ. Multiple flood peaks over 2-week duration. Flooding causes decrease in Topminnow population in upper portion of Cienega Creek. Record amounts of precipitation throughout area. Rain and snow melt on Mt Lemmon on January 5, 6 cause flooding in Tanque Verde Creek, Sabino Creek. Major flooding on January 7 on Agua Caliente, Finger Rock, Tanque Verde and Sabino Canyons. Peak discharge on Rillito on January 8 comparable to October 1983 flooding. Severe erosion on Rillito banks. 2.6” in total precipitation in Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. 2.2” precipitation in Davidson Creek. Second major rain event, January 17-18 above Upper Santa Cruz area causes flooding from Green Valley to Marana. (Historic Flood Events. Pima County website)
events.source: 1993 January 5-19 https://webcms.pima.gov/cms/one.aspx?portalId=169&pageId=60316

events.title: Patagonia drought period impacts detected
events.description: Precipitation below the normal of 18.45 inches indicates drought conditions in 9 years interrupted by 8 years of modest above-normal precipitation. The drought years were severe enough that impacts first detected in the region in the form of a big headcut erosion of a channel.

events.title: Gas line explosion accident on Empire Ranch Road
events.description: During routine road maintenance of the main route into the Empire Ranch, J.J. Swift hits a gas line that has been exposed through unforeseen erosion. J.J. is hospitalized but recovers and still maintains road and infrastructure at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area.
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: VR Ranch established in Rosemont Valley
events.description: Edward Vail and Risley establish VR Ranch, associated with the Vails’ Empire Ranch. Located in present-day Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Boice family begins to sell parts of larger Empire Ranch
events.description: In 1939, the US Forest Service steeply reduces the number of cattle permitted to each rancher on Forest ranges. Many corporate ranches, including the Chiricahua Ranches Company, which depends upon Forest range for seasonal forage, have to break up their ranch holdings. The Boice family sells a number of Empire parcels, including the Ingram Ranch south of the Pantano in 1941 and the Andrada Ranch in Davidson Canyon in 1944.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Jack Greenway buys Sanford and VR ranches from Boice family
events.description: Jack Greenway purchases the original Sanford and Edward Vail’s VR ranches from the Frank Boice family and renames them the Cienega Ranch. Greenway builds his ranch headquarters in Section 35 T18S R17E, East of the Ag Fields on Cienega Creek. Greenway uses the fields for pasture.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Empire Ranch Headquarters seismic structural repair plan completed
events.description: Seismic structural repair plan for the Empire Ranch's Adobe Haybarn, Hired Man's House, Grove House, and Ranch House completed. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source: #Structural and Seismic Evaluations of the Empire Ranch House, Hay Barn, Hired Man's House, and Grove House. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2008. Technical Report 08-27
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Wild turkeys appear at Empire Gulch
events.description: Arizona Game & Fish Department (AZG&F) notes that wild turkeys reappear in the watershed beginning around 2008. Areas of successful population development include Southern Arizona Sky Islands and riparian habitats. Eight are sighted at Empire Gulch around 2009 and 2011. Other sightings: April 2008-20-30 Gardner Canyon; and May 2009-1 hen on a trail camera on the east side of Santa Ritas.
events.source: #Tucker R. Arizona Game & Fish Department Records on Wild Turkey Transplants and Sightings. Personal Communication .2020.

events.title: Sam Bell builds Grand Canal at Cienega Ranch
events.description: Sam Bell buys the Cienega Ranch from Jack Greenway in 1969. Monsoon floods in Cienega Creek frequently cause damage to crops and agricultural fields. Bell reworks the agricultural fields in 1972; he plows all of the fields to one level and excavates a two-mile-long ditch -- now called the Grand Canal. Soil excavated from the Canal is used to build the raised roadway (#6901) that today parallels the Canal. Bell creates a temporary berm with sandbags at the southern end of the field to divert Cienega Creek flood waters into the Canal during summer rains. Immediately downstream of that berm is a road with culvert that crosses the reduced Creek; the road provides access to the Cienega Ranch. Bell’s redirection of floodwaters initiates significant erosion downstream in Matty Canyon, Canal enlargement, and other flooding problems near the agricultural fields.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Sacaton grassland vegetation condition mapping complete
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management Tucson and The Nature Conservancy mapping program identifies communities of the sacaton grassland as well as condition assessment at Las Cienegas.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: BLM Gila District Office moves to Tucson from Sierra Vista
events.description: Tim Shannon reports as Gila District Manager located in Tucson; Dennis Silvia as Associate; Brian Bellew departs as Tucson Field Manager, replaced by Vi Hillman
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: Empire Ranch Huachuca House remodeled as a Visitor Contact Station
events.description: The Huachuca House at the Empire Ranch is remodeled as a Visitor Contact Station for the Empire Ranch Foundation.Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source:
#. Visitor Contact Station Debuts at Roundup. Empire Ranch Foundation News. Nov, 2011. 12(4):3:3
#. We Raised the Roof. Empire Ranch Foundation News. Nov., 2012. 13(4):2:2
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Huachuca Forest Reserve established
events.description: In the following year, Huachuca Forest Reserve is redesignated the Huachuca National Forest. Later, the Forest is combined with Tumacacori and Baboquivari NFs to form the Garces National Forest on July 2 1908. The Garces is added to the Coronado National Forest on July 1, 1911. Federal lands in T21S, R18E set aside as Huachuca Forest Reserve. These lands are later transferred to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: BLM restores water flow to Cienega Creek at Agricultural Fields
events.description: BLM removes the dikes and levee in the LCNCA Ag Fields and blocks the flow of water into the Grand Canal. These historic agricultural fields were originally developed by Don Sanford and later used by Walter Vail, Frank Boice, Jack Greenway and Sam Bell for cattle and horse fodder. This restoration and stabilization project redirects the Cienega Creek back into its original channel and permits an unfettered flow in the Creek again. The marshlands, once extensive even in 1936, had been reduced to small half-acre remnant east of the Grand Canal, as a consequence of the long history of agricultural modifications. The new Creek-crossing roadway is moved downstream ¼ mile and rebuilt as a concrete slab designed to have minimal impact to Creek flows. The BLM has situated a public campsite in a portion of the Ag Fields.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Wilderness Act passes
events.description: The Wilderness Act creates the National Wilderness Preservation System and is designed to provide an additional layer of protection to public lands that remain relatively unaltered including those under NPS, USFS, BLM, and USFWS. The act restricts specific types of uses and alterations to the landscapes and creates protections for both natural and cultural resources present at the time of wilderness area establishment. While all other extraction uses are terminated within wilderness areas, the act allows livestock grazing to continue.

events.title: Coronado National Forest begins scoping for Rosemont Mine Plan of Operations
events.description: On March 13, 2008, the Coronado begins soliciting comments on the preliminary Mine Plan of Operations (MPO) with publication in the Federal Register of a 'Notice of Intent to Prepare an Environmental Impact Statement' (Federal Register 73(50):13527–13529). An initial six public meetings are extended at public request and three public hearings added. CNF receives 16,000 discrete comments through August 1, 2008. Issues include potential indirect impacts to historic structures; water quality and quantity with specific concerns for Davidson Canyon, Empire Gulch, and Cienega Creek; air quality, transportation, and access; and threatened and endangered species like the jaguar and ocelot.
events.source: #Draft Record of Decision and Finding of Nonsignificant Forest Plan Amendment for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; December 2013

events.title: Empire Ranch cattle driven to California
events.description: Edward 'Ned' Vail and Empire Ranch foreman Tom Turner drive cattle overland to Warner's Ranch, CA as protest against Southern Pacific RR's rate increase for shipping livestock. Because of dry conditions and little grass, many ranchers in Southern Arizona needed to move their cattle out of the region. After Vail and Turner's successful cattle drive, SPRR rescinded its rate increase.
events.source:
#Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978
#Vail, Edward L. Diary of a Desert Trail: 1880 Cattle Drive from Arizona to California. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2016

events.title: Coronado National Forest releases Draft Environmental Impact Statement for Rosemont Copper Mine
events.description: Coronado National Forest releases Notice of Availability of Draft Environmental Impact Statement (DEIS) for the Rosemont Copper Project which begins a 90-day public comment period, extended on January 19, 2012 through Jan 31, 2012 due to technical difficulties in receiving comments. Seven public meetings held. EIS covers 12 major issues identified in scoping. Over 41,000 individual comments are received on the DEIS. The Environmental Protection Agency rates the DEIS as unacceptable.
events.source: #Final Environmental Impact Statement for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; Dec 2013

events.title: Kentucky Camp investors experience issues resulting in the cessation of mining
events.description: Due to a series of personal problems that tie up finances, gold mining stops at Kentucky Camp. Investor James Stetson dies in fall from Santa Rita Hotel window in Tucson on May 20th; George McAneny begins lengthy divorce proceedings.
events.source: #McAneny begins lengthy divorce proceedings. Arizona Daily Star. May 21, 1905.

events.title: Wild and Free-Roaming Horses and Burros Act
events.description: Act requires BLM and USFS to protect and manage herds of wild animals. Management of herd growth has been through roundup and private adoption. Transition to private ownership has been fraught with problems.

events.title: Rosemont Fire
events.description: The Rosemont Fire is 61.77 acres (0.25 sq. km.) in size. .

events.title: Williams Fire
events.description: The lightning-caused Williams Fire burns 18,390 acres (74.422 sq. km.) in an area 10 miles WSW of Benson on the north side of the Whetstones near Williams Ranch. 500 firefighters fight it; one is killed. 180,000 gallons of slurry are dropped. Cost: $275,000.
events.source: #. Williams Fire . Tucson Daily Citizen. June 21, 1968. Pg. 1

events.title: Kentucky Camp acquired by Louis Hummel for cattle ranching
events.description: Louis Hummel acquires the Kentucky Camp property and begins using it for cattle ranching.
events.source: #Doumas, M. Kentucky Camp Interpretive Plan. Personal communication.May 10, 2013.

events.title: Clean Water Act in Arizona
events.description: The Clean Water Act requires consideration and permitting for actions that impact waters of the United States. The Army Corps of Engineer oversees enforcement of permits for Clean Water Act of 1972 in Pima County. The Act establishes the basic structure for limiting discharges of pollutants into AZ waters and provides legal authority for states to establish water-quality standards for lakes, rivers, and streams to protect water quality for drinking-water sources, recreation, and agricultural irrigation, and to maintain and protect water quality for fish and wildlife. The EPA, in partnership with the states, implements Clean Water Act programs to maintain, protect, and restore the biological, physical, and chemical integrity of the nation's waters, including waters that do not flow year-round or consistently, which describes the vast majority of Arizona's streams.
events.source: #United States. Clean Water Act as Amended through 1972. PL92-500. 33US Code 1251. Washington, DC: Government Printing Office; 1972

events.title: Agricultural Research, Extension, and Education Reform Act
events.description: Act provides agricultural research, education, and extension funds for FY 2000 and 2001

events.title: Vail Unified School District acquires original Vail town site
events.description: The property between the railroad tracks is purchased by the Vail Unified School District. The 1908 Old Vail Store & Post Office, Vail's only pre-statehood building, is located on this property.

events.title: Large flood in Cienega Creek
events.description: Cienega Creek experiences a large flood during the summer monsoon in 1988. The flood had a discharge rate of 7420 cfs (5-10 year recurrence interval) and substantially scours the lower Cienega reach. Floodwaters remove significant amounts of trees and vegetation and open the canopy in channel. The flood coincides with the initial reduction of cattle grazing in the Cienega Creek Nature Preserve. Recruitment of cottonwood, willow and deergrass result. At Empire Ranch, Karen Simms states that roads are badly flooded.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Native Americans gather plants on Las Cienegas
events.description: On the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area (LCNCA) managed by the Bureau of Land Management (BLM), Native American families gather plants for use in basketry and medicine. In 2003, the LCNCA Resource Management Plan decision CL05 requires the BLM to work with Native Americans to select harvesting areas for noncommerical collection of indigenous plants, a continuation of plant gathering that has occurred over the last 8,000 years.
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016. #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: The first use of the name Colossal Cave in print
events.description: Alfred Trippel, businessman, and US Forest Ranger Jim Westfall determine to promote and develop "as a natural wonder of the district" what is suddenly called in print 'Colossal Cave'. Prior to this, it has been known as Five-mile Cave or Five-mile Cave at Mountain Springs, or the 'Arizona Catacombs'.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Southwestern Willow Flycatcher listed as endangered
events.description: The southwestern willow flycatcher (Empidonax traillii extimus) is a small Neotropical migratory bird, whose nesting habitat is restricted to relatively dense growths of trees and shrubs in riparian ecosystems in the arid southwestern United States and possibly extreme northwestern Mexico. In the 1990s, bird surveys show reduction in bird numbers. In 1995, the species is listed as an endangered by US Fish and Wildlife Service. A recovery plan is developed in 2002.
events.source: #US Fish and Wildlife Service. Final rule determining endangered status for the southwestern willow flycatcher (Empidonax traillii extimus). Federal Register. Feb. 27, 1995. Federal Register 60:10694
events.tags: ESA Status, Loss of animal, Loss of habitat

events.title: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
events.description: The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) gives EPA the authority to control hazardous waste from 'cradle-to-grave.' This includes the generation, transportation, treatment, storage, and disposal of hazardous waste. RCRA also sets forth a framework for the management of non-hazardous solid wastes. The 1986 amendments to RCRA enables EPA to address environmental problems that can result from underground tanks storing petroleum and other hazardous substances.The program imposes stringent record-keeping and reporting requirements on generators, transporters, and operators of treatment, storage, and disposal facilities handling hazardous waste.

events.title: Gray Hawk nesting expands at LCNCA after fencing riparian areas
events.description: After fencing riparian areas, there is a large expansion of numbers of Gray Hawk nesting as well as other riparian raptors not previously seen, such as black hawks.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Linda Kennedy becomes Apacherîa Program Director at Research Ranch
events.description: Linda Kennedy promoted from Assistant Director (1999) to Apachería Program Director at the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch. In 2006, the Living Gently on the Land education program begins on the Research Ranch.
events.source: Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: William Emory surveys for U.S. Mexican border
events.description: Emory & others publish: Report on the United States and Mexican boundary survey : made under the direction of the secretary of the Interior. Emory boundary survey reports on wildlife in region. Reports on geology, Paleontology, botany, fishes, reptiles, birds and mammals. The report includes the Cienega.
events.source: #United States. Dept. of the Interior, Emory H, Baird SF, Conrad TA, Englemann G, Girard C, Hall J, Parry CC, Schott A, Torrey J . Report on the United States and Mexican boundary survey : made under the direction of the secretary of the Interior. Volume 1, pt. 1. . Washington: C. Wendell, printer; 1857

events.title: Lowest flows at the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve
events.description: Groundwater measuring also shows impact to surface flow because of decade-long drought.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Burrowing Owls appear at Cieneguita Prairie Dog release site
events.description: Burrowing Owl burrows are spotted by individuals netting for bird species on monitoring areas at the Cieneguita Site at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Typically found on the ground, burrowing owls often use prairie dog burrows for their habitatations. In 2012, YES! participants (Youth Engaged Stewardship) observe a burrowing owl along the road side of the prairie dog colony.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Grants aid pronghorn population near Sonoita
events.description: The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation extends grants to the Arizona Antelope Foundation in 2011, 2013, and 2014 which supplement the Pronghorn antelope population, set up GPS tracking, and ensure connectivity by removing barriers. thus increasing suitable grassland. In the Sonoita Plain, the program partners include Arizona Game and Fish, US Fish and Wildlife, Bureau of Land Management, Pima County, local landowners, and a grazing permittee. In 2013, the grant work includes a Southwest Conservation Corps youth crew to remove fences that impede antelope crossing, and other habitat improvements. Over 61 miles of fencing are removed or modified, opening up over 45,000 acres to antelope.
events.source: #Millican J, Dickens G. Pronghorn Recovery on the Sonoita Plain. In: Proceedings of the Tenth Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain . Tucson, A: Cienega Watershed Partnership ; June 2, 2018.

events.title: Frank Schmidt relinquishes his Colossal Cave leases to the state of Arizona
events.description: Frank Schmidt, leaseholder and caretaker of Colossal Cave, wants the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) to develop the Cave. However, CCC projects are restricted to the development of public properties. Colossal Cave, although on public land, is a commercial enterprise on land leased to a private individual and is therefore not eligible for a CCC project. When the CCC becomes active in Southern Arizona, Schmidt, the Pima County Board of Supervisors, the State Land Bureau, and the Tucson Chamber of Commerce unite in efforts to make Colossal Cave a public property. Schmidt gives up his State leases so that the area can be under the control of a government agency, and Colossal Cave becomes a State Park and is thus eligible to be a Civilian Conservation Corps Public Park Improvement Project. CCC Camp SP-10-A is authorized.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Huachuca House installed at the Empire Ranch
events.description: A remodeled surplus building from the army base at Ft. Huachuca is installed west of the Empire Ranch House as a home for Bob and Miriam Boice.
events.source: #The Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2015

events.title: Hollywood filming comes to the Cienega Watershed
events.description: 38 Western films and TV series use the landscape and structures of the Empire Ranch as backdrops including 1946 Duel in the Sun; 1948 Red River; 1959 Last Train from Gun Hill; TV shows Gunsmoke, Bonanza; almost 50 movies. Producers are attracted to the Ranch for its spectacular grasslands uncluttered by modern infrastructure and by the historic buildings and structures of the Headquarters.

events.title: Empire Ranch's Frank (Pancho) Boice dies
events.description: Pancho Boice dies in a plane crash. His son Steve takes over sole responsibility for the operations on the Empire Ranch.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Alien Species Prevention and Enforcement Act
events.description: The Act prohibits shipping certain categories of plants and animals through the mail. The prohibited species are those injurious animals, plant pests, plants and materials under federal quarantine, and certain plants and animals under the Lacey Act, a law that pertains to illegal trade in fish, wildlife, and plants that are considered invasive species. The purpose of the legislation is to protect native species by regulating the expansion/transport of non-native species and to maintain a relatively high level of biodiversity.

events.title: Bureau of Land Management and National Audubon Society partner on Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Cooperative Agreement signed between BLM and National Audubon Society 'for the management of public lands within the Appleton-Whittell Biological Research Sanctuary' The Research Ranch), August 8, 1986. Arizona State Land Dept. re-conveys State's County Bond Trust lands and School Trust lands within Section 16 (T21S,R18E) [Research Ranch] to BLM.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Bullfrog having a negative effect on Chiricahua Leopard Frog
events.description: The Chiricahua Leopard Frog is a native frog, protected by the Endangered Species Act. Bullfrogs prey on these Leopard frogs and often severely impact their populations. Scientists recognize that other factors like cold weather and disease may be part of the negative impacts.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.
events.tags: Non-Native, Loss of Animal, ESA status

events.title: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan
events.description: In 1998 Pima County begins an extended debate (first political and then scientific) about how to protect natural resources and endangered species from growth, development, and loss of habitat. In 2004 voters approve a bond of $164 M to purchase and protect important parcels of land. In 2016 the Pima County Board of Supervisors gives final approval to the Plan. The Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan (SDCP) guides regional efforts to conserve the best lands and natural and cultural resources. The Plan combines short-term actions with long-range land-use decisions in Pima County. County bond monies purchase open spaces, riparian areas, and ranch lands in the Cienega Watershed to preserve those important cultural and natural resources.

events.title: Yellow-billed Cuckoo study ids them at Las Cienegas
events.description: Baseline Yellow-billed Cuckoo survey by Harris Environmental Services finds a high number of nesting birds at Las Cienegas.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Federal Land Policy and Management Act
events.description: Federal Land Policy and Management Act requires public lands be managed for multiple uses and sustained yield through land use planning. Congress recognizes the value of the public lands, declaring that these lands would remain in public ownership. FLPMA, as amended, is the Bureau of Land Management's '(BLM) Organic Act' that establishes the agency's multiple-use mandate to serve present and future generations. The public lands are to be managed in a manner that will protect the quality of scientific, scenic, historical, ecological, environmental, air and atmospheric, water resource, and archaeological values; that, where appropriate, will preserve and protect certain public lands in their natural condition; that will provide food and habitat for fish and wildlife and domestic animals; and that will provide for outdoor recreation and human occupancy and use. FLPMA is the basis for BLM's ability to partner with local non-profit agencies in the management of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area.
events.source: #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Drought severe impacts detected on Las Cienegas
events.description: Drought severe impacts first detected by researchers who also notice a big headcut erosion along Cienega Creek.
events.source: #REF!

events.title: Civilian Conservation Corps work in Southern Arizona
events.description: The Civilian Conservation Corps, working under the US Forest Service, constructs hundreds of miles of drift fences and numerous water developments on Coronado National Forest. Allotments with relatively light stocking rates show marked improvement. The goal of these developments and fencing is to increase range capacity and management.
events.source: #Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20

events.title: Frank Appleton conveys 800 acres to Appleton Whittell Research Ranch
events.description: Adding to Audubon's Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, Frank Appleton conveys 800 acres in Sections 27 & 28 (T21S,R18E. Ultimately the lands are conveyed to the Bureau of Land Management through 3rd party exchange.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Audubon conducts avian surveys and bird counts
events.description: To support its staus as a recognized Important Bird Area, beginning in 2007, Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch conducts the Christmas Bird Count and sets up transects to monitor avian species. An example of the work: in 2008, 120 species are noted with 5,306 individual birds sighted; in 2016, preliminary results tallied 103 species, down from 105 from the 2015 count, and 4,448 individuals, up from 2726 in 2015.
events.source: #Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch . Annual Reports of the National Audubon Society Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, 2007-2017. . Elgin, Arizona: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch ; 2008.

events.title: FROG Project monitors Mexican Garter snake
events.description: In 2009, a major new aquatic study and monitoring program--the Restoring Leopard Frog Habitat in Sky Island Grasslands of Southeast Arizona projec--begins. The FROG Project targets native and non-native species. According to the frog scientists, the Mexican Garter Snake remains uncommon to rare in the frog project area and may have further declined; even with intensive fieldwork in 2010-2012, fewer were seen than in 2002-03. A declining food base may be the chief cause.
events.source: #Rosen PC, Steklis N, Caldwell DJ, Hall DH. Restoring Leopard Frogs and Habitat in Sky Island Grasslands, Final report 2010-2012 National Fish & Wildlife Foundation Keystone Initiative, Wildlife & Habitat Project. Tucson, AZ: Frog Project, Cienega Watershed Partnership; July 29, 2013

events.title: Pantano Jungle Restoration Project
events.description: Pantano Jungle Restoration is the first section 404 restoration project (under the Clean Water Act) allowing for an off-site location in Pima County by the Army Corps of Engineers to mitigate for a project. It is part of a larger vision for restoring miles of banks along Cienega Creek and Pantano. This specific project aims for restoring 5 acres in Township 16 South, Range 17 East, Section 35. Restoration goals are to restore plant diversity to an area that had been cleared of mesquite. In August 1996, volunteers plant 600 seedlings of sacaton grass. Funded through a wildlife grant, the project also experiments with tall pot revegetation to ensure that plants are well-watered. At restoration, some mesquite trees are coming back naturally. Some additional mesquite are planted but with the focus on diverse vegetation, the project adds hackberry, gray thorn acacia, catclaw, sacaton, elderberry and little leaf sumac. It is a restoration success.

events.title: Bullfrogs, crayfish removed from Las Cienegas NCA
events.description: Bullfrogs are removed from the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, and non-native crayfish are removed from Clyne Ranch pond. Mexican Garter Snake is released in Cienega Creek. Subsequently, two new populations of leopard frogs are found in Las Cienegas National Conservation Area.
events.source: #Rosen PC, Steklis N, Caldwell DJ, Hall DH. Restoring Leopard Frogs and Habitat in Sky Island Grasslands, Final report 2010-2012 National Fish & Wildlife Foundation Keystone Initiative, Wildlife & Habitat Project. Tucson, AZ: Frog Project, Cienega Watershed Partnership; July 29, 2013

events.title: Memorial Service for Grant Drennen
events.description: The Federal Government Shutdown includes access to Federal facilities and employees; thus closes the Empire Ranch facilities. The memorial service for Grant Drennen, Bureau of Land Management staff (retired) for Las Cienegas has to be moved to nearby private ranch lands. Grant was a key person in setting up adaptive management processes for the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area including biological planning.
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: Mary Boice leaves the Empire Ranch
events.description: 2 years after, Frank Boice's death, Mary Boice remarries and relocates.
events.source: #The Empire Ranch Foundation. Docent Manual. Sonoita, AZ: Empire Ranch Foundation; 2015

events.title: National Forest Management Act
events.description: The National Forest Management Act (NFMA) is an amendment to the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974, designed to enhance protection of forests from excessive and destructive logging and to develop regulations that limit the size of clearcuts, protect streams and soils, and ensure prompt reforestation based on Multiple-Use and Sustained-Yield principles. The Act requires implementation of a resource management plan for each forest unit. Under the Cornado National Forest land use plan, logging in the Cienega Creek watershed is highly limited.

events.title: Jeff Simms surveys fish at Las Cienegas NCA
events.description: Jeff Simms (Bureau of Land Management aquatic biologist) surveys Cienega Creek surface water for fish populations. He observes 100+ fish in pools. Jeff notes that the surface water was 10+ square miles in 1990, but is reduced in 2012 to 5-7 square miles. In 1990 the tree canopy is very sparse but by 2010, swamps (cienegas) are forming. Shared History Video Part 5
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Pima County is granted in-stream flow water right for Cienega Creek
events.description: In 1993, Pima County applies for and is granted an in-stream flow certificate protecting water in Cienega Creek. An in-stream flow water right is a non-diversionary appropriation of surface water for recreation and wildlife use.

events.title: Chiricahua Leopard frog gone in Cienega Creek on LCNCA
events.description: Scientists report that the Chiricahua Leopard frog has disappeared in Cienega Creek on the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Note that bullfrogs and Mexican garter snakes are common.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Radio Corporation of America proposes satellite city near Lower Cienega Creek
events.description: Pima County Comprehensive Plan accommodates a giant development to support RCA, a large entertainment and communications corporation. The development involves placing a dam at the Benson Hwy bridge in order to construct a lake for recreation purposes. The industrial development does not happen but the area remains zoned as an industrial area until removed by the Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan.
events.source: #Fonseca J.. Cienega Watershed Shared History Part Three. Personal Communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Wet dry monitoring of Cienega Creek starts at Las Cienegas
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management staff began wet/dry monitoring stream flow, well depths and other charateristics in 2006 at the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. These statistics are made available at the annual State of the Watershed symposium and report. The stream flow has been variable depending on climatic factors like monsoon rains.

events.title: Partners agree on Audubon Whittell Research Ranch management
events.description: Signed Memorandum of Understanding between The Nature Conservancy and National Audubon Society for management of 70-acre parcel contiguous with the Research Ranch.

events.title: Beaver reintroduction on Las Cienegas under consideration
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management considers a proposal for beaver reintroduction on Cienega Creek. The Environmental Assessment releases for public review in 2022; decision pending. Discussions at the semi-annual biological planning meetings show support for beavers as a restoration tool and identify issues such as monitoring.
events.source: #Notes: Biological Planning Meeting. Spring 2018 Biological Planning,Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Tucson, AZ: Bureau of Land Management ; Mar. 30, 2018.

events.title: Rosemont Copper purchases water rights from Vail Water Company
events.description: Rosemont Copper Company purchases and holds an option to buy surface water rights from the Del Lago Golf Course (Vail Water Company). The plan is to return the water to Cienega Creek and the Pantano Wash. Vail Water Company is a private water utility company serving water to approximately 4,900 residential and commercial customers in Vail, Arizona. Vail's boundary to the north is Rex Molly Road, to the south is Sahuarita Road, to the west is Houghton Road and to the east is Camino Loma Alta. Vail Water supplies the Del Lago Golf Course water. The Water Company owns the Del Lago well #1 and obtains some water from the Central Arizona Project.

events.title: FROG Project Native Aquatic Species report completed
events.description: The final report on the FROG (Frog and Fish Restoration Outreach Group) Project complete; thorough report available. Among objectives reached: leopard frog breeding sites increased from 2 to 10 and all breeding locations are free from exotic species like bullfrogs. Phase two is to ensure that bullfrogs don't return to the Chiricahua leopard frog ponds. Monitoring and maintenance of ponds continues. Bullfrogs, if found, are removed.
events.source: #Rosen PC, Steklis N, Caldwell DJ, Hall DH. Restoring Leopard Frogs and Habitat in Sky Island Grasslands, Final report 2010-2012 National Fish & Wildlife Foundation Keystone Initiative, Wildlife & Habitat Project. Tucson, AZ: Frog Project, Cienega Watershed Partnership; July 29, 2013

events.title: Survey confirms overgrazing degrades S Arizona grasslands
events.description: David Griffiths, a botanist with the Arizona Agricultural Experiment, sends a survey to cattlemen in the area in order to document how excessive and continued grazing over time has degraded the quality of the ranges of Southern AZ.
events.source: #Wagoner JJ. History of the cattle industry in southern Arizona, 1540-1940. University of Arizona Bulletin. Social Science Bulletin. 1952. 23(2):1-131:44

events.title: Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act
events.description: The Act authorizes new enrollments in the Conservation Reserve Program of the Food Security Act. Thus more farmers, ranchers allowed to receive payments for setting aside sensitive lands from agricultural use or improving environmental quality of those lands. FAIR also establishes a fund for Rural America to support agriculture research and rural development.

events.title: Drought limits stream restoration at Cienega Creek Ag fields
events.description: Drought affected project by preventing riparian plant colonizations (by 2010 part of project area head-cutting). Solution likely to change channel sinuosity.

events.title: Colossal Cave Park is sublet by Pima County to a private partnership
events.description: In an arrangement unique for a public park, Colossal Cave Park is sublet to Joe Maierhauser and Earl Brockelsby, businessmen experienced in tourism; this is a lease of the entire park, not a concession agreement. It is also unique in that Pima County itself is leasing the Park from the Arizona State Land Department.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: State of the Knowledge Workshop for Cienega Watershed and Sonoita Valley
events.description: The 'State of the Knowledge Workshop for the Cienega Watershed and Sonoita Valley,' meets September 17, 2005; hosted by the Valley Planning Partnership Natural Resources working group. The one-day event updates participants on knowledge about resources, issues, management and efforts of various entities in the watershed. Breakout groups identify data gaps, prioritize issues and make recommendations for actions. The 2005 workshop set the stage for later workshops held by participants in the watershed.
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: Fish habitat in Cienega Creek surveyed
events.description: Fish Survey in Cienega Creek shows that pool habitat has improved (deeper) and marsh habitat increased, tree canopy increased, oxygen levels in water decreased
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Coordinated Resource Management Planning for Empire Pasture
events.description: Under the leadership of the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) Tucson, a voluntary natural resource planning process results in a Coordinated Resource Management Plan to enhance resource management and resolve resource issues coordinating parties who are concerned about the land . The Plan focused on the Empire Cienega Allotment on public lands and the Empire Allotment on State Lands. The Empire Ranch CRM plan involved 20 stakeholders and resulted in a plan to meet specific objectives through management and conservation practices. Major partners were the Vera Earl Ranch, the Bureau of Land Management, State Land Department, and NRCS. The CRMP includes a grazing and monitoring plan as well as specific water and restoration projects and standard practices to maintain the landscape health.

events.title: Mexican American War ends in Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
events.description: Mexican-American War ends on February 3, 1848. Mexico agrees to cede most of area now in US Southwest, including Arizona lands north of Gila River. US agrees to pay Mexico $15M in damages.

events.title: Skirt at Pantano dam disintegrating
events.description: In 2007 the dam is breached and leaking.The Rancho Lago Golf Course receives permission from the Pima County Flood Control District to make repairs so they can continue to divert water to the Golf Course Ponds. Pantano Dam is owned by the Vail Water Company. The dam is located in T16S, R16E, Section 14, roughly 1.5 miles upstream from Colossal Cave Road. The dam effectively ends the perennial reach of the creek by diverting water for irrigation at the Vail Valley development to the northwest. The dam, constructed in 1911, is an at-grade concrete structure built directly on bedrock creating a complete barrier to subsurface flow (Hill 1998). A United States Geological Survey stream gage and a Pima County ALERT station are located on the north bank of the creek 60 feet upstream from the dam.
events.source: Source PAG2000 report

events.title: Frank and Mary Boice become sole owners of the Empire Ranch
events.description: Frank and Mary Boice become sole owners of the Empire Ranch, formerly owned by the Chiricahua Ranches Company. Empire Cattle Company is created; partners are Frank, Mary, Frank Stephen (Pancho), and Bob Boice.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Sands Ranch partners on range management
events.description: A coordinated management resource plan is prepared through the National Resource Conservation Service for the Sands Ranch. which includes federal, private, and county lands in the Whetstones (eastern Cienega Watershed). Four primary resource concerns are the subject of more intensive and coordinated management: change of plant communities from grasses to shrubs, loss of soil surface, loss of ability to absorb and store rainfall, and a lack of water reliability for cattle and wildlife. The plan increases the ability of Sands Ranch to apply for grant funding.

events.title: Fire on La Posta Quemada Ranch destroys headquarters house
events.description: Another fire on La Posta Quemada Ranch destroys the headquarters house that had been built in the 1930s by Charles Day on the site of Solomon Lick's Mountain Springs Hotel. Colossal Cave Mountain Park's Mountain Springs Grove Picnic Area is located here today.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Third Science on the Sonoita Plain
events.description: The third Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium (Quarterly meeting of Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership) meets on the Research Ranch. The Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch of the Audubon Society and the Bureau of Land Management celebrate a 25-year anniversary of their cooperative agreement on management of the Research Ranch. Proceedings at http://researchranch.audubon.org
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013. #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.
events.tags: Cienega Watershed Partnership, Research Ranch, Bureau of Land Management

events.title: Severely dry winters impacted cattle
events.description: On two ranches, the Empire in the Cienega Watershed, and the Arivaca in the Santa Cruz, severe and dry winters left cows in poor condition, though Richard Schauss reports that the calves were fine. These were being separated and branded on each Ranch in April 1959.
events.source: #Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]:1

events.title: BLM removes mesquite in upland grass areas
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management used mechanical techniques to fulfill the plan of reducing mesquite trees in the uplands. Restoring the grasslands through multiple means including mesquite removal is directed in the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area approved resource management plan. As part of the post-2008 recession, stimulus funding in 2010 paid for a total of 3,000 acres of removal and resource work. Mesquite forests are viewed as an invasive plant community.

events.title: Appleton Whittell Research Ranch manager Bill Branan hired
events.description: Dr. William V. Branan hired as Apacherîa Program Director and later serves as Research Director at the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch. Branan overlaps with Dr. Michael Morrison (Research Director) in 1994 and 1995.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Arizona Depart. of Water Resources statewide water assessment
events.description: Arizona publishes first Statewide Water Resources Assessment that examines water supply, demand, and management issues for six planning areas.
events.tags: Groundwater, Springs, Surface, Water developments, Water Rights

events.title: National Conservation Landscape System becomes permanent
events.description: Bureau of Land Management establishes the National Conservation Landscape System that gives additional protection to Monuments, Conservation Areas, Wild and Scenic Rivers, Wilderness Areas. Later Congress in March 2009 makes system permanent. LCNCA is one of the first to be designated under the new policy.

events.title: Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act passes
events.description: Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act ensures environmental safeguards of coal mining & reclamation. Established fund to pay for cleanup of abandoned mining lands.
events.source: #Muhn J, Stuart HR. Opportunity and Challenge-The Story of BLM. Washington, DC: Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management; 1988

events.title: Gila chub listed as endangered with critical habitat designated
events.description: The Gila chub is listed as endangered with critical habitat under the Endangered Species Act. Gila chub fish are present in Cienega Creek on both the LCNCA and Pima County's Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. Protecting these watersheds is critical to preserving them and many other aquatic species.
events.source: #Department of the Interior. Fish and Wildlife Service. Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Listing Gila Chub as Endangered With Critical Habitat . Federal Register. Nov 2, 2005. 70(211):66664-66721

events.title: Multiple reports on ecological components available
events.description: The Bureau of Land Management Tucson Field Office and The Nature Conservancy produce multiple reports describing upland grasslands, biological planning, riparian areas, and Gila topminnow fish.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Climate Change Scenario Planning for Cienega Watershed
events.description: Multiple partners of the Cienega Watershed Partnership and The Nature Conservancy participate to develop potential scenarios for the Cienega Watershed and resources under climatic changes. Workgroups based on the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area technical teams (heritage, riparian, upland, montane) identified high risk concerns from climate change and other factors like public engagement. Phase 1 created scenarios for testing against the watershed resources and for future applications in management decisions. The outcome was provided to a wide array of partners and managers for background considerations in viewing issues like restoration, erosion control and revegetation.

events.title: Empire Ranch partner, Herbert Hislop, leaves partnership
events.description: Herbert Hislop, Walter Vail's original ranching partner, leaves partnership due to a combination of family difficulties in England and exhaustion with ranching challenges. Hislop sells his share to Vail for $7,000 and departs for England.
events.source: #An Englishman's Arizona. The Ranching Letters of Herbert R.Hislop 1876-1878. Tucson, AZ: The Overland Press; 1965

events.title: Joe Maierhauser becomes sole proprietor of Colossal Cave Park sublease
events.description: Joe and his partner, Earl Brockelsby, dissolve their Colossal Cave Park partnership, and Joe becomes sole proprietor of the operation.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Deer Spring Fire
events.description: The Deer Spring Fire is 35.59 acres (0.14 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: Appletons purchase Clark Ranch
events.description: Frank and Ariel Appleton purchase the Clark Ranch.
events.source: #Braun B. Ecology Goes to the Country. Tucson, Arizona: Sunday Star-Citizen. September 6, 1970.

events.title: Environmental Quality Incentives Program
events.description: EQIP is a program begun in 1996 under the Farm Bill and modified with every subsequent Farm Bill. The National Resource Conservation Service provides financial resources and one-on-one help to plan and implement improvements and conservation practices for farms and ranches. The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) has provided a steady and major source of annual support, authorizing $2 million in 1997 throughout Arizona, gradually increasing to $10 million in 2002 and $20 million in 2006. EQIP money is spent for water development, drought funding and planning, implementation of conservation practices. It has helped to maintain and improve rangeland conditions, especially to alleviate the drought damage brought by the continued warming and drying climate starting the late 1990s.

events.title: Cienega Creek Natural Preserve management plan update
events.description: Established in 1986, the Pima County Cienega Creek Natural Preserve has regional significance due to the perennial Cienega Creek segments within the Preserve and lush vegetation and resources within the 4,010 acres. The management plan is important because it ensures continued care and protection of significant preserve and creek/riparian resources. The original plan of 1994 makes recommendations for preserving resources, restoring eroded areas, and managing recreational uses through a permit system. The update of the management plan is still awaiting approval by Pima County Flood Control; the 1994 plan is still in effect.

events.title: Land Exchange to Frank Appleton from Forest Service
events.description: Land Exchange Patent 02-62-0119 to Frank Appleton (1076 acres in Sections 27,28 (today the Audubon Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch) from U.S. Forest Service (3rd party exchange). Through a series of land exchanges and purchases, the Audubon Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch was created. This was a significant parcel added in 1962.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Wild Horse Protection Act protects wild horses and burros
events.description: Act prohibits poisoning of water sources for wild horses and burros or hunting from motorized vehicles.

events.title: 5th Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium
events.description: Partners hold annual event at the Research Ranch, focuses on climate change, scenario planning, drought, water. Partners: Bureau of Land Management Tucson, Cienega Watershed Partnership, Audubon Research Ranch, The Nature Conservancy, Sonoran Institute, Pima County, University of Arizona, and Pima Association of Governments.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Monitoring erosion from drought impacts on Lower Cienega
events.description: Transducers are installed at the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve as part of the long-term monitoring of drought effects. Headcuts now showing up from drought. Wet-dry mapping begins in Lower Cienega Creek. Reported in Pima Area Governments study.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Fish Fire
events.description: The human-caused Fish Fire burns in the Fish and Gardner Canyons on the east side of the Santa Rita Mountains. It is 2,076 acres (8.401 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: Border Patrol begins and eventually expands operations in the Southwest
events.description: The U.S. Border Patrol is founded on May 28, 1924, as an agency of the United States Department of Labor to prevent illegal entries along the Mexico–United States border and the United States-Canada border.

events.title: Public Rangelands Improvement Act
events.description: The Public Rangelands Improvement Act of 1978 defines the current grazing fee formula. The act establishes rangeland monitoring and inventory procedures, trend analysis, and improvements of public rangelands for BLM and USFS rangelands.

events.title: Frank Seymour Boice dies
events.description: Frank Seymour Boice dies. Management of the Empire is taken over by his sons Frank Stephen (Pancho) and Bob.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Chiracahua Leopard Frog population crashes in the Watershed
events.description: Chiracahua Leopard Frog die-offs at Las Cienegas are noted by BLM biologist Jeff Simms. He observes thousands of dead frogs and suspects bullfrogs, cold weather, and chytrid disease as causse.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Frank Schmidt dies at age 85
events.description: He has been at Colossal Cave Park for 35 years, having explored it, protected it, and developed it.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Biological Planning Field Day at Las Cienegas
events.description: Twice each year, the Bureau of Land Management and its partners meet in the field at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area to discuss upcoming decisions and implementation of the LCNCA Resource Management Plan. After 2021 and the covid pandemic, the group meets once a year in the fall.

events.title: Kentucky Camp Headquarters entered into Rooms with a View rental program
events.description: Headquarters Building kitchenette is built, ceiling insulation added, electrification completed. Headquarters Building is entered into the 'Rooms With a View' rental program.
events.source: #Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle [Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: 1908 Old Vail Post Office stabilized
events.description: Vail Preservation Society stabilizes Old Vail Post Office with volunteers led by David Yubeta, National Park Service. This is the first of three community adobe workshops.

events.title: Box Fire
events.description: 0.88 km2 in size. 1960s decade saw 13 fires burning over 30,000 acres.

events.title: Agriculture Risk Protection Act passes
events.description: Act provides funds to insure livestock farmers from risk of price fluctuations. It also provides research funding for cattle processing sites and funds for fencing to separate potentially diseased wildlife from livestock.

events.title: Kentucky Camp hydraulic water cannon is recovered
events.description: The historic hydraulic monitor (water cannon) is recovered, rebuilt, and put on display.

events.title: Appleton Whittell Research Ranch completes Grassland Center
events.description: To support research activities at the National Audubon's Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, the Grassland Center completed. Supports outreach events like potlucks and Science on the Sonoita Plain symposia.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Archaeological Resources Protection Act passes to protect sites
events.description: Archaeological Resources Protection Act requires permits for any excavation on public land, provides criminal, civil penalties for removal of artifacts or defacement of sites. Purpose is to provide more effective law enforcement in the protection of public archaeological sites.

events.title: Spanish explorer Coronado travels through Southeast Arizona
events.description: Spanish explorer, Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, in 1540 travels through SE AZ with Fray Marcos de Niza searching for Cibola, the imaginary city of gold. His entourage includes 225 cavalry men, 60 foot soldiers, 5 friars, 1000 indian guides, scouts and supporters, and 1,500 horses, mules and cattle. They bring livestock with them as a travelling food source and means of transport. The assembly probably enters AZ travelling down the San Pedro River; they turn NE through Government Draw Pass and Apache Pass and into New Mexico. This 'entrada' is likely to be the first time that European livestock are in Southeast Arizona. The journey is unlikely to have any lasting environmental effects from cattle presence; there is no evidence that any of these migrating cattle escape to survive and reproduce in the area.
events.source: #Allen L.. Livestock and the Coronado National Forest. Rangelands. 1989. 11(1):14-20

events.title: Melendrez Pass fire
events.description: The lightning-sparked Melendrez Pass Fire burns at the north end of the Santa Rita Mountains in Madera and Box Canyons. It is 5,800 acres (3.02 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: Empire Ranch book published
events.description: Images of America: Empire Ranch, co-authored by Gail Corkill and Sharon Hunt is published. Book is a comprehensive review of the history of the Empire Ranch and includes many photos of the ranch and the families that lived and worked there.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.

events.title: Hummel Fire
events.description: The Hummel Fire is 691.89 acres (2.80 sq. km.) in size..

events.title: Pronghorn reintroduced into Cienega Watershed
events.description: Pronghorn have been gone since the 1950s and 1960s. Through cooperation of the Bureau of Land Management and the Federal grazing permittee, John Donaldson, the Arizona Game and Fish Department reintroduces Pronghorn antelope.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Extreme dry years
events.description: Drought period is one of the driest on record in the Southwest US

events.title: Mac and Billie Donaldson partner with John Donaldson at Empire
events.description: John Donaldson's son Mac and his wife Billie move to the Empire Ranch to partner with John who holds a grazing lease with Anamax Mining Company to run family cattle.
events.source: #Corkill GW, Hunt SE. Empire Ranch. Charleston, SC: Arcadia Publishing; 2011.:46

events.title: Nine land grants established in Southern Arizona
events.description: Nine land grants established in Southern Arizona by Spanish and Mexican governments to encourage settlement in northern Sonora (later southern Arizona) and development of food industries to feed missionary with Indian communities and the presidios that defend them.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:60-66

events.title: Diggins Fire
events.description: The Diggins Fire is 415.13 acres (1.68 sq. km.) in size.

events.title: Las Cienegas National Conservation Area Establishment Act
events.description: HR 2941 Dec 6, 2000, PL 106-538. The act directs the Secretary of the Interior to acquire lands suitable for the LCNCA and to manage those lands in a manner that conserves, protects, and enhances its resources and values. LCNCA is designated because of collaboration among stakeholders. Cienega Corridor (Missing Link) not included, but Congress interested in protecting.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: Appleton Whittell Audubon Research Ranch part of Las Cienegas NCA
events.description: Congress includes BLM land within the Research Ranch as part of Las Cienegas NCA (Public Law 106-538)
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Early settlement in Cienega valley prior to GLO Survey
events.description: A formal survey of an area is required before a homestead claim can be filed. Prior to that survey, ranchers and farmers will ‘squat’ on the land they hope to lay claim to later. Edward Nye Fish and probably Don Sanford do just that; they establish a physical presence in a location and ‘improve’ the land by their built structures and their farming and ranching activities. That investment on the land is essential in the squatter’s later acquisition of title to the land. Or the squatter can sell those improvements to the next homesteader to make a claim.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Free use of grasslands on the public domain
events.description: Unclaimed lands –- the public domain – are free for anyone to use as they see fit. Cattle and sheep require water on a daily basis. Most animals are willing to travel a few miles for that necessity. In the West, waters are often limited to widely dispersed springs or cienegas. Ranchers use those distances between watering sites to keep out other livestock from ‘their’ grasslands. By claiming the 160 acres surrounding Empire Spring and Gulch, Fish and subsequent Empire Ranch owners control access to 1500 acres of high-quality grass without having to invest in additional infrastructure.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Drs. Carl and Jane Bock direct Research Ranch
events.description: Drs. Carl and Jane Bock serve as Research Directors of the Research Ranch under contract to National Audubon Society. Vern Hawthorne is Resident Director of the Research Ranch.
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013.

events.title: Arizona Groundwater Management Act designates Active Management Areas
events.description: Under the Groundwater Management Act, all responsibilities for water planning and regulation, (except water quality) are centralized under one new state agency, the Arizona Department of Water Resources. The act requires that a developer verify he has secured physical, legal, and continuous access to a 100-year supply of water. The act designates four parts of the state where groundwater pumping is heaviest as Active Management Areas (AMAs). The management plans outline conservation goals and methods for various groundwater users in the agricultural, industrial, and municipal sectors. The GMA prohibits the transfer of water between different AMAs, but mine companies and mine operations are exempt. A decision is made to exclude area of Rosemont mine (then owned by ASARCO) from the Tucson AMA and also exclude portions of Davidson Canyon.

events.title: 4th Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium
events.description: 4th Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium (Quarterly meeting of Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership) held on the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch. Partners: Bureau of Land Management Tucson, Cienega Watershed Partnership, Audubon Research Ranch and The Nature Conservancy. Topics focus on bird species and habitats and monitoring with other papers on rattlesnakes, lizards and mapping; Proceedings available at: http://researchranch.audubon.org
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013. #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.
events.tags: Cienega Watershed Partnership, Research Ranch, Bureau of Land Management,

events.title: Early Cienega Valley roads link at Empire Ranch
events.description: General Land Office survey of Township 19 South Range 17 East by T H White locates Fish’s Ranch just north of the junction of Sawmill Road from the Santa Rita Mountains with the Fort Crittenden Road to Tucson. Another road departing northeasterly from Fish’s ranch is labelled Road to Sanford’s. This same road later provides access to the Boice family airstrip and the agricultural field, and is still used today as BLM road #6901.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Victorian Addition section of Empire Ranch House roof replaced
events.description: Americorps volunteers install cedar shingles on Victorian Addition roof and make other repairs

events.title: First annual Empire Ranch Roundup and Open House held
events.description: First annual Empire Ranch Roundup & Open House is held, drawing over 500 visitors to the Empire Ranch.
events.source: #All Heart: Empire Roundup Open House and BBQ. Empire Ranch Foundation News. Nov, 2000. 1(2):1,3

events.title: Rosemont Mining claims located in Wasp and Barrel Canyons
events.description: William McCleary and L.J. Rose begin locating Rosemont mining claims near Wasp and Barrel Canyons. This settlement around the claims becomes known as the McCleary Camp. Rose and McCleary later incorporate as Rosemont Smelting and Mining Co. These Rosemont claims are in present-day Coronado National Forest in NE Santa Rita Mountains.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: New Mexico and Arizona Railroad is built
events.description: The New Mexico and Arizona Railroad is built from Nogales and Benson and connects the towns of Fairbank, Sonoita, and Patagonia. The Sonoita station provides a much closer shipping point for Cienega Valley ranchers and southern Santa Rita miners. Floods along Sonoita Creek wash out parts of the line in 1929. The remaining components are closed in the early 1960s.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Public Land Administration Act passes to make government efficient
events.description: Public Land Administration Act initiates programs to reevaluate all public lands and to improve efficiency of administration of public lands. Act authorizes studies and investigations on public lands, cooperative agreements with other agencies and entities, modernization of fees for service, rehabilitation of lands damaged by timber companies, and acceptance of monies for public land improvements.

events.title: Audubon citizen science bird surveys
events.description: The Tucson Audubon Society initiates citizen science bird surveys, first in the Lower Cienega Creek in 2001-2003 (info still online) and later at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area in 2007-08 (neither area is designated as an important bird area, but data still there).
