Citizens volunteer to work with Audubon staff on recording avian sightings in Lower Cienega Creek. Many Yellow-billed cuckoos are discovered in the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve and a black bear is sighted. The Gray Hawk is recorded in the mid-2000s. Citizen science is the collection and analysis of data relating to the natural world by members of the general public, typically as part of a collaborative project with professional scientists.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Walter Vail and John Selah Vosburg partner on Pantano Ranch
events.description: Walter Vail partners with John Selah Vosburg to operate the 2,700-acre Pantano ranch on Cienega Creek. Vosburg buys the land at Sheriff's sale when Pinckney Tully and Estevan Ochoa default on loan. Vail supplied the cattle. This partnership is outside the Empire Land and Cattle Co. The shared range along with mill claims on north Empire Mountains springs secures full control of the public range from Sanford Ranch to North of Pantano Wash and links Vail-controlled ranges in the upper Cienega watershed with the Happy Valley Ranch on the east side of the Rincons purchased 2 years earlier. Now Vail cattle operations extend 21 miles from the Gardner Ranch in Sonoita to the Happy Valley Ranch in the lower San Pedro Valley.
events.source: #Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015. #Dowell GP. History of the Empire Ranch. Master's Thesis. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 1978:28

events.title: Multiple Use Sustained Yield Act for National Forests passes
events.description: Act mandates that National Forests be administered for 5 separate values: outdoor recreation, range, timber, watershed, and wildlife and fish in a sustainable manner. MUSYA was the first legislation to require the USFS to manage its resources for recreation and wildlife. The act is not highly successful as it had little specificity. Not until other federal acts overseeing USFS management are passed (NEPA, NFMA, PRIA, and FLPMA), does the USFS take management for sustained yield seriously.

events.title: Freight road built from Helvetia to Vail's Station
events.description: This road is needed to transport ore from the mines in and around Helvetia to a point where it can be shipped for processing. Helvetia Mining Company approaches the Pima County Board of Supervisors about sharing the cost of the road and bringing the business to Tucson. Inaction on the part of the Supervisors brings the road to Vail's Siding. Mining in the Santa Rita Mountains and the new road are catalysts for growth in the area.
events.source: #Lamb JJ. The Old Vail Post Office, Connecting the Greater Vail Community Since 1908. The Smoke Signal. The Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2011. 90

events.title: Samuel J. Holsinger surveys Santa Catalina Mountains for Forest Reserve
events.description: Special Agent Samuel J. Holsinger of the General Land Office is sent to Tucson AZ to survey Santa Catalina Mountain area for a future Forest Reserve. With support from the local community, Holsinger recommends the area be set aside as a Forest Reserve. Secretary of the Interior, Ethan Hitchcock, withdraws the range from further homesteading on June 20, 1900. On July 2,1902 Theodore Roosevelt creates the Santa Catalina Forest Reserve.
events.source: #Klein JB. Preserving Our Western Natural and Historical Heritage: the Enduring Legacy of SJ Holsinger. The Smoke Signal, Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2008. 84:77-136

events.title: Empire Ranch House south zaguan lintel repaired and strengthened
events.description: Empire Ranch House zaguan lintel (south end) repaired and strengthened by the installation of a steel beam. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source: #Repair of the Lintel at the South End of Room 2 at the Empire Ranch House. Field Report. Final Inspection.. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2010. Technical Report 10-20
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Action Plan developed for stabilization and repair of the Empire Ranch House
events.description: Action Plan developed by Statistical Research, Inc. provides guidance for the stabilization and repair of roof, drainage, and foundation systems at the Empire Ranch House.
events.source: #Action Plan for Completing Stabilization and Repair of the Roof, Drainage, and Foundation Systems at the Empire Ranch House. Technical Report 00-57.. Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research, Inc.; 2001.
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Pima County Metro population reaches one million
events.description: Pima County grows from 17,000 in 1880 to 980,263 in 2010. As population grows beyond Tucson City boundaries, concerns increase regarding the quality and quantity of water, spread and control of development into rural areas, changing vegetation communities with native plants threatened by invasive species, and pressure on resources due to recreation and residential development. About 20% of Tucson's water availability depends on the Cienega Watershed and its major drainage, Cienega Creek.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Mexican policies encourage increased violence against Apaches
events.description: The end of the struggle for Mexican Independence brings a sharp drop in federal support for political and economic activity on the northern frontier. The northern provinces become more isolated. The frontier economy declines during these years. Military garrisons decrease in size. Civilian militias become more important, although largely ineffective. The Mexican government loses control of the northern frontier and unable to curb the increased violence from Apaches. The government places a bounty on Apaches and hires bounty hunters to bring in Apache scalps. Bounty hunters prey on peaceful rancherias, which are easy targets, more than on hostile Apaches. Some presidios, apparently, poison Apaches. Apaches retaliate more frequently against the Mexicans. Revenge becomes an important driving force of hostilities. Economic support by the central government of the Apaches declines. Mexican communities frequently take hostages to use as advantage against the Apaches. Apaches do the same. Apaches frequently trade goods to one community that they take from another. Political confusion exists on the northern frontier. Mexicans become increasingly worried about a general Apache revolt.
events.source: #Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:82

events.title: Shela McFarlin named as BLM Tucson Field Manager
events.description: Second Field Manager in Tucson for the Bureau of Land Management, she serves from 2001 to 2005. She has oversight for completing the Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and signs the plan in July 2003.
events.source: #McFarlin S. Land Uses on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Personal Communication.Nov 2016.

events.title: Invasive plants mapping and treatment intensifies
events.description: In the 1990s, multiple agencies and partners begin noting the occurrence of invasive species like buffelgrass (Pennisetum ciliare) within the Cienega Watershed and especially areas along Cienega Creek. Between 2008 and 2013, Intensive surveys, often by helicopter, map acres where the invasive plants occur at Saguaro National Park. Treating specific areas begins in 2008 after serious evaluation, and efforts intensify within Saguaro National Park and the adjacent Cienega Creek corridor. While invasive species like mesquite and Lehmann's lovegrass are noted years before in the Watershed, buffelgrass sparks a collaborative effort of managers and volunteers to remove plants.

events.title: Federal Civil Defense Department names Colossal Cave as fallout shelter
events.description: The Federal Civil Defense Department names Colossal Cave a fallout shelter, slated for use by Pima County and City of Tucson government officials. Boxes of food and barrels of water are stored in Cave's Side Routes.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Panic of 1907 halts Rosemont mining
events.description: Banking panic and the resultant stock market crash cause loss of banking liquidity and collapse of copper market. Economic recession for the next 3-4 years halts most copper mining operations in Arizona, including Rosemont.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Santa Fe Pacific Railroad land exchanges in Cienega Valley
events.description: The Santa Fe Pacific Railroad Company is granted exchange lands in Section 34 in Township 16 South and Sections 3, 4, 9, and 10 in Township 17 South, all in Range 16 East containing three thousand thirty-nine acres; Patent 720542. In lieu of payment for building the intercontinental railroads, Congress granted to the railroad companies lands along their tracks. Following the construction of the Atlantic and Pacific Rail line, some of its granted lands fell within the newly established San Francisco and Grand Canyon Forest Reserves (now the Kaibab NF and Grand Canyon NP). Under the Act of April 28, 1904, Congress allowed A & P RR and its successor, the Santa Fe RR, to choose unclaimed exchange lands outside of the Forests of equal value. Exchange lands granted to SF RR were selected in many Township and Ranges throughout Cienega Valley.

events.title: Frank Boice initiates mesquite controls at Empire Ranch
events.description: Moving out of wash environments, mesquite begins invading range grasslands around the beginning of the 20th century. Frank Boice on Empire ranges initiates a program to control mesquite using arsenic and diesel fuel to poison the shrubs, and hand-removal to restore the grasslands. That control program (without the poisons) continues today. The Bureau of Land Management and volunteers have cleared 20,000 acres to improve range quality and to open grasslands for the release of prairie dogs and pronghorn antelope.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Bureau of Land Management Arizona State Office created
events.description: BLM has re-organized multiple times but in 1961, it creates a state office system. The Arizona State Office is created to oversee Arizona public lands. AZ State Director: Fred J. Weiler 1961-1970.
events.source: #Public Lands Foundation. Historical Record of the Offices, Managers and Organizations of the U. S. Bureau of Land Management, Grazing Service, General Land Office and O&C Revested Lands Administration 1934 - 2012. Phoenix, AZ: Public Lands Foundation; April 2012

events.title: Stabilization and repair of Empire Ranch House, Stone Corral, and windmill
events.description: Action Plan repairs to Ranch House completed. Emergency repairs of the Stone Corral include anchoring the roof, installing new support posts, and repointing deteriorated mortar. Headquarters windmill repaired.
events.source:
#Stabilization and Repair of the Stone Corral at the Empire Ranch House. Final Report prepared for Empire Ranch Foundation. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2005. Technical Report 04-70
#Documentation of Action Plan Stabilization and Repairs Completed at the Empire Ranch House. Report Prepared for Empire Ranch Foundation, 2001-2002. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2003. Technical Report 03-05
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership Oral History Work Group begins
events.description: Partners: CWP, Empire Ranch Foundation, Amerind Foundation, Colossal Cave Mountain Park, Bureau of Land Management, Coronado National Forest, Vail Preservation Society
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Sky Island Alliance citizen science wildlife tracking program
events.description: The Sky Island Alliance Citizen Science program organizes volunteers for a wildlife tracking program. Sky Island lays out four to five transects in Lower Cienega Creek and two at Las Cienegas. Trevor Hare organizes volunteers to record sightings along the specific transects and roads on Las Cienegas.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Second Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium
events.description: Second Annual Science on the Sonoita Plain Symposium (Quarterly meeting of Sonoita Valley Planning Partnership), meets on the Research Ranch with wide variety of topics on: archaeology, paleontology, grazing management, species monitoring, aquatic species; Sponsors: Cienega Watershed Partnership, Audubon Research Ranch, Bureau of Land Management. Proceedings available at http://researchranch.audubon.org
events.source: #Kennedy L, Kugler P. Research Ranch Timeline. Personal communication.April 2013. #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.
events.tags: Cienega Watershed Partnership, Research Ranch, Bureau of Land Management

events.title: Boice water control at Agricultural Fields
events.description: Frank Boice designs and builds a dam for water storage to irrigate the Agricultural Fields with waters from Cienega Creek in the summer of 1936. The reinforced concrete dam is 55’ long and 12’ high across the Creek in the northwest corner of Section 35 T18S R17E. The dam and reservoir last only two years, however, before being washed away by an exceptionally large monsoon flood in 1938. Concrete remnants of that dam are still visible on both sides of the Creek channel.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Arizona Department of Water Resources releases latest version of the Arizona Water Atlas
events.description: The Arizona Water Atlas is an assessment of water resources, water planning, and management. Its purpose is to provide water-related information on a local, regional, and statewide basis to support present and future planning. LCNCA is located within the SE planning area, whereas the lower Cienega Creek is in the Tucson Active Management area. Volume 3 contains a good summary of Cienega Creek Waters.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: US Fish and Wildlife Service issues the Las Cienegas NCA Biological Opinion
events.description:
The Endangered Species Act (ESA) requires Federal agencies proposing management decisions and actions to consult with the US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) to determine potential impacts and mitigation on Threatened and Endangered (T&E) species. Since the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area is home for several T&E species, the 2003 Resource Management Plan requires that a Biological Opinion be developed and finalized by the Bureau of Land Management with USFWS. Species consulted on: 
 1) endangered southwestern willow flycatcher (Empidonax traillii extimus), 2) endangered Gila topminnow (Poeciliopsis o. occidentalis), 3) endangered Huachuca water umbel (Lilaeopsis schaffneriana var. recurva), 4) endangered desert pupfish (Cyprinodon m. macularius), 5) endangered Canelo Hills ladies'-tresses (Spiranthes delitescens), 6) endangered northern aplomado falcon (Falco femoralis septentrionalis), 7) endangered lesser long-nosed bat (Leptonycteris curasoae yerbabuenae), 8) endangered cactus ferruginous pygmy-owl (Glaucidium brasilianum cactorum), 9) threatened Chiricahua leopard frog (Rana chiricahuensis), 10) proposed endangered Gila chub (Gila intermedia), all with proposed critical habitat. 
 Appendix 5 of the Decision Record for the RMP provides the Biological Opinion which allows most actions covered by the RMP to occur without additional consultation.
events.source: #Approved Las Cienegas Resource Management Plan and Record of Decision. Tucson, AZ: U.S. Department of Interior. Bureau of Land Management; 2003

events.title: Emergency repairs to Empire Ranch Hired Man's/Ranch Hand's House
events.description: Emergency repairs to the Hired Man's/Ranch Hand’s House include repair of deteriorated east wall foundations and brick buttresses and strengthening of the foundations. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source: #Emergency Repairs at the Adobe Hay Barn and Hired Man's House at the Empire Ranch Headquarters.. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2006. Technical Report 05-37
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Ryan Wildfire at Research Ranch
events.description: The Ryan Wildfire burns 90% of 8,000-acre (32.375 sq. km.) Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch.
events.source: #Bock CE, Kennedy L, Bock JH, Jones ZF. Effects of Fire Frequency and Intensity on Velvet Mesquite in an Arizona Grassland. Rangeland Ecology Management. 2007. 60(5):508-514

events.title: Emergency repairs to Empire Ranch Adobe Haybarn
events.description: Adobe Haybarn repairs straighten and seal huge cracks in two leaning walls and a gable, restore eroded foundations, repair a falling corner, and tie down the roof. Work conducted by Statistical Research Inc. with funding provided by the Empire Ranch Foundation and Bureau of Land Management.
events.source: #Emergency Repairs at the Adobe Hay Barn and Hired Man's House at the Empire Ranch Headquarters.. . Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2006. Technical Report 05-37
events.tags: Bureau of Land Management, Empire Ranch

events.title: Chiricahua leopard frog listed as threatened under Endangered Species Act
events.description: Chiricahua Leopard frogs receive protections under the Endangered Species Act with a listing as threatened. Federal agencies must take this into account in their proposed actions on this species.
events.source: #Department of the Interior. Fish and Wildlife Service. Endangered and Threatened Wildlife and Plants; Listing of the Chiricahua Leopard Frog (Rana chiricahuensis). Federal Register. June 13, 2002. 67(114):40790-40811

events.title: Anamax proposes land exchange with Coronado National Forest
events.description: Anamax Mining Co. proposes to acquire 5,544 acres of public lands (not specifically identified) through a land exchange with Coronado National Forest. Later Anamax enters into agreement with the University of Arizona for environmental analysis including archaeological surveys and excavations of potential lands for mining development.
events.source:
#Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Ayres J. The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) ; 1984
#Briggs D. History of Helvetia-Rosemont Mining District, Pima County, Arizona. Arizona Geological Survey. June 2014. Contributed Report, CR-14-D:7

events.title: Byron Cummings takes two expeditions into Colossal Cave
events.description: Professor of Archaeology Byron Cummings, Director of the Arizona State Museum, later President of the University of Arizona, takes two expeditions into the Cave. He makes a survey and a map, naming the formations and passageways. He finds a number of Indian artifacts, as well as two human skeletons, one an Indian and one a Caucasian. He found them in separate places, not together. Unfortunately, the map he drew to accompany his notes is missing, so the specific whereabout of his findings is unknown.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio established at San Pedro River headwaters
events.description: Spanish presidio is designed to protect local citizens and peaceful Indians from Apache depredations. Location unhealthy, water bad, and lack of adequate farm land leads to starvation of inhabitants.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:50-51

events.title: Cienega Corridor Conservation Council formed by partners
events.description: The Cienega Corridor Conservation Council or 4C is established to protect and steward cultural and natural resources in the area that links Saguaro National Park and Coronado National Forest south to the Las Cienegas NCA. 4C partners and the Sonoran Institute develop the 'Missing Link Assessment' to identify issues, threats, and challenges to long-term preservation of natural and cultural resources in the region.
events.source: Final Record of Decision for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Forest Service, Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; Dec 2013.

events.title: Huachuca Water Umbel transplanted into Finley Springs
events.description: The Endangered Huachuca Water Umbel [plant] is transplanted into Finley Springs on the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch. This expands the watershed locations where the plant occurs.
events.source: #Titus JH, Titus PJ. Assessing the Reintroduction Potential of the Endangered Huachuca Water Umbel in Southeastern Arizona. Ecological Restoration. 2008. 26(4):311-320

events.title: Research Ranch implements upland vegetation monitoring
events.description: A new program sets in motion vegetation monitoring of upland sites on the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch. Monitoring is needed to identify presence of non-native plants and fire effects, and to continue to observe the effects of no grazing. Transects for monitoring are sited in representative areas of the various Ecological Sites found on the Research Ranch.
events.source: #Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch . Annual Reports of the National Audubon Society Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch, 2007-2017. . Elgin, Arizona: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch ; 2008.

events.title: Horizon Corporation purchases Rancho del Lago
events.description: Joseph Timan, president of Horizon Corporation, purchases properties to begin his Rancho del Lago residential development in Vail. He plans to develop housing and a golf course on the site.

events.title: Nueva Vizcaya declares war against Apaches
events.description: New Spain's northern province formally declares war against Apaches and begins establishing presidios in northern Sonora (present-day southern Arizona).
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:40

events.title: San Ignacio del Babocomari land grant approved
events.description: Ignacio Elias and sister Eulalia purchase San Ignacio del Babocomari land grant ~34,000 acres for 380 pesos between the Whetstone and Huachuca Mountain Ranges. The lands include the waters of the Babocomari River and some of the best grasslands in SE AZ. The Mexican government encourages the ranching industry and settlement of the region through the sale of large land areas for little money.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Southern Pacific Mail Line operates a stagecoach station at La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: Southern Pacific Mail Line operates a stagecoach stop at La Posta Quemada Ranch on what today is part of Colossal Cave Mountain Park. According to Edward Vail, there is a burned stage station here by 1875, hence the name Posta Quemada--'Burnt Station'.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Conservation Needs Inventory highlights soil and water problems
events.description: By the early 1940s, the Soil Conservation Service (SCS) realizes natural resource information is required to develop programs and set priorities for various conservation needs throughout the country. After assembling and analyzing the available resources data, SCS publishes in 1945 a report on U.S. soil and water conservation needs, which becomes the Conservation Needs Inventory (CNI) and prepares the ground for future inventories.
events.source:
#Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008:1-3,5-6
#Bock CE, Bock JH. View from Bald Hill. Berkeley, CA: University of California Press; 2000:3-4

events.title: Jack Lewis sells most of his interest in La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: Jack Lewis sells most of his interest in La Posta Quemada Ranch to Armond Arnson, head of a Cleveland consortium of investors, and enters into a partnership with them, still hoping to create a resort on the Ranch,

events.title: Appleton Whittell Research Ranch declared Important Bird and Biodiversity Area
events.description: The Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch is declared an Important Bird and Biodiversity Area (IBA) by the American Bird Conservancy. This IBA status is later managed by the National Audubon Society. Under Audubon, the IBA national conservation activities include habitat restoration, land acquisition, and education of local communities about their unique birds and bird habitats.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Bird banding stations are established at Empire Ranch and Appleton Whittell Post Dam
events.description: Bird-banding stations are established at the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch's Post Dam, and at Empire Ranch within Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. In 2002, Bureau of Land Management establishes the National Conservation Area station at Empire Gulch. Each station is run for at least seven seasons between 1997 and 2009, according to a standardized protocol. Both sites are in riparian zones but differ in plant species composition and habitat structure. Almost 2,000 birds are banded during 5,500 net-hours. Seventy-one species are captured at Empire and 56 species are captured at the Post Dam site. Almost three times as many individuals are captured at Empire as at the Post Dam site. The 2002 Ryan wildfire requires that the Post Dam site be reestablished.
events.source: #Hass C. Monitoring Avian Productivity and Survivorship at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area 1997-2009. Reports: Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch National Audubon Society. Mar 7, 2010.

events.title: Gila topminnow and Gila chub found at Cienega Creek Natural Preserve
events.description: At the Cienega Creek Natural Preserve on Lower Cienega, documenting fish shows that the habitat is improving. Gila topminnow and Gila chub now occur at another site, indicating the potential recovery of the two species. That improvement is threatened by drought, but continues into the following decade.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Appleton heirs sell 1,000 acres of Research Ranch
events.description: Heirs of Ariel Appleton sell approximately 1,000 acres within the boundary of the Research Ranch to Swift Current Land and Cattle Co. (Resolution Copper Company). This sale is intended to be part of the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch but is tied up in a land exchange proposal. Resolution Copper is offering the land in exchange for other Federal mining properties.

events.title: Annual State of the Watershed focuses on Scenario Planning
events.description: The Cienega Watershed Partnership and 18 partners focus on Scenario Planning for Climate Change for the annual State of the Watershed. For most, the session conducted by the University of Arizona is an introduction to how scenarios are formed and how these may be useful in resolving resource issues ranging from water to restoration decisions. A decision is made to begin planning for a full session of climate change scenario planning in the near future.

events.title: Tubac has the largest population in Southern Arizona at about 500
events.description: At the time that the Franciscans take over missionary responsibilities from the Jesuits, Tubac is the largest settlement in the region with over 200 Hispanics and close to 300 Indians living around the presidio.
events.source: #Officer J . Hispanic Arizona: 1536-1856. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1989:47

events.title: Colonel Delbert Maxwell Potter surveys private lands not available for homestead
events.description: Survey to identify the boundaries of private lands that are not available for homesteading by settlers moving into the AZ territory; done by cadastral land surveyors working for the General Land Office.
events.source: #Colllins GE. A History of the Lands in the National Audubon Society's Research Ranch near Elgin, in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. Manuscript on file ; 2008

events.title: Moisture and temperatures similar to today create new economic opportunities
events.description: Agriculture increasingly possible in the Watershed in floodplains and some dry locations. While earlier people began experimenting with domesticating maize, during this period, expansion of flood plain zones enabled villages to become more dependent on agriculture.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: Widespread farming communities and settled village lifestyle develop
events.description: Archaeological sites attest to how local communities become dependent on agriculture and how agricultural productivity permits a more settled life. Farming becoms a full-time activity not just part of a foraging strategy. Smaller villages continue but larger communities begin at the end of this time period
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001.

events.title: Prehistoric, protohistoric, and historic use of Colossal Cave and area
events.description: Artifacts indicate that Hohokam, Apache, and Sobaipuri groups use areas of what today is Colossal Cave Mountain Park as a seasonal village and hunting camp. They use Colossal Cave for habitation, shelter, storage, and as a shrine.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Hohokam adopt large complex settlements and intensive agriculture
events.description: Some large Hohokam archaeological sites contain public structures like ball courts, evidence of a growing and complex society. Agriculture expands to support increased population. A number of features like check dams and terraces show the intensiveagricultural practices. These sites, which were occupied for long periods of time, occur along today's highway I-10 and Cienega Creek. Smaller farming sites are located in a wider area.
events.source:
#Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2
#Ferg A, Rozen KC, Deaver WL, Tagg MD, Phillips DA Jr, Gregory DA. Hohokam Habitation Sites in the Northern Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) . Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum ; 1984
#Ravesloot JC, Boley MJ, Medeiros MA editors. The Prehistory of the Marsh Station Road Site (AZ EE:2:44[ASM]), Cienega Creek, Southeastern Arizona, Arizona State Museum Archaeology Series 202. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum ; 2011

events.title: Protohistoric Apache and Sobaipuri living in the Cienega Watershed
events.description: Sobaipuri [O'odham] communities are found at multiple locations in the Cienega Watershed including Colossal Cave Park area. Colossal Cave itself is used for storage, shelter, and religious purposes
events.source:
#Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2
#Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000. :32-57

events.title: Dryland farming possible in specific areas
events.description: Along floodplains, washes, and with irrigation in Cienega Watershed, farming is still viable even though climates are drier. Proto-historic, post-Hohokam groups are living in smaller communities with diverse economies.
events.source: #Pima County. Historic Summary of Pima County, Cultural Resources Fact Sheets. In: Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan. Tucson, AZ: Pima County; 2001. .

events.title: Fort Buchanan established
events.description: Camp Moore abandoned and Fort Buchanan established 3 miles west of Sonoita. The Fort Buchanan location is a fever pit; all soldiers contract malaria. Buchanan abandoned and burned to the ground on June 31, 1861 when confederate soldiers threaten invasion.
events.source: #Collins W et al . The United States Military in Arizona, 1846-1945. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona State Historic Preservation Office; 1993:90

events.title: Frank J Pop Schmidt, first developer of Colossal Cave, arrives in Tucson
events.description: Frank J. 'Pop' Schmidt, a native of Cologne, Germany, arrives in Tucson.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Sobaipuri O'odham in the Santa Rita Mountains
events.description: Archaeological and historical data support this likely timespan for Sobaipuri communities in the area. When described in the late 1600s by Kino and Manje, the Sobaipuri [O'odham] people occupy the Santa Cruz and San Pedro river valleys, maintaining agriculture-based villages. Later researchers investigate protohistoric sites dating to mid-1700s (likely Sobaipuri but possibly Apache or Tohono O'odham) and find roasting pits and house rings of stone.
events.source: #Huckell BB. Sobaipuri Sites in the Rosemont Area. In: Tagg MD, Ervin RG, Huckell BB eds. Miscellaneous Archaeological Studies in the ANAMAX-Rosemont Land Exchange Area, Archaeological Series No. 147, Vol. 4. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum, University of Arizona.; 1984. pp. 107–130

events.title: Illegal grading at Rancho del Lago
events.description: Joseph Timan, of Horizon Corporation, in a hurry to move his plans for the development of Rancho del Lago in Vail forward, illegally grades area around Cienega Creek, resulting in major environmental damage during the October 1983 flood. Pima County and Joe Maierhauser at Colossal Cave Mountain Park sue the Horizon Corp.

events.title: Apaches first noted by Spanish recorders in SE AZ
events.description: Captain Juan Mateo Manje, assigned to guard Padre Eusebio Kino as he travels through S AZ and Sonora, records first comment about presence of Apaches in Pinalenos mountains. It is likely that they have inhabited the area for decades if not centuries before this time.
events.source: #Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:74

events.title: Sumas, Jocomes, Janos Indians occupy Chiricahua Mountains
events.description: Sumas, Jocomes, Janos Indians, nomadic hunter-gatherers, occupy Chiricahua Mountains. This is the first record of their presence. Along with the Chiricahua Apache, these tribes were likely present for decades if not centuries prior to this recording. Very little in known about them. Later they were likely absorbed into other tribes and/or decimated by disease.
events.source: #Rushforth S et al. Ethnographic Overview and Assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site . Denver, CO: US Department of the Interior, National Park Service, Intermountain Support Office; 2010:75

events.title: Orange Coast Group proposes 10,000 seat amphitheatre near Colossal Cave Park
events.description: Orange Coast Group CA, a development company, proposes to build 10,000-seat amphitheatre for the performing arts immediately to southwest of Colossal Cave Park on 80 acres of State land. Development would have included a 30-acre car park for 3,000 cars. Proposal unsuitable from environmental and traffic issues; when made generally known in April, public outcry defeats proposal.

events.title: Empirita Ranch land sold to DW Ingram
events.description: Chiricahua Ranches Company, owned by the Boice family, sells lands to DW Ingram that will become the Empirita Ranch. These lands had been ranched previously by Don Sanford in the 1870s, Kane in the late 1880s, the Villa family in the early 1900s, and the Vail family from 1870 through the 1920s. Ingram sells the land to Mary and Wallace Fleming in 1943; they are the first to call it Empirita Ranch.
events.source: #Parkhurst J, Kaldahl K and Dart A. Cultural Resources Survey, Historic Building Inventory, and A Historic Context for Pima County's 366-Acre Empirita Ranch Property East of Tucson, Arizona. Old Pueblo Archaeology Center Tech. Rep. 2002.002; 2002

events.title: Pima Indians revolt against controls imposed by the missions
events.description: Pima Indian converts from the San Xavier del Bac, Guevavi, and Santa Maria de Soamca missions, rise up repeatedly over the interval to combat Spanish control. In 1734, they damage San Xavier property and abandon their settlements. In 1751 Pima Indians again rise up, murdering priests, burning the Saric, Arivaca and Tubutama missions, reversing Spanish settlement trends. Pima indians continue to harass the settlements until many of the members of the uprising are killed in a final battle in 1760.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:46-49

events.title: Fort Bowie established in Apache Pass
events.description: Fort Bowie is established to protect water and transportation access in Apache Pass and is major player in control and management of Chiricahua Apache depredations as well as other criminal activity in the area after removal of the Chiricahua to Florida in 1886. Fort Bowie is finally abandoned on October 17, 1894.
events.source:
#McChristian D. Fort Bowie, Arizona, Combat Post of the Southwest, 1858-1894. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2005
#Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Fort Crittenden established near headwaters of Sonoita Creek
events.description: Fort Crittenden established ½ mile NE of old Fort Buchanan. New location is out of the marshy area and therefore a more healthy environment for soldiers. Purpose of establishment is to continue effort to control movement and activities of the Chiricahua Apache and to protect ranchers and miners in the Sonoita and Cienega Valleys.
events.source: #McChristian D. Fort Bowie, Arizona, Combat Post of the Southwest, 1858-1894. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 2005

events.title: Spanish forces relocate Sobaipuri settlements out of San Pedro Valley
events.description: In the past Sobaipuri settlements in the San Pedro Valley act as first defense against raiding Apache bands from the East. But even with Spanish military support, communities are decimated by continuing raiding. Spanish forces consolidate Sobaipuri populations further west to Sonoita, San Xavier del Bac and Santa Cruz Valley locations. Raiding continues; Guevavi and Tubac presidios later abandoned. It is likely that this consolidation leads to loss of Sobaipuri identity as they integrate with Akimel O'odham over time.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:40,49-50

events.title: Fort Lowell moves to NE side of Tucson Basin to be closer to Chiricahua Apache activities
events.description: Fort Lowell is moved from downtown Tucson to northeastern corner of Tucson basin. The shift in location brings the military encampment closer to center of Chiricahua Apache operations. Following the capture and removal of the Chiricahua to Florida in 1886, the need for a fully stations fort is significantly reduced. The post is closed in 1891.
events.source: #Pinto R . Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Greaterville established
events.description: Town of Greaterville is established as a result of the discovery of placer gold.
events.source: #Granger BH. Arizona's Names (X Marks the Place). Tucson, AZ: The Falconer Publishing Company; 1983:276

events.title: Henshow, Rothrock and Rutter travel through S AZ recording flora and fauna
events.description: Naturalists H.W. Henshaw, J.T. Rothrock, and J. M. Rutter travel through S AZ recording flora and fauna. After crossing the San Pedro River 'near the site of present day Benson, and about fifteen miles farther west, they came to the 'Cienega', a marshy spot on the Cienega Creek near the locale known today as Pantano. Turning to the south the road moved up Davidson Canyon and the naturalists could see the Santa Rita Mountains...' Observations by naturalists during the US Army Corps of Engineers Wheeler expedition to survey lands in Arizona.
events.source: #Brown DE. Arizona Wildlife. The Territorial Years 1863-1912. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Game and Fish Department; 2009:9

events.title: Greaterville post office established
events.description: Greaterville post office established; Thomas Steele postmaster.
events.source: #Theobald J, Theobald L. Arizona Territory Post Offices & Postmasters. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Historical Foundation; 1961:104

events.title: First formal exploration of Colossal Cave
events.description: January 23, 1879: a party leaves Tucson for Mountain Springs, eager to explore 'the cave or tunnel near there' . January 26, 1879: the Arizona Daily Star reports on the five-hour expedition into what it calls the 'Arizona Catacombs, in which the exploring party finds 'a thousand varied beauties'.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Sobaipur O'odham at San Xavier del Bac decimated by disease
events.description: Following repeated Apache raids, Sobaipuri relocate out of San Pedro Valley to the Santa Cruz Valley and move again later to San Xavier del Bac. Such aggregation of populations increases transmission of disease further decimating populations by 1773. During the following decades, Tohono O'odham groups are brought to San Xavier to supplement loss of Sobaipuri. Ultimately Sobaipuri become absorbed into O'odham groups.
events.source: #Statistical Research Inc. . The People of Southern Arizona, Past and Present. In, Regional Synthesis of Cultural and Historical Resources. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Sonoran Desert Conservation Plan; May 2000. #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:46-58

events.title: The Nature Conservancy purchases two preserves in the region
events.description: The Patagonia-Sonoita Creek Preserve purchased by The Nature Conservancy; around the same time they also purchase the Canelo Hills Cienega Preserve.

events.title: Pantano post office established
events.description: Pantano post office established; Lyman W. Wakefield postmaster.
events.source: #Theobald J, Theobald L. Arizona Territory Post Offices & Postmasters. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Historical Foundation; 1961:117

events.title: Apache Peace policy initiated by Spanish government
events.description: In the 1780s, Spanish offensive military efforts (search-and-destroy) to drive out the Apache were finally succeeding. A pacification policy by the Spanish viceroy was initiated in 1786 that many Apache including Chiricahua, Mimbreno, and Mescalero Apache accepted. Indians who accept are settled near presidios, taught to farm, and given rations. Pacification efforts end when military funding terminates and rations discontinued. Apaches return to old pattern of raiding.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:55-57

events.title: The Nature Conservancy issues report on grassland biology
events.description: Under an agreement with the Bureau of Land Management Tucson, The Nature Conservancy (TNC) initiated a longer-term monitoring program report for the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. The report summarizes work completed to assist the BLM in the development and implementation of a science-based adaptive management and monitoring program to evaluate progress toward objectives established in the Resource Management Plan. Includes 1) an analysis of data collected between 1995 and 2004 on the condition and trend of the NCA’s grasslands, 2) a review of monitoring protocols, and 3) an outline of the adaptive management process implemented by BLM in 2004/2005.

events.title: Pronghorn Grant supports youth stewardship
events.description: Range Riders Fencing Pronghorn, Youth Stewardship on horseback, part of Pronghorn grant from the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation

events.title: Forest Service Organic Act estabalishes Forest Service authority
events.description: The act specifies the purpose for which forest reserves can be established and gives the Forest Service the authority to manage forest lands in order to protect water resources or control access to timber resources. The act allows holders of patented lands or valid homestead claims within forest boundaries to trade acreage for other unclaimed lands from the public domain. Presently the law must to be applied in conjunction with MUSYA and NFMA.
events.source: #Pinto RL. Cienega Timeline. Personal Communication.Feb 1, 2015.

events.title: Solomon Lick builds the Mountain Springs Hotel and Stage Station
events.description: Lick builds hotel about a mile west of Posta Quemada or Burnt Station location noted by Edward Vail. La Posta Quemada Ranch's Mountain Springs Grove is located here today.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: La Posta Quemada Ranch enlarged from combined lands
events.description: Charles (Chay) Day combines federal and state grazing leases with patented lands to enlarge La Posta Quemada Ranch; working lands total 33,000 acres on which Day runs 600 head of cattle.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Bartlett surveys proposed US-Mexico border
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico, in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua. The survey includes observations of flora, fauna, people, geography. Chapter 17 covers area that includes Cienega Watershed.
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854

events.title: Total Wreck post office established
events.description: Total Wreck post office established; Nathan R. Vail postmaster.
events.source: #Theobald J, Theobald L. Arizona Territory Post Offices & Postmasters. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Historical Foundation; 1961:132

events.title: JR Bartlett records seeing many deer and antelope
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 11th: 'many deer and antelope were seen.' Antelope most likely Pronghorn Antelope.
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:384

events.title: JR Bartlett sees wild horses
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 11th: 'We saw for the first time to-day a herd of mustangs, or wild horses.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:383

events.title: JR Bartlett describes the land and flora west of the San Pedro River
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico, Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 11th: 'since we had left the valley of the San Pedro. From that river we had ascended to a plateau of an undulating character, similar to the western prairies. It was covered with short grass ; and in the depressions, some of which were fifty or a hundred feet lower than the plain, we found pools of water, more luxuriant grass, and groves of small oaks.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:383

events.title: JR Bartlett encounters cottonwood trees, willow bushes, oaks, mesquite
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico, Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 12th: 'the valley for the last ten miles of our march resembled an old and highly cultivated place, from which the people and their habitations had suddenly disappeared. Large cottonwood trees and willow bushes lined the stream, while here and there in little groves were beautiful oaks and large mezquit [mesquite] trees; for the latter, although adapted to every soil, becomes a large tree in a rich soil like this.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:384

events.title: JR Bartlett describes agave, yucca, Spanish bayonet, fouquieria, cedar, oaks
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico, Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 13th: 'But amid all this sterile grandeur there was a rich and varied vegetation. The graceful agave thrust up its tall and slender stem from among the rocks; the yucca and Spanish bayonet monopolized as usual every spot where there was a few inches of earth or gravel; while the fouquieria with its thorny stems was well represented. Cedar and stunted oaks jutted from many little depressions where there was sufficient soil to give them a foothold.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:387

events.title: JR Bartlett and Henry C. Pratt hunt for turkey and fish for trout
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 14th: 'Several of us set out in search of game ; but although deer were seen, we were not fortunate enough to kill any. I perceived the traces of turkeys among the cottonwood, and watched for hours beneath them ; but they came not. Mr. Pratt rigged up a fishing line to try what he could find in the brook. His labors were attended with, success; and our dinner table was served with a plentiful supply of trout, which, though small, were a welcome addition to our bill of fare.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:390

events.title: JR Bartlett hunts bear
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 15th: 'He [Colonel James Duncan Graham] himself was quite short of provisions, though much better off than we were ; and having killed a bear in his journey, he had had an abundant supply of fresh meat. This kind of meat, however, will not keep, and is no good after the second day, except in cold weather.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:390

events.title: JR Bartlett kills wild turkey
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 15th: 'I took my rifle and went out again in search, following a deep ravine far up towards the Santa Rita Mountain, and was so fortunate as to get a shot at a turkey, which I brought down. He proved to be a very large one, and a pretty good load to trudge over the hill and rocks with.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:390-391

events.title: John C Cremony, Bartlett Survey interpreter, kills a young panther
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 18th: 'When passing the stream to-day, we were startled by a singular cry from the top of a cottonwood tree, which overhung our path. It was found to proceed from a young panther; when a well-directed shot by Mr. Cremony, brought the animal down. It proved to be not much larger than a cat, and of light brown, or tawny colour.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:393

events.title: JR Bartlett and expedition members observe wild horse herd
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 18th: 'Another incident, was the meeting with a herd of about a dozen wild horses. They gazed on us for some time, with heads and tails erect; they finally got our wind, when they bounded gracefully over tall prairie in a single file, led by a large black stud.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:393-394

events.title: Henry Cheever Pratt, Bartlett expedition artist, catch fish for dinner
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 18th: 'Before we had our tents pitched, Mr. Pratt got out his fishing-tackle to see what the stream could furnish; and his industry was rewarded with a good mess of fish, which helped to eke out our scanty dinner.' [perhaps trout?]
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:394

events.title: JR Bartlett and Henry C. Pratt observe San Rafael Valley
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. Chapter XXVI, Rio San Pedro to the Santa Cruz, September 23rd: 'A few miles brought us to the puerta or gate in the mountain; passing which, we emerged into a very broad and open plain of remarkable beauty. From the elevation where we first saw this valley, the prospect was exceedingly picturesque. Around us grew the maguay, the yucca, and various kinds of cacti, together with small oaks ; while beneath us, the valley spread out from six to eight miles rn width, and some twelve or fifteen in length. Unlike the desolate and barren plains between the mountain ridges, which we had crossed between the Rio Grande and the San Pedro, this valley was covered with the most luxuriant herbage, and thickly studded with live oaks; not like a forest, but rather resembled a cultivated park. While the train was passing down the mountain, I stopped with Mr. Pratt to enjoy the scene, which he hastily transferred to his sketch-book.'
events.source:
#Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:401-[402]
#Davis GP. Man and Wildlife in Arizona: The American Exploration period 1824-1865. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Game and Fish Department; 2001

events.title: JR Bartlett discusses natural history encountered during survey
events.description: John Russell Bartlett and Hector Garcia Conde survey in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua for a potential boundary between the United States and Mexico. 'The Natural history of the regions traversed—Animal life on the deserts Quadrupeds — Reptiles, their great variety and numbers — Peculiar vegetation of the deserts — The Prairie Dog and its habits — The antelope, etc.' This is the chapter title in volume 2 of Bartlett's Narrative of his work on the boundary survey. He goes on: 'Having but incidentally spoken of the Natural History of the countries I passed through, I now propose to give some brief notices of the most remarkable animals that were seen time to time...In the mountains and along the water-courses, where there are more or less forest trees and shrubbery, both quadrupeds and birds are found in greater variety. Among the former may be mentioned the leopard, cougar, ocelot, lynx, panther; the brown, black, and grizzly bear; the fox, antelope, and various kinds of deer; the large wolf (lobo), and the coyote, raccoon, skunk, marmot, weasel! a great variety of moles, rats, and mice, which harbor in the ground; hares rabbits, squirrels, Rocky Mountain Sheep, etc.'
events.source: #Bartlett JR. Personal narrative of explorations and incidents in Texas, New Mexico, California, Sonora, and Chihuahua, connected with the United States and Mexican Boundary Commission during the years 1850, '51, '52, '53, Volume 1. New York and London: D. Appleton and Company; 1854:555-564

events.title: Antelope observed in Upper Cienega Valley
events.description: Colonel James D. Graham,, chief astronomer and head of the scientific corps of the Boundary Commission, observes many antelope grazing in a treeless grassland bordered by the Whetstones on the east and the Santa Ritas on the west.
events.source: #Davis GP. Man and Wildlife in Arizona: The American Exploration period 1824-1865. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Game and Fish Department; 2001:68

events.title: Mearn's quail observed near Sonoita
events.description: Colonel James D. Graham,, chief astronomer and head of the scientific corps of the Boundary Commission, reports: 'Mr. [John Henry] Clark, assistant to Graham, drew our attention today to a new species of dove, also to a partridge, somewhat like our common partridge except that the color about the head is white instead of yellow.'
events.source: #Davis GP. Man and Wildlife in Arizona: The American Exploration period 1824-1865. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Game and Fish Department; 2001:68

events.title: New species of dove observed near Sonoita
events.description: Colonel James D. Graham,, chief astronomer and head of the scientific corps of the Boundary Commission, reports: 'Mr. [John Henry] Clark, assistant to Graham, drew our attention today to a new species of dove, also to a partridge, somewhat like our common partridge except that the color about the head is white instead of yellow.'
events.source: #Davis GP. Man and Wildlife in Arizona: The American Exploration period 1824-1865. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Game and Fish Department; 2001:68

events.title: Black bellied Whistling Duck found in Cienega Watershed
events.description: The U.S./Mexican Boundary survey (1854-5) headed by Major William Emory, US Commissioner and Chief Astronomer, includes zoologists and botanists, who collect and describe species as they move from Texas to California. A number of birds illustrated by the ornithologist Spencer Baird currently occur in the Cienega Watershed and vicinity. A bird called a Long-legged Duck in Emory, is known as a Black-bellied Whistling-duck today; the scientific name Dendrocygna autumnalis is the same. (In Emory, see v.2, pt., pg. 26, pl. 25). It is included in the ebird hotspot list for the Cienega.
events.source: #United States. Dept. of the Interior, Emory WH, Baird SF. Report on the United States and Mexican boundary survey : made under the direction of the secretary of the Interior. Volume 2, pt.2. Birds of the Boundary.. Washington : C Wendell, printer; 1859

events.title: Santa Rita Forest Reserve proclaimed
events.description: Santa Rita is the first forest reserve to be established in southern Arizona and is set aside primarily because of its grass resources rather than its timber.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Pinto RL. Cattle Grazing in the National Parks: Historical Development and History of Management in Three Southern Arizona Parks [dissertation]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 2014

events.title: Sonoita established near rail line
events.description: Present-day community of Sonoita established near the newly completed New Mexico and Arizona Railroad line.
events.source: #Granger BH. Arizona's Names (X Marks the Place). Tucson, AZ: The Falconer Publishing Company; 1983:575-576

events.title: JS Sullivan buys La Posta Quemada Ranch
events.description: John S. Sullivan buys La Posta Quemada Ranch, reinstates it as a working cattle ranch, builds new headquarters house near the corrals, which is also near where the CCC camps had been located.
events.source: #Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000

events.title: Emory and Baird find Western Screech Owl
events.description: Major William Emory, US Commissioner and Chief Astronomer, while surveying between the United States and Mexico in order to establish a boundary (a border) in 1854-5, also conducts studies of the fauna, flora, and geology. A number of the birds described and illustrated in the US Mexican Boundary Survey Report are found in the Cienega. The Western Screech-Owl (Megascops kennicottii) is one. See Plate I for image of the Owl.
events.source: #United States. Dept. of the Interior, Emory WH, Baird SF. Report on the United States and Mexican boundary survey : made under the direction of the secretary of the Interior. Volume 2, pt.2. Birds of the Boundary.. Washington : C Wendell, printer; 1859:4

events.title: Emory’s Boundary Survey provides description of Gadsden Purchase landforms
events.description:
Sketch of territory acquired by treaty of December 30, 1853. how watered. — face of the country.— platas.— valleys and their capacity for agriculture — abandoned settlements. — Mineral wealth. —Pimos indians. — description of sketches. — views.'
 
'The territory acquired under the treaty of December 30, 1853, lies between, the parallels of 31° 20' and 33° 30', and between the meridians of 106° 30' and 104° of longitude measured from Greenwich, and contains 26,185 square miles. Its eastern part is bounded by the Rio Bravo; its northern by the Rio Gila. The interior of the area is traversed by two rivers, which run northwest and empty into the Gila. These are the San Pedro and the Santa Cruz.'
events.source: #United States. Dept. of the Interior, Emory H, Baird SF, Conrad TA, Englemann G, Girard C, Hall J, Parry CC, Schott A, Torrey J . Report on the United States and Mexican boundary survey : made under the direction of the secretary of the Interior. Volume 1, pt. 1. . Washington: C. Wendell, printer; 1857:93-100

events.title: James Pennington and family settle on Sonoita Creek.
events.description: James Pennington and his family settle on Sonoita Creek near Fort Buchanan. They raise money by cutting hay to sell to the military. The Pennington family is one of the earliest Anglo-American families in the Cienega/Sonoita area.
events.source: #Farish TE. A History of Arizona, Volume 2. San Francisco, CA:Filmer Brothers Electrotype Company; 1915:199-200

events.title: Total Wreck post office closes
events.description: Total Wreck post office closes; John O'Dougherty postmaster.
events.source: #Theobald J, Theobald L. Arizona Territory Post Offices & Postmasters. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona Historical Foundation; 1961:132

events.title: Cienega Creek water clear, beautiful, slightly alkaline
events.description: Phocion Way writes in his diary: 'Traveled 8 miles and stopped at de Los Pimos [Cienega] Creek for breakfast. The water is clear and beautiful, but slightly alkaline. The valley is a delightful looking place and its cool water, green foliage and scrubby trees is like a paradise to the weary traveler...' This may be the earliest written description of Cienega Creek.
events.source: #Way, PR. Overland Via "Jackass Mail" in 1858: The Diary of Phocion R. Way. Arizona and the West. Summer 1960. 2 (2): 147-164:158

events.title: Cienega Valley has green foliage and scrubby trees
events.description: Phocion Way writes in his diary: 'Traveled 8 miles and stopped at de Los Pinos [Cienega] Creek for breakfast. The water is clear and beautiful, but slightly alkaline. The valley is a delightful looking place and it's cool water, green foliage and scrubby trees is like a paradise to the weary traveler...'
events.source: #Way, PR. Overland Via "Jackass Mail" in 1858: The Diary of Phocion R. Way. Arizona and the West. Summer 1960. 2 (2): 147-164:158

events.title: BID Irwin describes Sonoita Valley trees
events.description: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes the Sonoita Valley trees: 'Forest Trees--the sulva of the country is of the most diversified character. In the mountains fine timber is found in abundance of the following varieties: Pine, pinon, fir cedar, and spruce; in the river valleys, ash, sycamore, buttonwood, cottonwood, hackberry, black walnut, elm, and mesquite of a very large kind; on the plains, live-oak, in great abundance and of superior quality and size, white-oak, several varieties of mesquite, some of which yield an excellent kind of gum acacia, ironwood, cedar, and a variety of maple.'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:28

events.title: BID Irwin describes Sonoita Valley plants
events.description: Plants--Of shrubs there are great numbers, varying in each locality and according to the character of the soil in which they grow. Wild cherry, sumac, poison-oak, sage brush, elder, bo-elder, creosote bush, scrub-oak, willow, white willow, will currant, manzanita, gooseberry, wild grapevine, a variety of oleander, mulberry, and cowania stansburiana.'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:28

events.title: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes Sonoita Valley mammals
events.description: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes Sonoita Valley mammals: 'Mammals--The following have been noticed: the panther, leopard, wild cat, lynx, gray wolf, coyote, red fox, gray fox, grizzly bear, brown or cinnamon bear, badger, pole cat, weasel, raccoon, beaver, rat mouse, prairie dog, mole gopher, ground hog, gray squirrel, brown squirrel, ground squirrel, antelope, white-tailed deer, peccary or Mexican hog, and the mustang or wild horse, which roams over the plains in vast herds.'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:29

events.title: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes Sonoita Valley birds
events.description: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes Sonoita Valley birds: 'The following [birds] have been met with: wild turkey, (Meleagris mexicana), swan, brent, mallard duck, greenwinged teal, bluewinged teal, diver, blue crane, white crane, white heron, gray heron, jack-snipe, and-snipe, killdeer plover, curlew, bittern, kingfisher, water-hen, black hawk, gray hawk, reddish hawk, sparrow-hawk, Emory's hawk, night-hawk, chuck-willswidow, turkey buzzard, yellow-beaked buzzard, raven crow, (two varieties), magpie, hooting owl, white owl, three varieties of jay, bluebird, blackbird, red-winged blackbird, mocking bird, bunting yellow-hammer, meadow lark, sand-lark, titmouse (blue with crest), titmouse, (greenish, with crimson crest,) hummingbird (three varieties), pisano or prairie pheasant massena partridge, black-crested quail, speckled quail, crimson-headed woodpecker, large gray woodpecker with red crescent on breast, small gray woodpecker, bluish woodpecker with red spots all over the body, fly-catcher, cat bird, chaffinch, sparrow, wren, swallow, martin, golden oriole, dove, ringdove, and wild pigeon.'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:29

events.title: BID Irwin describes Sonoita Valley reptiles
events.description: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes Sonoita Valley reptiless: 'Reptiles--...the large diamond-headed rattlesnake; the short prairie or ground rattle-snake; the coralito, a very small, delicate, and beautifully colored snake, the bite from which is fatally poisonous; the viper; the puff-adder; the mocassin; black-snake...The 'escupion' or spitter (Gila monster) is a large variety of lizard, from twelve to twenty-four inches long, eighth inches in circumference, beautifully marked with black and lemon-colored elevated spots, slow in its movements, and making a hissing sound when irritated, and thrusting its tongue from its mouth in the manner of a serpent. By the Mexicans and the Indians it is reputed to be deadly poisonous...The other varieties of lizards amount to about two dozen...Of chameleons there are two species...Frogs and toads are very numerous and the horse-leech is found occasionally. A variety of rattle-snake, found on the sand plains, has a fold of skin in the form of a hood over the eyes, capable of erection, which gives the appearance of being a 'horned snake'...'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:29-30

events.title: BID Irwin describes insects in Sonoita Valley
events.description: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, comments on some insects that are poisonous and of 'hideous appearance.' Describes the 'vinagrila' [vinegaroon], centipedes, scorpions, and tarantulas.
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:30

events.title: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes Sonoita Valley climate
events.description: Climate--The climate in the vicinity of Fort Buchanan is warm and agreeable throughout three fourth parts of the year. December, January, and February are the winter months...During the warm months, June, July, August, and the September, the thermometer frequently rises above 100 degrees F in the shade...'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:30

events.title: BID Irwin, Fort Buchanan's medical officer, describes rainfall
events.description: The quantity of rain that fell during the year was 16.08 inches, being 1.34 per month. May was the only month in which rain did not fall...July, August, September constitute the rainy season.'
events.source: #Serven, JE. The Military Posts on Sonoita Creek. A review of the brief but important roles of Fort Buchanan 1857-1861 and Camp Crittenden 1868-1861. The Smoke Signal. Fall, 1965. 12:26-48:30

events.title: Cabin C rehabilitation complete at Kentucky Camp
events.description: Cabin C rehabilitation complete, with outdoor running water and modern vault toilet. With this new work, Cabin C is entered into 'Rooms With a View' rental program, a very successful Forest Service program to adaptively reuse older structures.
events.source: #Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle {Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: First Lidar Survey at Cienega Creek Natural Preserve
events.description: First Lidar Survey at Cienega Creek Natural Preserve: lidar is a remote sensing technology using light to create accurate 3-dimensional information about earth surfaces and to enhance management of the CCNP by Pima Association of Governments.

events.title: Montezuma Quail present in Cienega Valley
events.description: First described by Lesson in 1830, the Montezuma Quail (Cyrtonyx montezumae) is found year-round in the watershed. Cassin provides a good history of its discovery by the various members of the U.S./Mexico boundary survey and various military operations. The illustration, Pl. 4, may be one of the earliest depictions of the quails, male and female.
events.source: #Cassin J. Illustrations of the birds of California, Texas, Oregon, British and Russian America. : Intended to contain descriptions and figures of all North American birds not given by former American authors, and a general synopsis of North American ornithology. Philadelphia: J.B. Lippincott ; 1862:21-27

events.title: Cienega School District No. 36 established
events.description: Pima County Board of Supervisors establishes District No. 36 when petitioned by citizens of Cienega Valley. District HQ is located at Crane & Fraker's Ranch.
events.source: #Lamb JJ. Voices of Vail School Timeline. Vail, AZ: Vail Preservation Society; 2016

events.title: Santa Catalina Forest Reserve established
events.description: Santa Catalina Forest Reserve is proclaimed by Theodore Roosevelt to protect water sources and to create summer recreation sites for residents of Tucson. The Rincon Mountains are added to the Santa Catalina Reserve in 1907.
events.source:
#Sayre N. Recognizing History in Range Ecology: 100 Years of Science and Management. In:McClaran MP et al eds. Santa Rita Experimental Range: 100 Years (1903 to 2003). Ogden, UT:US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service Rocky Mountain Research Station; 2003. p.1-15
#Klein JB. Preserving Our Western Natural and Historical Heritage: the Enduring Legacy of SJ Holsinger. The Smoke Signal, Tucson Corral of the Westerners. 2008. 84:77-136

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad builds depot at Vail
events.description: So many people are flagging down the train at Vail's siding that the Southern Pacific Railroad decides to build a depot. The depot also includes Class IV postal service.
events.source: #Lamb, JJ. The 1908 Old Vail Post Office. Smokesignal. Corral of the Westerners; 2011. 1-32:9

events.title: Vail post office established
events.description: Vail post office established; Harry A. Mann postmaster.
