The team investigates sites using historical materials like census reports, almost 100 percent artifact collection, limited test excavations, and mapping and recording. The work reveals a rich use of the area for mining, ranching, and other related historic uses. This work permits greater understanding of how Europeans had utilized the landscape already known to have been occupied during prehistoric times.
events.source: #Ayres J. The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) ; 1984

events.title: Cienega Creek excavations define Early Agricultural period
events.description: Bruce Huckell, supported by Anamax Mining Co.and University of Arizona, excavates again at site AZ EE:2:30 and at Los Ojitos, 500 meters downstream in the Cienega Creek channel. Large numbers of artifacts and pithouses representing early agricultural village settlement occupied year round for perhaps a decade are found. Work provides basis for defining the Cienega phase of Early Agricultural Period as 800 BC to AD50. Huckell notes the diverse biotic communities, first-class farmland along a gentle flowing perennial stream, and a relatively long growing season had been highly conducive to maize agriculture in the area.
events.source: #Huckell BB . History of Archaeological Research in the Cienega Valley . Archaeology Southwest. 2001. 15(4):2

events.title: Arizona Wilderness Act of 1984 approves portions of USFS lands
events.description: The AZ Wilderness Act approves the addition of many portions of USFS lands within Arizona to the National Wilderness Preservation System, including the nearby Rincon Mountain, Miller Peak, Mount Wrightson Wildernesses.

events.title: Marie M. Contzen Homestead Patent
events.description: Marie M. Contzen files homestead/ stock raising claim for 640 acres. Township 14 south, Range 14 East, northwest northeast of Section 3. Township 16 south, Range 16 east, southeast Section 3, east one half of southwest of Section 3, east one half of northwest Section 10, northeast of Section 10, north one half of southeast Section 10, southeast, southeast of Section 10.
events.source: #Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: BLM acquires Empire, Cienega and Rose Tree Ranches
events.description: A significant decline in copper prices leads Anamax to forgo development of its ore body and divest its Empire/Cienega Ranch holdings. As Anamax searches for a buyer, Pima County, interested in protecting an important water source, considers floating bonds to purchase the property. Arizona Congressman Jim Kolbe and Senator Dennis DeConcini believe that the ranchlands should be managed at the Federal level. They petition the Bureau of Land Management to acquire the property and preserve the remaining marsh and riparian environments along with the threatened fish, animals, and birds dependent on those critical habitats.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Winifred M. Lorentson Homestead Patent
events.description: Winifred W. Lorentson, widow of Carl E. Lorentson files homestead claim for 640 acres located in the east half and the east half of the southwest quarter of Section eleven and the northeast quarter and the east half of the northwest quarter of Section fourteen in Township 16 south of Range sixteen east of the Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona
events.source: #Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Pair of Gray Hawks sighted on Empire Cienega RCA
events.description: Bureau of Land Management employees Karen and Jeff Simms, who live on the Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area, sight a Gray Hawk pair. This is the first evidence of potential nesting and reproduction in the area. Gray hawks inhabit mesquite and oak woodlands, especially in the Patagonia Preserve.
events.source: #Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Empire Cienega has grass over our knees
events.description: Karen and Jeff Simms arrive at the Empire-Cienega Resource Conservation Area and describe the area as having lots of rain with the result that “grass is over our knees”. The Empire-Cienega RCA becomes the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area in 2000 (still managed by the Bureau of Land Management).
events.source: Cienega Watershed Partnership. Cienega Watershed Shared History: YouTube Videos. Personal communication.Nov. 2012.

events.title: Frederick J W Contzen Homestead Patent
events.description: Frederick J W Contzen files homestead/stock raising claim for 160 acres. Township 11 south Range 14 east, northeast corner of southeast corner of Section 26, and northeast corner of northeast corner of Section 34 in Township 14 south, Range 14, and wester one half of southwest corner of Section three in Township 16 south, Range 16 east. And, a homestead/stock raising entry for 640 acres in northeast corner of northeast corner of Section 34, Township 14 south, Range 14 east, northeast corner of southeast corner of Section 26, Township 11 south, Range 14 east, south one half of Section 27 in Township 14 south, Range 11 east, and the north one half of the north one half corner of Section 34 in Township 14 south, Section 11 east, and, the western one half of the southwest corner of Section 3 in Township 16 south and Range 16 east.
events.source: #Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Charles C. Day land claim near Vail
events.description: Rancher Charles C. Day files an Exchange-Pvt w/Navajo land claim for 160 acres in the northeast of Section 26 in Township 16 south, Range 16 east.

events.title: Banner Mining Co. acquires mines at Rosemont
events.description: Banner Mining Co. acquires the Rosemont mines from the Lewisohn estate in April 1961 and the Narragansett mine properties from the Albert Steinfeld estate in July 1963.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Briggs D. History of Helvetia-Rosemont Mining District, Pima County, Arizona. Arizona Geological Survey. June 2014. Contributed Report, CR-14-D:7

events.title: Harold H. Nason purchases Rancho del Lago in Vail
events.description: Harold Nason plans to develop the property into a combination cattle and luxury guest ranch. Nason also owns the Westward Look resort in Tucson. Accommodations for 20 are available at Rancho del Lago. The purchase is comprised of 1,850 acres of patented land.

events.title: Anaconda Copper Co. leases Rosemont mines
events.description: Anaconda Copper Company enters into an agreement with Banner Mining Co. to lease their Arizona and Rosemont mine holdings. Anaconda begins exploration in April 1964.
events.source:
#Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Briggs D. History of Helvetia-Rosemont Mining District, Pima County, Arizona. Arizona Geological Survey. June 2014. Contributed Report, CR-14-D:7
#Ayres J. The History and Archaeology of Post-1880 Sites in the Rosemont Area, Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum Archaeological Series 147(3) ; 1984:136-137

events.title: Yellow billed Cuckoo listed as Threatened
events.description: Yellow-billed Cuckoos, once widely distributed in North America, are severely reduced in much of their range as a consequence of destruction of riparian habitats. Yellow-billed Cuckoo (Coccyzus americanus) is listed as a Threatened species under the Endangered Species Act in the western United States. The cottonwood forests of the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area are one of its primary refuges in Arizona. Both cottonwood forests and cuckoos are threatened by the Rosemont mine development and its potential effects on underground water supplies.
events.source: #Cornell Lab of Ornithology. eBird Field Checklist Las Cienegas NCA (Pima Co.) . Internet Resource.2002.

events.title: Archaeological Testing at the Hummel Prehistoric Site
events.description: Archaeologists from SWCA Environmental Consultants complete archaeological testing along a proposed waterline within prehistoric site AZ EE:2:314 to mitigate impacts. Artifacts and analysis indicate the site used as a limited-activity locus possibly associated with Hohokam.
events.source: #Ezzo JA. Archaeological Testing of a Portion of a 23-Meter-Long Segment of Waterline at AZ EE:2:3:314 (ASM), Hummel Ranch Property, Pima County, Arizona. Tucson, AZ: SWCA Environmental Consultants; 2006

events.title: Kentucky Camp receives roof improvements
events.description: Wood shingle roofs installed on all the buildings at the Kentucky Camp Headquarters by Coronado National Forest and volunteers. This restoration program seeks to sustain the original headquarters, cabins, and facilities while opening them for public use.

events.title: Marsh Station excavations reveal early agricultural remains along Cienega Creek
events.description: William Self Associates conducts surveys and excavations to support Kinder Morgan's new pipeline from El Paso to Phoenix. WSA partially excavates Marsh Station Road site, a village with evidence of early agriculture in Cienega Creek. Maize cobs dated to 900 BC and 790 BC. Rich site yields pithouses, 148 features and 40,000 artifacts. Use of the site ranged from 1000 BC to AD 1400, from the Early Agricultural period through the Hohokam Classic period.
events.source: #William Self Associates, Inc. A Modern Pipeline and An Ancient Place . Web page.2015. #Ravesloot JC, Boley MJ, Medeiros MA editors. The Prehistory of the Marsh Station Road Site (AZ EE:2:44[ASM]), Cienega Creek, Southeastern Arizona, Arizona State Museum Archaeology Series 202. Tucson, AZ: Arizona State Museum ; 2011

events.title: Kentucky Camp Centennial Celebration continues restoration program
events.description: As part of the Centennial Celebration, Friends of Kentucky Camp volunteers and Coronado National Forest add a second vault toilet near Headquarters Building, to not only support public day use of the area, but also permit future programs like cabin rental to sustain the historic property.
events.source: #Friends of Kentucky Camp. Various Articles. Kentucky Camp Chronicle [Newsletter]. 1995 - 2015.

events.title: Vail Preservation Society completes first strategic plan
Anaconda Company pursues a Land Exchange to develop mining properties
events.description: Anaconda Company, as lessee of Banner Mining Co., informs Coronado National Forest of its intent to pursue a Land Exchange to develop mining properties.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Schaefer J. The Anamax Project. History of the Rosemont Area in the Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Arizona State Museum; 1979:26

events.title: Cultural resources survey at Las Cienegas reveals grassland sites
events.description: Harris Environmental Group conducts a cultural resources survey for the Bureau of Land Management Tucson Office. Harris surveys 2,214 acres and identifies 18 archaeological sites, including historic and prehistoric properties (mostly preceramic). The fieldwork supports BLM's grassland restoration project.
events.source: #Harris Environmental Group . Cultural Resource Survey, Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Web page.2015.

events.title: San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio transferred from San Pedro headwaters to Fairbank
events.description: San Pedro location of San Mateo de Terrenate Presidio is unhealthy due to bad climate, bad water, and lack of farmland. Presidio moved north to site near Fairbank on San Pedro River in 1775 and renamed Santa Cruz de Terranate. Again poor choice of location leaves troops open to Apache attack. Presidio is moved again in 1780.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:51

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership establishes Wall of Honor, recognizes five individuals
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership establishes the Wall of Honor 'to recognize those who have made significant contributions over time to the Watershed'. At the annual reception on February 10, 2012, five individuals receive posthumous honors: John Donaldson, Jake Kittle, Joe Maierhauser, Mike Seidman, and Stephen Wood.

events.title: Wild turkeys appear in Colossal Cave Mountain Park
events.description: Wild turkeys appear in Colossal Cave Mountain Park: A tom and several hens roam an area extending from the North Picnic Areas to La Posta Quemada Ranch.There is speculation that they were driven down from the higher Rincons by drought and fires; they are still seen occasionally.
events.source: #Maierhauser M, Show S. Turkeys in Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Personal observation, Personal communication.August, 2011.

events.title: Amax Mining Co. acquires Banner Mining Co. Rosemont mine holdings
events.description: Amax acquires Banner Mining Co.’s mine holdings in Rosemont. Amax and Anaconda create daughter company, Anamax Mining Co., to share development expenses.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Schaefer J. The Anamax Project. History of the Rosemont Area in the Santa Rita Mountains, Arizona. Arizona State Museum; 1979:26

events.title: Santa Rita Mountains areas eligible as traditional cultural property
events.description: Ce:wi Duag (Long Mountain in the Tohono O'odham language) (143,645 acres) is determined to be eligible as a Tohono O'odham Traditional Cultural Property. The description notes that others (all O'Odham, Apache, Zuni, Hopi, Pascua Yaqui along with Hispanic communities, local ranchers and residents) have deep ties and values for the Santa Rita mountains. Evidence includes both historic and current economic and religious uses, and 7,000 years of archaeological remains. Ce:wi Duag remains in "Determined to be Eligible" status; no formal nomination has resulted and not likely since the Arizona State Historic Preservation Office is not processing Traditional Cultural Properties as of 2012.
events.source: #Griset S, W Gillespie, M Farrell.. National Register of Historic Places: Ce:wi Duag ("Long Mountain" in O'odham). National Registration Form: SWCA Environmental Consultants, U.S. Forest Service, and Trans-Sierran Archaeological Research. Dec. 10, 2012.

events.title: Central Arizona Project water confirmed in groundwater reclamation wells
events.description: Central Arizona Project water confirmed in groundwater reclamation wells. Isotopic analysis of groundwater withdrawn from CAVSARP, SAVSARP, and Pima Mine Road recharge facilities. Colorado River water is confirmed to be reaching the aquifers beneath the recharge facilities. Not all wells sampled near the facilities show the presence of CAP water, indicating the influence of subsurface hydrology on CAP water distribution in aquifers.
events.source: #Pima Association of Governments. Clearwater Program Stable Isotope Study - 2013 Monitoring Report. . 2014.

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership 2013 Wall of Honor recipients are named
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership recognizes two individuals for their significant work in the Watershed: Jeff Williamson and Charlotte Cook.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Anamax Land Exchange proposal is dropped
events.description: In November 1985 Anamax Mining Co. ceases operations at the Twin Buttes site (its other mining operation in Sahuarita) and liquidates its southern Arizona assets including its Helvetia-Rosemont mining properties and later the Empire, Cienega and VR ranches. Its proposed land exchange with Coronado National Forest is dropped.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Briggs D. History of Helvetia-Rosemont Mining District, Pima County, Arizona. Arizona Geological Survey. June 2014. Contributed Report, CR-14-D:8

events.title: Spanish garrison established in San Bernardino to fight Apaches
events.description: Garrison at Fronteras, Sonora, moves north in 1775 to site in San Bernardino Valley one mile south of border. Poor choice of location; area open to repeated Apache attack. Garrison retreats to Fronteras five years later.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:50

events.title: Preservation Youth Project work on Esmond Station K8
events.description: Cienega High School Construction Tech students (Vail) work on the rehabilitation of a 1915 railroad section foreman house, which has been relocated to Esmond Station K8. Pantano High School students begin processing collections; Esmond Station K8 students conduct oral histories. The Esmond house was originally located at Marsh Station, about eight miles to the east. It had been moved twice. It's third move was to Esmond Station K8 while the school was under construction. The school's site has an 1880s railbed bisecting the site, hense the school's railroad theme. The project is a partnership between Vail Preservation Society and Vail Unified School District.

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership 2014 Wall of Honor recipients are named
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership recognizes three individuals for their significant work in the watershed; Julia Fonseca, Karen Simms, and Elizabeth Webb. The Wall of Honor was established to ensure that outstanding work to sustain the watershed is noted.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Santa Cruz de Terrenate Presidio moves again to Las Nutrias
events.description: The Presidio location is deemed not defensible and moves again to Las Nutrias in the headwaters of the San Pedro River 5 miles from the original San Mateo de Terrenate.
events.source: #Wilson JP . Islands in the Desert: A History of the Uplands of Southeast Arizona. Albuquerque, NM: University of New Mexico Press; 1995:52 #Officer J . Hispanic Arizona: 1536-1856. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 1989:64, 67

events.title: Camp Moore established near Rio Rico AZ
events.description: Camp Moore is established at the abandoned presidio of Calabasas. The first US troops arrive in 1856 to take control of the area from departing Mexican troops after the Gadsden Purchase is ratified. It is the first American military encampment in southern Arizona.
events.source: #Collins W et al . The United States Military in Arizona, 1846-1945. Phoenix, AZ: Arizona State Historic Preservation Office; 1993:86-87

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership 2015 Wall of Honor recipients are named
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership recognizes four individuals for their significant work in the Watershed: Martie Maierhauser, Dennis Caldwell, Ian Tomlinson, Phil Rosen.

events.title: Solomon Lick's daughter dies of burns
events.description: Solomon Lick's baby daughter overturns a candle or lamp at the Mountain Springs Hotel, and dies of her burns
events.source:
#Maierhauser MK, Cockrum EL. The Timeline: The Intertwined Histories of Colossal Cave and La Posta Quemada Ranch. Tucson, AZ: Pima County Parklands Foundation; 2000:
#Hunt SE, Lamb JJ, Maierhauser M. Civilian Conservation Corps Scrapbook: Camp SP-10-A Colossal Cave Mountain Park. Tucson, AZ: Colossal Cave Mountain Park; 2012

events.title: ASARCO acquires Anamax Helvetia Rosemont mine holdings
events.description: ASARCO acquires the Anamax Mining Co. holdings in mid August 1988 for $1M. The holdings include several thousand acres of both patented and unpatented mining claims.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015. #Briggs D. History of Helvetia-Rosemont Mining District, Pima County, Arizona. Arizona Geological Survey. June 2014. Contributed Report, CR-14-D:8

events.title: Anglo Americans begin farming in Sonoita Creek area
events.description: Early settlers who were engaged in farming on the Sonoita Creek...included EG Pennington, Tom Gardner, William Kirkland, Tom Hughes, and John Cady who located in the order named between 1857 and 1872. These pioneers grew corn, beans, and wheat with the use of a occasional flood waters, after the example of the Pima and Papago Indians.'
events.source: #McOmie AM. Dry farming in Arizona. Agricultural Experimental Station . Feb.1, 1918. Bulletin 84:537:537

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership 2016 Wall of Honor recipients are named
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership recognizes four individuals for their significant work in the Watershed: Alison Bunting, Doug Duncan, Jeff Simms.

events.title: A teacher for Vail's Siding school
events.description: Miss Ferris rides the Sunset Express to Vail's Siding to take charge of the school attended by children of railroad and ranching families. This is likely the Cienega School District school located about two miles north of Crane and Fraker's place (present-day Rancho del Lago).

events.title: First Ranger cabin built at Old Rosemont settlement
events.description: Cabin built at Old Rosemont is used by Forest Supervisor Thomas Meagher and Ranger Armour Scholefield.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Las Cienegas NCA is considered a birding hotspot on eBird
events.description: eBird is an online database of bird observations providing scientists, researchers, and amateur naturalists with real-time data about bird distribution and abundance. The Cienega Watershed and vicinity are recognized as a bird-rich area with 200+ species (+34 other taxa) seen year-round, all years.
events.source: #Cornell Lab of Ornithology. eBird Field Checklist Las Cienegas NCA (Pima Co.) . Internet Resource.2002.

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership adds directors and officers
events.description: Officers approved: Shela McFarlin, Chairman; Tahnee Robertson, Vice-Chairman; Larry Fisher, Secretary; new board members Robert Fink, Bob Hernbrode and Frank Postillion joined Mead Mier, Thomas Meixner, Chris In-Albon as board members.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: State of the Watershed Workshop Health Assessment
events.description: The Cienega Watershed Partnership and its partners gather to review the health assessment resulting from the 2016-2017 application of health indicators for the watershed, the first such health assessment. Draft report in the form of a PowerPoint presentation, presents 19 indicators provided by 33 individuals in four areas: climate (precipitation, temperature, drought), water (groundwater, surface water, water quality), ecological (vegetation, wildlife, fire), and socio-cultural (economic vitality, land use, archaeological site conditions, recreational permits, and engagement programs). Data gaps remain for additional 2017 work along with issues on how to present to the stakeholders and the public.

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership 2017 Wall of Honor recipients are named
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership recognizes Gita Bodner, J.J. Lamb, and the Empire Ranch Foundation for their significant work in the Watershed.
events.source: #McFarlin Shela. Cienega Watershed Partnership Files. Personal Communication.2017.

events.title: Sawmill wildfire in Cienega Valley
events.description: Human-caused Sawmill wildfire starts 10 miles southeast of Green Valley, Arizona, and quickly moves to the east side of the Santa Rita mountains into the Cienega Valley. It burns 47,000 acres (186 sq km), including 12,000 acres (49 sq km) on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. Many cottonwoods along the Empire Gulch and Cienega Creek are severely affected. Impacts to Las Cienegas include impacts to vegetation, to habitat for threatened and endangered species like the Chiricahua Leopard Frog and Yellow-Billed Cuckoo, damaged range and recreational structures. Later BLM treats soils, removes damaged trees, and replaces signs and cattle guards. Over 100 people are evacuated and total damage amounts to about $8 million. Over 600 firefighters are engaged. The fire starts when a father shoots into a target to reveal the gender of the expected baby (a boy). Dennis Dickey pleads guility and under a plea agreement, agrees to a sentence of five years’ probation and restitution totaling more than $8.1 million. He agrees to make an initial $100,000 payment and monthly payments thereafter.
events.source: #Bureau of Land Management. Las Cienegas National Conservation Area Post Sawmill Fire Emergency Stabilization and Rehabilitation . Personal Communication .June 8, 2017. #Gabbert B. Firefighters Make Progress on the Sawmill Fire in Arizona. Wildfire Today. April 28, 2017.

events.title: Tucson to Vail Motorcycle Race
events.description: The only July 4th event scheduled in 1915 for Tucson and Vail. The race begins at the Tucson Carnegie Library heads east to Vail. There is a 30-minute rest stop at Schley's Store (1908 Old Vail Post Office) before the race resumes to end at the Tucson Carnegie Library. Lorenzo Boido’s Indian motorcycle crosses the finish line at the Carnegie Library with a time of 49:34. D.J. Buck is 2nd with a time of 51:30, Ray Reynolds on his Excelsior makes the 44 mile course in 57:01, and Highfill, the local dark horse, finishes 6th with a respectable time of 66:45 on his Flying Merkle.
events.source: #Lamb, JJ. Vail - Town Between the Tracks. ; Manuscript

events.title: Edward Nye Fish Homestead Patent
events.description: Edward Nye Fish claims 640 acres in Township 13 south, Range 13 east in the west one half of the southwest quarter of Section 17, and in Township 13 south Range 13 east southeast quarter of southwest quarter of Section 17. And, Township 13 south, Range 13 east, southeast quarter of northeast quarter of Section 18, Township 13 south, Range 13 east, northeast quarter of southeast quarter of Section 18, and Township 13 south, Range 13 east in the western one half of northeast quarter of Section 20.

events.title: Rosemont Ranger Station closed
events.description: Rosemont Ranger Station in the Santa Rita Mountains is closed and relocated to Patagonia around 1929.
events.source: #Gillespie W. A Rosemont Timeline 1879-1999. Personal Communication.May 8, 2015.

events.title: Vulnerable Chestnut collared Longspurs monitored in LCNCA
events.description: The status of the Chestnut-collared Longspur, a grassland bird, is raised to Vulnerable by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). The birds winter in one of Arizona's Global Important Bird Areas (IBA), Las Cienegas National Conservation Area IBA. Large flocks of Longspurs spend the winter in these grassland areas. Tucson Audubon volunteers document these wintering flocks.
events.source: #MacFarland J.. Arizona important bird areas: spotlight on vulnerable bird species: Chestnut-collared Longspurs. Vermilion Flycatcher: the quarterly news magazine of Tucson Audubon Society. Jan.-Mar. 2018. 63(1):12:12

events.title: State of the Watershed Workshop on Health Indicators II
events.description: In follow-up to 2015 Workshop, the 2016 State of the Watershed further defines criteria to be adopted for the first watershed health assessment. In partnership with the Udall Center (University of Arizona), the Cienega Watershed Partnership and its partners narrow 47 potential indicators to fewer than 20, based on a previous survey and workgroups during the workshop. Indicators are grouped into landscape, riparian, upland, and socio-cultural areas. To meet the criteria for a good indicator, it must: measure impacts of change (human, climate, etc.) and the thresholds that threaten ecosystem integrity; produce useful information for management in the short and long term; be repeatable, comparable, consistent, simple/cost effective to collect; be able to expose threats and vulnerabilities; be quantifiable, transferable, and applicable to management across jurisdictions; use data already or readily available; and use data that speaks to the public.

events.title: Vail Preservation Society receives (501)(c)3
events.description: Established in 2006, Vail Preservation Society applies for and receives non-profit 501(c)(3) status.

events.title: Cienega Watershed Partnership 2018 Wall of Honor recipients are named
events.description: Cienega Watershed Partnership recognizes four individuals for their significant work in the Watershed: Linda Kennedy, Dan Robinette, David Scalero.

events.title: Vail Historic Preservation Plan developed
events.description: Vail Preservation Society works with the University of Arizona students to develop a Historic Preservation Plan for Vail.

events.title: Rift Valley fossils and petrified wood
events.description: Formations from this part of the Cretaceous which has an enormous trough or valley in Arizona, have fossils including an unnamed sauropod, Tenontosaurus (ornithopod dinosaur), and petrified wood.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: A Great Rift Valley forms in southeastern Arizona
events.description: The Gulf of Mexico ocean waters fill the southeastern portion of the valley, ebbing and flowing through the years. Rift valley lakes fill the northwestern portions of the valley, as far north as Tucson. A particularly large lake, perhaps 20 miles wide and 60 miles long, exists for a period in this area. In the Cienega Valley, rocks of the Apache Canyon Formation are common.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015. #Dickinson, WR., Fiorillo AR, Hall DL, Monreal R, Potochnick AR, Swift PN. Cretaceous Strate of Southern Arizona. Penney JP, Reynolds SJ editors. Geologic Evolution of Arizona, Arizona Geological Society Digest 17, . ; 1989. p. 447-461

events.title: Rocks of the Gardner Canyon Formation deposited
events.description: The Gardner Canyon Formation, a mix of conglomerates, sandstone, and dark red mudstone is deposited in the Santa Rita Mountains in the early Jurassic period. Fossils include a tritylodon and a crocodilian.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015. #Drewes, H. Mesozoic Stratigraphy of the Santa Rita Mountains, Southeast of Tucson, Arizona, US Geological Survey Professional Paper 658C. US Geological Survey; 1971

events.title: Watershed covered (mostly) by a shallow sea
events.description: Numerous marine invertebrates (including brachiopods, mollusks, bryozoans, corals, and echinoderms) known from area.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Massive volcanic activity may have ended local life
events.description: Massive volcanic activity from giant volcanoes in the area, at a scale that one must suspect largely eliminates life. Upon emptying out its magma chamber, one of the volcanos collapses in on itself forming a giant caldera in the Mt Fagan area.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Rocks of the Fort Crittenden Formation deposited
events.description: Deposited in intermontane lakes and alluvial fans during early laramide deformation. Fossils include: petrified wood, pollen, snails, mussels, fishes (Lepisosteus, Melvius, Pachyrhizodus, Palaeolabrus), turtles (Adocus, Plastomenus, Helopanoplia, Trionyx sl), a polyglyphonodontine lizard, an alligatoroid, and dinosaurs (Tyrannosaur, Allosauroid, Dromaeosaurid, Hadrosaurine, Nasutoceratops (?), Chasmosaur, Ankylosaurine, and Egg Shell).
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015. #McCord RD, Gillette DD. Cretaceous Vertebrates of Arizona. Vertebrate Paleontology of Arizona. 2005. 94-103

events.title: Wildfires are frequent in this area
events.description: Demonstrating that some things never change, recent evidence in paleosoils and rock formations suggests that wildfires are frequent in this area during this time period.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Fossils and petrified wood deposited in rift valley sediments
events.description: Mid-Creteaceous fossils include Sonorasaurus thompsoni a previously unknown brachiosaurid dinosaur (Sonorasaurus thomponi) in the Whetstone mountains and petrified wood.
events.source: #McCord R D. Timeline for Cienega Watershed . Personal Communication.May 6, 2015.

events.title: Development of water retention structures at Empire Ranch
events.description: Empire Ranch manager, Harry Heffner, develops numerous stock tanks across the ranch lands to conserve rainwater runoff and distribute that resource and the effects of cattle grazing more broadly.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: State of the Watershed Workshop Using the Health Assessment
events.description: With its partners, the Cienega Watershed Partnership hosts the 2018 State of the Watershed workshop focusing on finalizing the first watershed assessment from 2017, determining trends in indicators, and addressing questions of how to utilize the information. This becomes an annual workshop. While a few natural and cultural indicators show definite trends like decrease in winter precipitation and increase in temperatures, such trends not yet establishable for other areas due to shortage of data coverage or gaps. As of 2022, 23 elements (indicators) are being used to assess trends.

events.title: Confederate occupation of Tucson for 80 days
events.description: Captain Sherod Hunter and 25 men arrive in Tucson from Mesilla and claim town for the Confederacy. In response to advancing Confederate troops, Colonel James Carleton and 2,000 California Volunteers march westward to defend the territory. They arrive in Tucson on May 20, 1862. Confederate troops abandon town and return to Mesilla.
events.source: #Sonnichsen CL . Tucson Life and Times of an American City. Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press; 1982

events.title: Sam Bell builds dikes/levees at Cienega Ranch Agricultural Fields
events.description: Sam Bell builds a series of earthen and concrete dikes and an earthen levee to manipulate the non-flood waters of Cienega Creek. Water is distributed from those reservoirs to the fields to irrigate alfalfa and hay crops.
events.source: # Chorover G, Erickson H, Pinto RL. Historic American Landscape Survey. Empire Ranch Landscape HALS AZ-19. Tucson, AZ:University of Arizona; 2016

events.title: Archaeological surveys for proposed Rosemont Mine
events.description: SWCA Environmental Consultants survey the proposed Rosemont mine and facilities expansion locating 93 sites and 315 isolated artifacts or features. Sites were evaluated for National Register Eligibility and to develop mitigation plans should the mine be approved. Of the 93 sites, 52 are prehistoric, 1 protohistoric, 36 historical, and 4 multicomponent prehistorical and historical.
events.source: #Final Environmental Impact Statement for the Rosemont Copper Project. Tucson,AZ: USDA Southwestern Region, Coronado National Forest; Dec 2013

events.title: Boice family famous for raising purebred Hereford cattle
events.description: The Boice family is well-known throughout the West for producing high-quality Hereford bulls. They use the Empire Ranch, with its fine grasslands, as the prime breeding location to raise the best Hereford cattle.
events.source: #Schauss R. Hereford Tradition of Arizona's Boices. American Hereford Journal . Jul 1959. 1-24 [reprint]

events.title: World War 1
events.description: Known as the 'War to End All Wars,' World War 1 originated in Europe and was primarily fought by European countries. 70 million soldiers were involved. 16 million people died. The US entered the war on April 6 1917 after Germany sank 7 US merchant ships. During the war, food, gasoline, and many materials were rationed and in short supply. With the demand to feed US troops abroad and later the populations in devastated European countries, the US government encouraged ranchers to buy and raise more livestock and farmers to put more land under cultivation. These misguided efforts led to serious overgrazing on private and public lands and the destruction of thousands of acres of arid grasslands that could not support crops. After the war, the US entered a 3-year long recession. Many returning vets suffered severe lung afflictions from the effects of mustard gas or tuberculosis. Large numbers of vets and their families moved to Arizona seeking a dry climate where they could breathe more easily and recover from their physical and psychological traumas.

events.title: Jose and Josepha Villa homestead in Empirita area
events.description: The Villa family with 11 children settle in the Empirita area on the West side of the Cienega Creek in sections 17 and 20 of Township 17 South Range 18 East. They build 2 2-room houses, 2 corrals and clear and farm 35 acres of barley, corn, and beans. They dig a well and a 2-mile-long ditch to bring water from the Cienega Creek further upstream. When they settle on their farm, the land has not been surveyed. When finally surveyed and entered into the General Land Office records, Josepha (Jose has died in 1904) proves up on their claim. Probably the Vail family buys the homestead shortly thereafter, though no record of that purchase has yet been found.
events.source: #Parkhurst J, Kaldahl K and Dart A. Cultural Resources Survey, Historic Building Inventory, and A Historic Context for Pima County's 366-Acre Empirita Ranch Property East of Tucson, Arizona. Old Pueblo Archaeology Center Tech. Rep. 2002.002; 2002

events.title: Transfer Act of 1905 moves Forest Service to Agriculture Dept.
events.description: The Transfer Act shifts the Forest Service from the Department of the Interior to Agriculture and gives the agency the responsibility of wisely managing the National Forest resources including grasslands. Early assessments by range surveyors indicate that forest grasslands are already carrying too many animals. The Forest Service instigates a policy of grazing permits for chosen ranchers. Later each permittee is allowed access to specific fenced areas (allotments) for a specified number of livestock. A policy of transfer reductions requiring a 10 percent reduction in the number of allowed animals with each transfer of the permit to a new owner is implemented in 1907 to slowly ease the amount of overgrazing. This automatic reduction policy is ended in 1953. Since then animal reductions are only imposed in order to improve range conditions.
events.source: #Pinto RL. Cattle Grazing in the National Parks: Historical Development and History of Management in Three Southern Arizona Parks [dissertation]. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona; 2014

events.title: Bones of animals accumulate in Papago Springs Cave
events.description: Remains of at least 50 species of vertebrate animals are deposited in Papago Springs Cave. The most abundant animal is an extinct four-horned pronghorn (Stockoceros onusrosagris). The fauna suggests the local open grasslands near ponderosa forests at the peak time of deposition, about 42 thousand years ago during the last interglacial period.
events.source:
#Skinner MF. The Fauna of Papago Springs Cave, Arizona, and a Study of Stockoceros; with three new Antilocaprines from Nebraska and Arizona. Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History. 1942. 80:143-220
#Czaplewski NJ, Mead JI, Ku T, Agenbroad LD. Papago Springs Cave Revisited, Part I: Geologic Setting, Cave Deposits, and Radiometric Dates. . Occasional Papers of the Oklahoma Museum of Natural History. 1999. 3:1-25
#Czaplewski NJ, Mead JI, Bell CJ, Peachey WD, Ku T. Papago Springs Cave Revisited, Part II: Vertebrate Paleofauna . Occasional Papers of the Oklahoma Museum of Natural History. 1999. 5:1-41

events.title: Large mammals occupy the Cienega Valley.
events.description: Bones of mastodon, camel, bison, horse, and probably mammoth are found from the last glacial period in several locations in and around the Cienega Valley. Unlike the nearby San Pedro Valley, no instances of direct association of artifacts and extinct mammals have yet been found in the Cienega Valley.
events.source:
#Mead JI, Czaplewski NJ, Agenbroad LD. Rancholabrean (Late Pleistocene) Mammals and Localities of Arizona. McCord RD ed. Vertebrate Paleontology of Arizona. Mesa, AZ: Mesa: Southwest Museum and Southwest Paleontological Society; 2005. p. 139-180
#Haynes CV Jr, Lindsay EH, Saunders JJ. The Billings Mastodon: A Terminal Pleistocene Locality in Santa Cruz County, Arizona. PaleoAmerica. 2016. 2:362-367

events.title: First description of Pleistocene fossils
events.description: Territorial Geologist and University of Arizona professor William Blake publishes the first account of extinct Pleistocene mammals from the Cienega watershed. He proposed a new species, Bos arizonica, for large horn cores of an extinct bison found near Greaterville and noted a mastodon tooth from Davidson Canyon near the Andrade Ranch. The bison was later referred to extinct species Bison latifrons. These were the first reports of extinct bison and mastodon in Arizona.
events.source:
#Blake WP. Remains of a Species of Bos in the Quaternary of Arizona. American Geologist. 1898. 22:65-72
#Arizona Governor. Report of the Governor of Arizona to the Secretary of the Interior for the Fiscal Year ended June 30, 1898. . . Washington DC: Government Printing Office ; 1898. p.84-85

events.title: Mammoth or mastodon tusk found along Cienega Creek.
events.description: University of Arizona students with Instructor Clara Lee Frap find and retrieve 250-pound section of a tusk of either a mammoth or mastodon from near Cienega Creek for the Arizona State Museum.
events.source: #. Mammoth or mastodon tusk found along Cienega Creek.. Arizona Daily Star. November 14, 1929; November 17, 1929.

events.title: Extinct Pronghorn found in Papago Springs Cave
events.description: Prep School teenagers Quentin Roosevelt and Joseph Burden explore Papago Springs Cave near the southern headwaters of Cienega Creek and recover elements of an extinct four-horned pronghorn. With assistance of American Museum of Natural History paleontologist Childs Frick, Roosevelt and Burden publish a description a new species, now known as Quentin's pronghorn or Tetrameryx (now Stockoceros) onusrosagris. In 1936 Roosevelt and Burden return to Papago Springs Cave and recover more extinct pronghorn fossils. Paleontologists Edwin Colbert and John Chaffee describe the collection in greater detail.
events.source:
#Roosevelt Q, Burden JW. A New species of Antilocaprine, Tetrameryx onusrosagris, from a Pleistocene Cave Deposit in Southern Arizona, No 754. New York City, NY: American Museum of Natural History; 1934
#Colbert ES, Chaffee RG. A study of Tetrameryx and associated fossils from Papago Spring Cave, Sonoita, Arizona, Noviate 1034 . New York City, NY: American Museum of Natural History; 1939
#White RS Jr. Papago Springs Cave, pronghorns and paleontology: Red Fields and the Burden of Proof.. Lucas SG, Morgan GS, Spielmann JA, Prothero DR eds, Neogene Mammals, Bulletin 44 . Albuquerque,NM: Museum of Natural History and Science ; 2008. p. 365-374

events.title: Extensive excavations in Papago Springs Cave.
events.description: Morris Skinner of the American Museum of Natural History leads excavations of fossil-bearing deposits, recovering more extinct pronghorn and fossils of 34 Pleistocene genera.
events.source:
#Skinner MF. The Fauna of Papago Springs Cave, Arizona, and a Study of Stockoceros; with three new Antilocaprines from Nebraska and Arizona. Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History. 1942. 80:143-220
#Czaplewski NJ, Mead JI, Bell CJ, Peachey WD, Ku T. Papago Springs Cave Revisited, Part II: Vertebrate Paleofauna . Occasional Papers of the Oklahoma Museum of Natural History. 1999. 5:1-41

events.title: Renewed investigations at Papago Springs Cave.
events.description: Paleontologist Nick Czaplewski and his colleagues return to Papago Springs to obtain radiometric dates and samples of small vertebrates. They find bone-bearing cave deposits date from about 250,000 to 26,000 years ago with dates most closely associated with the extinct Stockoceros pronghorn and most other species dating about 42,000 years ago, during the last interglacial of the Pleistocene. Czaplewski and others found 27 taxa, mainly small vertebrates, that were not reported by Skinner, giving a total of over 50 species, 8 or 9 of which are extinct.
events.source:
#Czaplewski NJ, Mead JI, Ku T, Agenbroad LD. Papago Springs Cave Revisited, Part I: Geologic Setting, Cave Deposits, and Radiometric Dates. . Occasional Papers of the Oklahoma Museum of Natural History. 1999. 3:1-25
#Czaplewski NJ, Mead JI, Bell CJ, Peachey WD, Ku T. Papago Springs Cave Revisited, Part II: Vertebrate Paleofauna . Occasional Papers of the Oklahoma Museum of Natural History. 1999. 5:1-41

events.title: Intensive archaeological survey in Empire Valley
events.description: Archaeologist Michelle Stevens of the Center for Desert Archaeology leads volunteers in a survey of 44 square miles in the Cienega Valley, locating 360 previously unrecorded sites, more than twice the number previously known. The survey affirmed the importance of the Early Agricultural period as well the Hohokam in the valley, and led to the definition of a new projectile point type, Empire points, diagnostic of the Early Agricultural period.
events.source:
#Stevens MN. Archaic and Early Agricultural Land Use in the Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona. . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Unpublished PhD Dissertation; 2001
#Stevens MN. Archaic and Early Agricultural Land Use in the Cienega Valley. . Archaeology Southwest . 2001. 15(4):3-5
#Stevens MN, Silva RJ . Empire Points: An Addition to the San Pedro Phase Lithic Assemblage.. Kiva. 2002. 67:297-326

events.title: Mescal Wash archaeological excavation
events.description: Archaeologists from Statistical Research, Inc. led by field director Rein Vanderpot conducted archaeological data recovery at the Mescal Wash Site at the confluence of Mescal Wash and Cienega Creek. Over 100 houses were excavated at this large site long-lived site.
events.source:
#Vanderpot R, Jeffrey H. . The Mescal Wash Site: A Persistent Place in Southeastern Arizona. . Sullivan AP III, Bayman JM, eds, Hinterlands and Regional Dynamics in the Ancient Southwest. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press; 2007. p. 50-69
#Vanderpot R ed. The Mescal Wash Site: A Persistent Place along Cienega Creek, Southeastern Arizona, Statistical Research, Inc. Technical Series 96. Tucson, AZ: Statistical Research Inc.; 2017

events.title: Empire Ranch Fire Burns Many Buildings
events.description: Fire (possibly arson) begins in Empire Ranch Washroom building with explosion. Fought by Fort Huachuca soldiers who are camping at Ranch. Buildings/structures lost or badly damaged include Stables, Adobe Hay Barn and other secondary barns, windmill, water tank, cowboy housing, slaughter house, wooden fences, 25 tons of hay, and untold amounts of corn feed. The only buildings not burned are the residences and the blacksmith shop. No loss of animal or human life. Fire initiates major upgrades of headquarters and buildings including metal roofs on all buildings, cement stucco on all adobe buildings, and reconstruction of stables in stone.

events.title: Dry Spell of 9 years
events.description: According to local individuals interviewed during Empire Valley archaeological surveys, an extended dry spell of 9 years during the 1940s (and into early 1950s) during which time springs and wells dry up and natural grasses are desicated necessitating heavy feeding of livestock. Drought results in increase in erosion and heavy and rapid loss of silt. The growth of arroyos prevents the use of floodwater farmland since they are usually too deep for waters to overflow.
events.source: #Swanson EH Jr. An Archaeological Survey of the Empire Valley, Arizona . Tucson,AZ: University of Arizona, Department of Anthropology Unpublished Master's thesis ; 1951:17-18

events.title: Loss of springs during early 1900s in Cienega Creek
events.description: According to Gene Hummel, most of the springs in the upper Cienega Creek have dried up with 1 or 2 exceptions since 1907. Spring water sources that supported livestock are mostly replaced by wells and stock tanks.
events.source: #Swanson EH Jr. An Archaeological Survey of the Empire Valley, Arizona . Tucson,AZ: University of Arizona, Department of Anthropology Unpublished Master's thesis ; 1951:12

events.title: Floodwater farming at Empire Ranch
events.description: Only one location in the Empire Valley can be found where floodwater can and does overflow and that is the land along Cienega Creek presently utilized as farmland.' Acreage is small.
events.source: #Swanson EH Jr. An Archaeological Survey of the Empire Valley, Arizona . Tucson,AZ: University of Arizona, Department of Anthropology Unpublished Master's thesis ; 1951:19

events.title: Comanduran and troops camp at Cienega de los Pimos
events.description: Tucson Presidio commander, Captain don Antonio Comanduran camps at Cienega de los Pimos (Cienega Creek) with Mexican infantry and cavalry during a campaign to seek out and attack Western Apaches
events.source: #Henry F Dobyns. From Fire to Flood: Historic Destruction of Sonoran Desert Riverine Oases. Socorro NM: Ballena Press; 1981:18

events.title: Zuniga and troops camp at Cienega de los Pimas
events.description: Tucson Presidio commander, Captain Jose de Zuniga camps at Cienega de los Pimas (Cienega Creek) with Spanish and Apache troops to reconnoiter the terrain bewteen Tucson and the Zuni Pueblo.
events.source: #Henry F Dobyns. From Fire to Flood: Historic Destruction of Sonoran Desert Riverine Oases. Socorro NM: Ballena Press; 1981:18

events.title: Mormon Battalion camps at Cienega de los Pimas
events.description: Philip St George Cooke and the Mormon Battalion camp at Cienega de los Pimas 'on good ground with water, grass and fuel.' Cooke and the Mormon Battalion were reconnoitering a route between the Rio Grande and Fort Yuma in California. They travel from Benson to the southern end of the Rincon Mountains and pass near Cienega Creek. Cooke remarks on an extraordinary variety of cactus 'which should be called columnar; a straight column thirty feet high, nearly 2 feet in diameter, fluted very similarly to a Corinthian column, only the capital was wanting; some throw out one or more branches gracefully curved and then vertical, like branches of a candelabrum.' [Saguaro cactus]
events.source: #Cooke, Philip St George. The Conquest of New Mexico and California: an historical and personal Narrative. New York: G P Putnam's Sons; 1878:147-148

events.title: Pantano High School Students begin processing Vail Preservation Society collections
events.description: Pantano High School students begin processing collection of Monthan family letters ranging from 1920s-1950s.

events.title: Esmond Station K8 students conduct oral histories
events.description: Esmond Station K-8 students conduct oral histories as part of Vail Preservation Society education outreach.

events.title: Maize (corn) present at Cienega Creek
events.description: Maize (Zea) pollen is identified from non-archaeological deposits along Matty Canyon and Cienega Creek from sediment profiles by Paul S. Martin. The maize pollen is detected in a stratigraphic unit dated to the preceramic San Pedro archaeological phase about 800 BC (3000 BP). Later excavations (Huckell p.132) find carbonized maize at archaeological site EE: 2:35. The presence of maize in these deposits does not indicate that local populations are dependent on domestic crops but suggest maize is being included in the highly productive wild foods present in the area.
events.source:
#Huckell BB. Of Marshes and Maize--Preceramic Agricultural Settlements in the Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers Number 59; 1995
#Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Richard Chasey writes an annotated bibliography on Lehmann lovegrass
events.description: On behalf of the Cienega Watershed Partnership and the Bureau of Land Management Tucson, the Appleton-Whittell Audubon Research Ranch, Richard Chasey compiles a 55-page annotated bibilography to consolidate and summarize available literature on Lehmann lovegrass, entitled: Lehmann Lovegrass (eragrostis lehmanniana nees), Annotated Bibliography. Chasey considers this a work in progress as further sources are identified and new research occurs.

events.title: Three plant communities available to prehistoric Cienega people
events.description: At Cienega Creek and within a short range, three plant communities--: riparian, grassland, and oak woodland--offer rich and varied food plants available during different seasons. Bruce Huckell (pg. 25), describes the potential as including: in mid- to late spring: mesquite pods, chenopod greens and seeds, cattail pollen and rhizomes, agave, yucca, bear grass and sotol flowers in the riparian and grasslands with the agaves, yuccas, bear grass, and sotol extending into oak woodland. In summer and fall: acorns and walnuts, chenopod, amaranth, purslane and horse purslane greens and seeds, caryopses (grass seeds), juniper berries, wild grapes, mesquite pods. Foraging further would have opened higher elevation conifer forest or more arid plant zones like saguaro.
events.source: #Huckell BB. Of Marshes and Maize--Preceramic Agricultural Settlements in the Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers Number 59; 1995

events.title: Early agricultural sites indicate mix of maize and wild plants
events.description: Two archaeological sites, the Donaldson and Los Ojitos in Matty Canyon are excavated in 1958 and 1983. The archaeological and stratigraphic deposits define that a strategy of floodplain farming and foraging rich plant communities leads to repeated intensive use of sites along the Cienega Creek/Matty Canyon confluence. Pollen and macrobotanical samples attest to maize farming. Squash may have been grown. Lisa Huckell analyzes the plant remains and provides complete identifications of wild and domestic plants, either foraged or farmed.
events.source: #Huckell BB. Of Marshes and Maize--Preceramic Agricultural Settlements in the Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona. Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers Number 59; 1995

events.title: Maize (corn) field in creek deposits
events.description: A study of non-archaeological deposits at the Cienega Creek confluence with Matty Canyon suggest that an agricultural field was present. Over 99% of the pollen identified on a sample dates to 900 to 1200 AD, indicating the dominance of zea maize over wild plants at that location.
events.source: #Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Frog Population and Disease Report release
events.description: The FROG Project researched the Chiricahau Leopard Frog population movements, annual cycles, habitats, and affects of chytrid disease on the viability of the frog. The report with detailed analysis and management recommendations was released on December 19, 2019 to the Cienega Watershed Partnership and Bureau of Land Management (study funder).
events.source: #Hall D. Local Population Dynamics of the Chiricahua Leopard Frog (Rana chiricahuensis) a Federally-Listed Frog within the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area in Arizona, Report to the Cienega Watershed Partnership and the Bureau of Land Management. Tucson, A: FROG Project, Cienega Watershed Partnership ; Dec.19, 2019

events.title: Youth Engaged Stewardship students report wildlife cameras
events.description: Youth Engaged Stewardship (YES!) participants purchase four wildlife cameras to set up at two habitat ponds, Bill’s Pond and Cottonwood Pond, located in Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. The cameras record the following species and number of sightings: at Bill’s Pond: bobcat 10, red fox 7, mule deer 90, coyote 38, javelina 24, roadrunner 15, raccoon 4, hawk 1, great blue heron 4, crow 1. At the Cottonwood Pond: mule deer 22, great blue heron 11, javelina 94, coyote 6, hawks 6, great white heron 1, raccoon 12.
events.source: #YES! . Youth Engaged Stewardship YES! Wildlife Camera Observations 2017-2018. In-Albon C. Report to the Bureau of Land Management. Tucson, A: Cienega Watershed Partnership ; Nov 2018.

events.title: Black tailed Prairie Dog Cieneguita colony surveys by youth
events.description:
In June 2017 and 2018, retired Arizona Game and Fish Department biologist Robert Fink, Youth Engaged Stewardship (YES!) participants, and two program leaders sample active and total burrow densities on the original upper portion of the Cieneguita black-tailed prairie dog (Cynomys ludovicianus) colony on the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area. 
 2017 results: population densities of black-tailed prairie dogs are 87/hectare (ha), indicating a total population estimate of 464 prairie dogs, providing a 95% confidence interval (reliability) of 365 to 563 black-tailed prairie dogs on the Cieneguita colony. 2018 results: population densities of black-tailed prairie dogs are 109/ha, indicating a total population estimate of 464 prairie dogs, providing a 95% confidence interval (reliability) of 365 to 563 black-tailed prairie dogs on the Cieneguita colony. At 0.38 ha surveyed, 8.92% of the colony is sampled. One hectare is approximately 2.47 acres.
events.source: #Fink R et al. Population Status of Black-tailed prairie dogs in the Cieneguita colony in Southeast Arizona. Biological Planning Newsletter Tech Talk. Tucson, AZ: Cienega Watershed Partnership; Fall 2017. #Fink R et al. Population Status of Black-tailed prairie dogs in the Cieneguita colony in Southeast Arizona. Biological Planning Newsletter Tech Talk. Tucson, A: Cienega Watershed Partnership ; Fall 2018.

events.title: Pleistocene erosion forms terraces while revealing Cretaceous landforms
events.description: Pleistocene erosion and further regional uplift carved several prominent terraces (mainly streamlaid gravels and cross-bedded sands). Features that are visible today. Such events also removed deposits exposing Cretaceous rocks along the Creek channel which represent nearshore and floodplain types of depositional environments.
events.source: #Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Alluviation builds Cienega Creek floodplain while erosion carves creek floor
events.description: In the Recent era but especially in the last four thousand years, alluviation and erosion have continually changed the Cienega Creek floodplain and creek floor. Alluviation buildt the floodplain to its current level by deposits of alluvial materials, mainly in swamps and ponds. Periods of erosion carve out the creek floor. This continuous process expanded the floodplain available for farming but causes headcuts, creek sediment erosion and other issues. In the last 2500 years bp, the expanding floodplains provided arable land for early farmers along the Cienega Creek and drainages.
events.source: #Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Mapping of Matty Wash and Cienega Creek strategraphic sections
events.description: As part of the mutli-disciplinary approach to understanding the prehistoric sites in the Cienega Creek and Matty (Canyon) Wash area, Eddy and cooley map the arroyo walls from the their juncture to one mile upstream, totaling 4424 meters at a scale of one inch to 50 feet. The goal is to understand the sedimentary environments and the alluvial stratigeraphy for each site. Seven stratigraphic sctions of the Recent alluvium are described and dated using radiocarbon and stratigraphic relationships. Determining the rate of alluviation proves difficult given the long history of alluviation and scouring but this continuous cycle still marks the creek and wash floors and walls.
events.source: #Eddy FW, Cooley ME. Cultural and Environmental History of Cienega Valley, Southeastern Arizona . Tucson, AZ: University of Arizona Press Anthropological Papers No. 43.; 1983

events.title: Fire Impacts on grassland studies
events.description: Researchers Carl Bock and Jane Bock report on 28 years of research at or adjacent to the Appleton-Whittell Research Ranch: 1) grazing reduces grass cover and fire frequency while encouraging shorter-stature grasses and wildlife typical of lower elevantion desert sites; 2) fires cause temporary declines in grass cover and some shrubs, and temporary increases in herbs and seeds while favoring birds, rodents and insects dependent on seeds and preferring more open habitats; and, 3) droughts cause temporary declines in shrubs, certain herbs and grasses, and associated wildlife. Plains lovegrass appears to survive drought better if it has recently burned.
events.source: #Bock CE, Bock JH. Factors Controlling the Structure and Function of Desert Grasslands: A Case Study from Southeastern Arizona. In:Tellman B, Finch D, Edminster C, Hamre R The Future of Arid Grasslands: Identifying Issues, Seeking Solutions. Fort Collins, CO: Rocky Mountain Research Station ; 1998. p.33-44

events.description: The 50-acre (0.202 sq. km.) Clyne Fire is near Willow Springs west of Apache Peak, one mile outside of Coronado National Forest. Because of its proximity to the Forest, it is fought by 18 USFS firefighters.

events.title: Cienega Fire
events.description: The Cienega Fire burns 10 acres (0.0405 sq. km.) near Empire Ranch Headquarters. Two other fires (Pit Fire and Windmill Fire) are on Las Cienegas National Conservation Area at same time. Total burned for the three fires is 500 acres (2.023 sq. km.). Fought by 4 fire engines and several aircraft.

events.description: The Empire 2 Fire starts in tall grass on the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area about 10 miles N of Sonoita and E of milepost 40 on State Rte. 83 near Empire Ranch. 611 acres (2.473 sq. km.) burn.

events.title: Hilton Fire
