events.title: Cienega Fire
events.description: The lightning-caused Cienega Fire burns 1,500 acres (6.07 sq. km.) in Cienega Creek 20 miles SW of Benson. The grass fire employs 40 firefighters. A B-17 Flying Fortress bomber dumping fire retardant crashes on lower Whetstone slope. No injuries reported.
events.source: #. Cienega Fire. Arizona Daily Star . July 13, 1971. Pg. 4

events.title: Montosa Fire
events.description: The lightning-caused Montosa Fire burns 10,301 acres (41.681 sq. km.). It starts in foothills of western Whetstone Mountains (6 miles east of Empire Fire), burns northward into the grasslands of Empirita and Empire Ranches. There is concern that fire will move into Cienega Creek Natural Preserve. After the fire, grazing in burned area is deferred for many years to allow grasses to recover. Fire controls shrubby invasions of creosote, white thorn acacia, and sand paper bush on several thousand acres of semi-desert grasslands. Fire is fought by more than 300 firefighters. Cost to control: $1M.
events.source: #. Montosa Fire. Arizona Daily Star . June 30, July 2, 1990. Pg. 1, Pg. 5

events.title: Oak Tree Fire
events.description: Human-caused Oak Tree Fire burns 4,471 acres (18.03 sq. km.) in Las Cienegas National Conservation Area.

events.title: Mulberry Fire
events.description: Human-caused Mulberry Fire burns 1,755 acres (7.103 sq. km.). Starts at Red Cloud Mine Rd., 8 miles SE of Vail, and spreads north along west side of Empire Mountains, stopping short of Bar V Ranch. Burns 4 houses, with evacuation of 20 residents. Fought by 200 firefighters. Cost of firefighting is $700,000.
events.source: #. Mulberry Fire . Arizona Daily Star . May 9, 2017. Pg. A1, Pg. A4, Pg. A41

events.title: Sawmill Fire in Cienega Valley
events.description: The Sawmill Fire is caused by, and immediately reported by, an off-duty Border Patrol agent who is shooting recreationally. The fire burns 46,991 acres (189.842 sq. km.). It starts on west side of Santa Rita Mountains and rapidly spreads east through Cienega Valley up to J- 6 Ranch near Benson. 412 residents are evacuated and State Rte. 83 is closed. 600 firefighters employed. High winds ground air support for a time. Suppression costs $8.2 M. Fire burns 42% in grasslands, 38% in shrub, 10% in oak-conifer association, and 4% in piñon-juniper association. The fire burns 28% (12,000 acres or 48.562 sq. km.) of land in the Las Cienegas National Conservation Area, including significant riparian areas within Empire Gulch and Cienega Creek, and increases threat to endangered fish, amphibians, Yellow-billed Cuckoo, and Huachuca water umbel. The fire re-burns 1,800 acres (7.284 sq. km.) of the 2011 Greaterville Fire, 2/3 of the 2015 Oak Tree Fire (2,023 acres or 8.287 sq. km.), the 2012 Empire Fire (148 acres or 0.599 sq. km.), and the 2016 Hilton Fire (163 acres or 0.66 sq. km.). Large amounts of flammable biomass due to heavy 2016 monsoon rains produce ideal conditions for a massive fire. The fire severity is highest in the western part of the fire (33% with 90% canopy mortality). In the eastern half, 41% saw little or no canopy mortality.
events.source: #Bureau of Land Management. Las Cienegas National Conservation Area Post Sawmill Fire Emergency Stabilization and Rehabilitation . Personal Communication .June 8, 2017. #Gabbert B. Firefighters Make Progress on the Sawmill Fire in Arizona. Wildfire Today. April 28, 2017.
events.Expert: Gerardo added an importance of 3 to this event

events.title: Florida Fire
events.description: The Florida Fire, which burns 23,201 acres (93.891 sq. km.), is caused by a lightning strike on Florida Peak in Santa Rita Mountains. Fire burns down the eastern slopes of Santa Rita Mountains and later spills over onto west side. Area has not burned to any significant degree since the 1950s. Terrain, almost vertical in higher elevations, presents major challenges to firefighting. Surrounding areas--Madera Canyon, Box Canyon, Gardner Canyon, Greaterville area---are all closed to access: Later Madera Canyon homeowners and investigators on Mount Hopkins telescopes are evacuated as fire surges south and west. At peak of containment effort: about 1,000 personnel (16 elite hot shot crews, 6 - 20-person teams, 7 helicopter tankers to deliver retardant, 27 fire engines, 6 bulldozers) are involved. Final cost of control: $6.5M. Only the arrival of monsoon rains on July 18 stems the continuing rapid expansion of fire lines. After a year, major portions of Santa Rita National Forest remain closed due to hazardous soil and vegetation conditions.
events.source: #. Florida Fire burns Santa Ritas. Arizona Daily Star . July 21, 2005. Pg. 3

events.title: Highest Cienega Creek flow in two decades
events.description: Monitoring of Cienega Creek shows highest flow in two decades. Near-record rainfall in the Tucson metropolitan are in summer 2021 contrasted with the year before with almost no rainfall. Before the monsoon began, the creek was experiencing the lowest flow in nearly 40 years of Pima Association of Governments (PAG) monitoring, with surface water visible on just 7% of the 9.5-mile monitored area. Colossal Cave area received 21 inches of rain flooding the cave.

events.title: Archaeologist relocate prehistoric early agricultural sites
events.description: Desert Archaeology, under contract to the Cienega Watershed Partnership funded by a Bureau of Land Management grant, relocate 23 archaeological sites at Las Cienegas National Conservation Area dating to the prehistoric early agricultural phase. Sites were originally recorded by the Cienega Valley Survey in the late 1990s. Desert Archaeology finds that most sites are in good condition but some environmental, human and animal disturbance is evident. Recommended management includes avoiding and protection the sites which have the potential to provide significant information on when and how maize agriculture was adopted in the area.

events.title: Storm Octave worst storm event in Pima County history
events.description: Tropical storm Octave is the worst flood event in Pima County and worst tropical system throughout Arizona. 5 days of continual rain. 13 people killed. $500M damage across state. Duncan, Hayden, Winkelman, Marana all submerged. 10,000 people driven from homes. Active monsoon through September – 2nd wettest month since 1941 – left ground saturated. By October 3, there had been six days of rain. On October 3, 6” of rain fell in 36 hours. 12” of rain on Mt Graham. 15 major rockslides on Catalina Highway. Homes on Pantano Wash washed away. Vail and Rincon Valley residents isolated. Ranch del Lago was a mudflat pocked with lakes and lagoons. The regional flood of October 1-3, 1983 caused $226 M in damage in southeastern Arizona. Rainfall was most intense in a narrow band from south of Tucson to Clifton. Peak discharges on the Santa Cruz and Aravaipa were more than twice those observed in the previous 65 years. The flood was the largest on record at Clifton.
events.source: 1983 September 28 - October 3 Wikipedia “Tropical Storm Octave (1983)” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_Storm_Octave_(1983)#:~:text=The%20system%20is%20considered%20the,while%202%2C052%20others%20were%20damaged. 2) “National Water Summary 1988-1989. Floods and Droughts: Arizona.” Pages 181-188. In: “Hydrologic Events and Floods and Droughts.” USGS Water-Supply Paper #2375. RW Paulson, EB Chase, RS Roberts and D Moody, Compilers. 1991.

events.title: Heavy rains flooding rail lines and destroying adobe houses
events.description: In a letter from Walter Vail to Edward Vail dated Aug 30, he reports that throughout AZ territory, very heavy thunderstorms accompanied by heavy rain and water spouts. Walter Vail notes that all of the adobes constructed for the first addition to the Empire HQ were destroyed in these rains. Tucson newspaper reports that it is shut off from outside world for 2 weeks due to considerable damage to railroad lines by recent flood.
events.source: Arizona Weekly Star Pg. 3 Letter from Walter L Vail to Edward Vail, August 30, 1878. ERF

events.title: Flooding and wash outs close rail lines and roads
events.description: Newpaper accounts describe flooding and rain damage. Flooding and washout of Southern Pacific railroad tracks between Pantano and Papago stations. Road between Pantano and Davidson’s spring now open on the high land. Old road up the Valley to the Empire Ranch is now impassible on account of the late rains. All freighting stopped.
events.source: Arizona Daily Star Pg.3 (7-27); Arizona Daily Star Pg. 3 (7-29)

events.title: Southern Pacific Railroad track washes out
events.description: Southern Pacific Railroad track washed out from Pantano Station to Cienega Bridge. Train thrown into washout. Cloudburst washed out telegraph poles and lines.
events.source: Arizona Daily Citizen Pg. 4

events.title: Storm damage severe along Cienega Creek
events.description: A series of newspaper reports note the Sept 9 and 10 storm damage. Arizona Daily Star Sept 9 and 10: Flooding causes Southern Pacific Railway railroad ties to be carried from Cienega Creek down to Ft Lowell. 100 workers sent to repair Cienega Creek washout. Several miles of SPRR track and some bridges in the vicinity of Pantano were washed away. Sept 13 Arizona Daily Star: “It will take 3 weeks to repair washed out places so that trains can pass over the road. … The present is the most destructive washout yet suffered by the SPRR, and it will cost not less than $200,000 to repair the damage.” Damage at foot of Dragoon Mountains has 50’ of fill that needs to be removed. Pump house engine at Benson station washed away. Between Benson and Ochoa stations, 8 miles of track washed away. Ties lifted by floodwaters with rails on top redeposited on top of mesa 40’ above wash bed. Rails bent around trees. Arizona Daily Star Sept 16 reports 300 men working on the Cienega Cree washout. Sept 17 damage report in Arizona Weekly Citizen 9.5 miles of railroad track are gone from Cienega Creek. 2 covered bridges, one 60 feet in length picked up and carried downstream. September 22 Arizona Weekly Star notes that crops between Benson and Mammoth on San Pedro River ruined from floods.
events.source: 1887 September 9 Arizona Daily Star Pg. 4; September 10 AZ Daily Star pg. 4 1887 September 13 AZ Daily Star pg. 4 1887 September 14 AZ Daily Star pg 4 1887 September 16 AZ Daily Star pg 4 1887 September 17 AZ Weekly Citizen Pg. 4 1887 September 22 AZ Weekly Star pg. 2

events.title: Damaging rains in Patagona area
events.description: Bloxton Family letter pg.69: “Last night the rains washed the wheels off the Hay Press, washed the Fence away to the north field at the Pass, barn and all, toppled the RR Bridge, piled logs up to near the top. Large logs, stumps and trash washed all over the fields. The field is most all washed away.” “We had the largest freshet (rain-induced flood) that has ever been known for years. No trains since Wednesday. 6 bridges gone between here (Patagonia) and Calabasas. I do not expect any trains from Nogales for 2 or 3 weeks. It washed out the alfalfa field so that we cannot cut it. Cady’s crop of beans and corn most washed away. The water was over the top of the fence at the north end of the mill field at the Railroad.” “Below the Sanford Station, the road and bridges are washed out in several places and mired in quick sand. The flood is still coming.”
events.source: 2019 Garber P Westward Bound With the Bloxtons. Settling the Arizona Territory; One Family’s Amazing Journey West p 69. Private Publication

events.title: Widespread rain damage includes Pantano bridge
events.description: August 5 through 9. Heavy rains have swollen rivers. 60 miles of the Southern Pacific RR between Benson and Nogales were washed out. Largest floods in 20 years on the Santa Cruz River. The Iron bridge at Pantano taken out in flood. August 30: More washouts in the Cienega and at Pantano.
events.source: 1890 August 5-9 AZ Weekly Citizen pg 3, Arizona Daily Star pg. 2 on August 6; AZ Weekly Citizen pg. 3 August 9 1890 August 30 AZ Weekly Citizen pg 4

events.title: Widespread storm damage Tucson to San Pedro
events.description: August 13 storm drops 2.5” rain in Tucson in 70 minutes with widespread damage. Rain extended from Casa Grande to Lordsburg and South to Bisbee and Douglas. All of Tucson without power. Continued rains cause SPRR wash-out at Fairbanks. Water waist deep on Broadway and First. Rillito running 200 yards beyond banks on each side. Santa Cruz River over banks and rising. Sonoita roads washed out.
events.source: 1940 August 13-15 Tucson Citizen (8/14) pg 1; AZ Daily Star (8/15) pg 5

events.title: Wettest December since record keeping began in So AZ has serious impacts
events.description: On Dec 10, the Tucson Daily Citizen reported 3 days of rain dump 4” on Catalina Mountains. 1.75” fall in 24 hours. Santa Cruz and Rillito Rivers raging with swollen waters. That was just the beginning rains for the wettest December on record at that time since record keeping began. . 7.27” rain in this month. The Rillito River running at a record rate. Erosion caused ruptured sewer lines at Pantano Wash. Bridges over Rillito damaged and closed to traffic Flooding in the Upper Gila, San Francisco Rivers, at San Carlos, Ajo, Sells, Yuma. 13 days of rain have fallen by December 25. Tanque Verde bridge washed out. $4M in damages across Pima County.
events.source: 1965 December 10 Tucson Daily Citizen pg 1 1965 December 23-25 Tucson Daily Citizen (12/23) pg 1, 9; AZ Daily Star (12/23) pg 1, 3; AZ Republic (12/24) pg 12; AZ Daily Star (12/25) pg 16

events.title: Storm Emilia produces historic floods at Rincon and Pantano
events.description: Tropical Storm Emilia produces 5 days of rain. 5-11” in Catalina and Rincon Mountains. Tanque Verde Creek area on July 31 receives 4-6”. Peak flood flow in Rillito at 32,900 cubic feet per second. Rincon Creek at 9 feet depth. Gauge washed away. Last measure 7,880 cfs. Pantano wash peak flow at 25,600 cfs. Pantano wash channel at Speedway lowered 8 feet. 200 debris flow locations in Catalina Mountains between Esperero Canyon and Soldier Canyon. Widespread geological change from landslides like that not seen in 10,000 years. (Historic Flood Events. Pima County website)
events.source: 2006 July 27-31 https://webcms.pima.gov/cms/one.aspx?portalId=169&pageId=60316

events.title: Heavy rainfall Vail and Cienega Creek
events.description: 1.5-2’ rainfall in Corona de Tucson in less than 1 hour. Upper Cienega Creek received 0.5”, Canelo Hills 2-2.5” of rain. Vail area and lower Cienega Creek received 3.5-5” of rain in less than 24 hours. (Historic Flood Events. Pima County website)
events.source: 2014 July 5-7 https://webcms.pima.gov/cms/one.aspx?portalId=169&pageId=60316

events.title: High waters wash away bridge
events.description: Very high waters come down Cienega at 2 PM. Washed away Don Alonzo Sanford’s bridge over the creek.
events.source: Robin RL History of Don Alonzo Sanford and the Development of the Stock Valley Ranch in the Cienega Valley

events.title: Rain damage severe in Patagonia area
events.description: Bloxton Family letters pages 69-70 describe September rains: Sept 2 “Part of the Leinder field is under water and there is lots of trash washed on it. It rained hard most every day and night.” Sept 10 “I do not know when they will get the trains running again. They are at work on the bridge at Cady’s (near Patagonia) with pile drivers. We had the hardest storm last Friday and Saturday that we have had this season. The rain and hail struck me before I got to the horse corral and could not get any farther and could not cross the river. When I got home the next morning, I found part of the roof off my shed. The whole upper field had been under water over the corn, barley and wheat. The levy had withstood all the storms until this one. It took the levy and all the fence from the corral to the ditch, trees and all, except the 2 largest at the ditch. Washed out the RR so we have no trains.”
events.source: Garber book, pg 69-70 1890 September 2 Garber pg 69-70 1890 September 10 Garber pg. 70

events.title: Heavy rains affect railroads
events.description: July 22, the AZ WeeklyCitizen reports that the Cienega Creek has been on a rampage for 10 days. Heavy rains around Greaterville. August 6-7, the AZ Daily Star reports that heavy rains washed out railroads east and west of Tucson. Railroad traffic is delayed.
events.source: 1893 July 22 AZ Weekly Citizen pg 3 1893 August 6-7 AZ Daily Star pg. 4

events.title: Sonoita railroad tracks wash out
events.description: Floods wash out New Mexico and Arizona RR tracks in Sonoita. Cloud burst causes death and destruction in San Pedro and Bisbee.
events.source: 1896 October 14 AZ Daily Star; Garber pg 31

events.title: Area thunderstorms produce flooding
events.description: Several thunderstorms over greater Tucson area. Rillito Creek overflows banks in several places. Severe flooding in city. 2 inches of rain in 1 hour. Sonoita Creek at flood stage. 3 Bridges on Vail-Benson Highway damaged.
events.source: 1950 July 30-31 AZ Daily Star (7-30) pg 1, 2; AZ Republic (7-31) pg 1

events.title: Flooding in Santa Cruz and San Pedro Rivers
events.description: Flooding in the Santa Cruz and San Pedro Rivers. Flooding across Cochise County. Flooding in Tucson from Santa Rita Mountains.
events.source: 1954 August 2-6AZ Daily Star (8/3) pg 5; Tucson Citizen (8/5) pg 20; Tucson Citizen (8/6) pg 1

events.title: Great storm damage for 60 years in Tucson
events.description: 4.92” of rain flooding streets and buildings in Tucson. Greatest storm damage in 60 years. Cfs 38,000 highest flow at the Pantano since 1958 according to range gauge
events.source: 1958 July 30 AZ Daily Star pg 13

events.title: Hurrican Heather produces major flooding
events.description: Remnants of last Pacific storm of 1977 year, Hurricane Heather, enter Arizona on October 6 producing 4 days of rain. Measurable rainfall of 8”; reports of 14”. Major flooding on Santa Cruz and San Pedro Rivers on morning of the 9th. Santa Cruz River sees highest discharge since 1892: 30,000-40,000 cfs. 2 bridges destroyed; 12-15 damaged. $14.6 M in damages. City of Tucson wells inundated with mud and rendered unusable.
events.source: 1977 October 6-9 Wikipedia “1977 Pacific Hurricane Season” https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Heather#:~:text=Hurricane%20Heather%20was%20one%20of,tropical%20depression%20on%20October%204.

events.title: Heavy rain damaging in Vail
events.description: 4.5” rain on July 24. 7.5 feet of floodwater in Tanque Verde Creek. Vail has 1.2” rain. Pantano wash at Colossal Cave road running 6.5 feet in depth. $1.7M in damage.
events.source: 1990 July 24-25 Tucson Citizen (7/25) pg 1A, 2A, 2C, AZ Daily Star pg 4

events.title: Rillito raging
events.description: Cloudburst flooded streets of Tucson to depth of 4 feet causing ~ $10,000 in damage. Rillito is a raging river, immense bodies of water coming down from the mountains, filling the water bed from six to nine feet deep. The Rillito is fully a quarter of a mile wide.
events.source: AZ Weekly Citizen pg 4.

events.title: Train uses new tracks
events.description: Southern Pacific Railroad train passes over new tracks for the first time since 1887 summer floods.
events.source: 1888 June 16 AZ Weekly Citizen pg. 3

events.title: Rains damage railway lines
events.description: Big flood yesterday in Cienega Creek. Rains damage RR lines between Pantano and Mescal. Cienega area despite high waters are now safe since RR lines moved to high ground.
events.source: 1888 July 28-29 Tucson Daily Citizen Pg. 4; AZ Daily Star pg. 4

events.title: Rains damaging in Sonoita Patagonia area
events.description: Family letter: “We had a great deal of rain last week. … It rained so hard that we could not cross the Oria (arroyo) until morning. … The animals (horses and cattle) that have been killed, the high water has washed away. All the Borrows (burros?) are all gone. Portions of the Sacy (acequia) are washed out and other places filled with sand. Nearly all the middle and lower fields were under water. The fences in the Orios are all washed out.” Blostonsletters tell of their family settlement on Patagonia Sonoita ranches, p. 68
events.source: 2019 Garber P Westward Bound With the Bloxtons. Settling the Arizona Territory; One Family’s Amazing Journey West p 68. Private Publication

events.title: Rain damage to farm in Patagonia area
events.description: A Bloxton family letter (page 70) reports: “The heaviest hail storm that I most ever saw struck us about 10 o’clock last night and drove us out of the shed. The rains came through the roof where it had never leaked before. There were heaps of hail this morning and it rained most all night. The hail riddled my corn.”
events.source: 1890 October 2 Garber pg. 70

events.title: San Pedro flooding
events.description: Floods on the San Pedro River wash out and bury several farms.
events.source: 1891 April 12 AZ Daily Star Pg. 4

events.title: Heavy rain washes Ft Lowell bridge out
events.description: Heavy rains drop 2 inches in 2 hours. Fort Lowell bridge washed out.
events.source: 1895 August 11 Arizona Republic pg 8

events.title: Flooding at Pantano abd beyond
events.description: Flooding at town of Pantano. Major floods in Tucson and Santa Cruz River
events.source: 1911 September 15 Tucson Citizen pg 1; Bisbee Daily Review pg 8

events.title: Pantano and Cienega Gorge flooding
events.description: Two bridges torn out. Flooding out homes along Rillito Creek and Santa Cruz River. River at town of Pantano 9 feet deep. Cienega Gorge choked with water.
events.source: 1935 September 1 AZ Daily Star pg 1, 4

events.title: Worst flood in 30 years on Gila River
events.description: “August 1934 One of the worst floods in thirty years occurred on the Gila River. The flood drove many residents from Duncan, Greenlee county, swept livestock away, and stopped railroad and highway traffic. Damage was estimated at $15,000 (Ingram 19). PEAK FLOWS: Gila R @ Clifton: 17,000 cfs (8/26/34) San Francisco R @ Clifton: 11,700 cfs (8/26/34) Gila R @ Solomon: 23,000 cfs (8/27/34) Gila R @ Calva: 18,000 cfs (8/28/34) Sonoita Creek @ Patagonia: 11,000 cfs (8/?/34)”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory

events.title: Heavy rains causes damage in Pima County
events.description: “August 17/20, 1959 On the 17th, heavy rains caused about $75,000 damage with Pima county. On the 20th, an estimated $50,000 damage was caused when stores, warehouses, and homes were flooded. PEAK FLOWS: Eagle Creek above Morenci: 4,780 cfs (8/17/59) Gila R @ Kelvin: 5,930 cfs (8/17/59) Pantano Wash @ Vail: 9,310 cfs (8/17/59) Santa Cruz R @ Cortaro: 8,000 cfs (8/20/59)”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory

events.title: Thunderstorms flood 100 Tucson streets
events.description: “September 24, 1976 In Tucson, thunderstorms with heavy rain filled washes, especially the Pantano Wash and Rillito River. Flooding occurred on almost one hundred streets and roads, particularly on the north and east sides of town. Nearly a dozen cars were swept into washes on the east side. One man was missing and presumed drowned. Two boys were carried down the Rillito River 1.5 miles before they could reach ground (Ingram 43). PEAK FLOWS: Alamo Wash @ Tucson: 3,200 cfs (9/24/76) Rillito Creek near Tucson: 9,400 cfs (9/24/76)”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory

events.title: Heavy rains fill Tucson creeks
events.description: “March 4-20, 1978 9.53 inches of rainfall occurred on Mt Lemmon. Overflows of the Gila River flooded Duncan and 1000-2000 acres of farmland in Safford Valley. The Rillito Creek, Pantano and Tanque Verde Creeks in Tucson were near bankfull (PHX HSM).”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory

events.title: Fierce thunderstorm fills Pantano wash and others
events.description: “August 23, 1982 A fierce thunderstorm with up to 4 inches of rain, marble-size hail and wind up to 50-60 mph, caused considerable street flooding and extensive property damage. About 40 mobile homes were damaged, a dozen seriously, and several totally destroyed in a westside trailer park (Sellers et al. 75). PEAK FLOWS: Tanque Verde Creek near Tucson: 2,460 cfs (8/23/82) Pantano Wash near Vail: 3,400 cfs (8/23/82)”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory

events.title: High Tucson rainfall damaging to homes and bridges
events.description: “January 7-19, 1993 Roads, bridges, homes and businesses suffered considerable damage in Pima County beginning on the 7th. A new all-time January record of 4.81 inches fell in Tucson, eclipsing the 4.00 inches in 1916. Numerous rescues were made throughout southeast Arizona as motorists tried to drive vehicles through creeks and low spots. Several thousand people were isolated in their homes as flood waters from the Rillito River cut off all roads. A weather-related crash in Tucson left 7 people hospitalized. Two major bridges over the Santa Cruz River were closed. Many roads closed in both Greenlee and Graham Countie” (“Southeast Arizona Flood History”, p. 19); “20/22 due to flooding. Duncan was the hardest hit. Half of the town was under water when a dike broke and later left at least 150 people homeless. The San Francisco River and Gila River flooded some farmland near Safford. Uncontrolled flow passed over the Coolidge Dam spillways for the first time since it was built (Storm Data).” “Pantano Wash (Broadway Blvd.): 4,340 cfs (1/18/93)”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory

events.title: Severe thunderstorm fill streets and Pantano Wash
events.description: “August 19, 1994 A devastating severe thunderstorm occurred just northeast of downtown Tucson, Arizona between approximately 225 and 330 pm. Along with wind damage, flash flooding occurred in both eastern Pima and Santa Cruz counties. Normally dry washes in the Pantano Wash area were running with two feet of water in some places. City streets were considerably flooded, especially between Broadway and Grant. A vehicle became stranded in one of the underpases and eventually the car was totally under water...but no one was injured. Washes were running over and streets were like rivers. Considerable flooding also occurred in Santa Cruz County as well, from an entirely different storm during the warning period (from local storm report).”
events.link: flood events in Southeast Arizona from NWS. https://www.weather.gov/twc/hydro_floodhistory
